HyPar  1.0
Finite-Difference Hyperbolic-Parabolic PDE Solver on Cartesian Grids
  • Main Page
  • Related Pages
  • Namespaces
  • Data Structures
  • Files
  • File List
  • Globals
 All Data Structures Namespaces Files Functions Variables Typedefs Macros Pages
doc/Examples.md
Go to the documentation of this file.
1 Examples
2 ========
3 
4 \subpage basic_examples :
5 Some basic examples that are simulated using HyPar. They
6 all use explicit time integration, and \b do \b not require HyPar to be compiled
7 with any external library.
8 Most of them can be run on one or a small number of processors.
9 
10 \subpage petsc_examples :
11 Some examples that use implicit or semi-implicit (IMEX) time
12 integration methods implemented in PETSc. To run them, HyPar needs to be compiled \b with \b PETSc.
13 
14 \subpage ib_examples : Examples that use the immersed boundary method to simulate various geometries.
15 
16 \subpage md_examples : Examples that use the multidomain functionality.
17 
18 \subpage sg_examples : Examples that use the sparse grids spatial discretization.
19 
20 \subpage librom_examples : Examples that use reduced-order modeling capabilities from libROM.
21 
22 \page basic_examples Basic Examples
23 
24 The following are some basic examples that are simulated using HyPar. They
25 all use explicit time integration, and \b do \b not require HyPar to be compiled
26 with any external libraries.
27 
28 \subpage linear_adv_sine \n
29 \subpage linear_adv_sine_varyingadv \n
30 \subpage linear_adv_disc \n
31 \subpage linear_diff_sine
32 
33 \subpage burger_1d_sine
34 
35 \subpage sod_shock_tube \n
36 \subpage lax_shock_tube \n
37 \subpage shu_osher \n
38 \subpage sod_shock_tube_wgrav
39 
40 \subpage sw_dambreak
41 
42 \subpage linear_adv_gauss \n
43 \subpage linear_adv_2d_sine_varyingadv \n
44 \subpage linear_diff_sine2d
45 
46 \subpage burgers_2d_sine
47 
48 \subpage vlasov_1d1v_prescribed \n
49 \subpage vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent
50 
51 \subpage euler2d_riemann4 \n
52 \subpage euler2d_riemann6 \n
53 \subpage euler2d_radexp \n
54 \subpage euler2d_vortex
55 
56 \subpage euler2d_igwave \n
57 \subpage euler2d_rtb
58 
59 \subpage navstok2d_ldsc \n
60 \subpage navstok2d_flatplate
61 
62 \subpage sw_circdambreak \n
63 \subpage sw_latbelt
64 
65 \subpage linear_adv_3dgauss
66 
67 \subpage ns3d_isoturb \n
68 \subpage ns3d_bubble
69 
70 \subpage numa3d_bubble
71 
72 \page linear_adv_sine 1D Linear Advection - Sine Wave
73 
74 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave
75  (This directory contains all the input files needed
76  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
77  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
78  example).
79 
80 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
81 
82 References:
83  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
84  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
85  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
86 
87 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
88  boundary conditions
89 
90 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
91 
92 Numerical Method:
93  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
94  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
95 
96 Input files required:
97 ---------------------
98 
99 \b solver.inp
100 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/solver.inp
101 
102 \b boundary.inp
103 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/boundary.inp
104 
105 \b physics.inp
106 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/physics.inp
107 
108 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
109 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/lusolver.inp
110 
111 \b weno.inp (optional)
112 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/weno.inp
113 
114 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
115 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
116 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
117 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
118 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
119 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
120 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
121 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/aux/init.c
122 
123 Output:
124 -------
125 After running the code, there should be 11 output
126 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
127 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
128 is the solution at \f$t=1\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
129 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
130 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
131 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
132 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
133 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
134 
135 Solutions at t=0,0.5,1: The following figure is obtained
136 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (initial), \a op_00005.dat (t=0.5),
137 and \a op_00010.dat (final).
138 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSine.png
139 
140 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
141 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
142 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
143 as well as \b errors.dat:
144 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/errors.dat
145 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
146 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
147 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
148 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
149 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
150 and cleaning up),
151 and total wall time.
152 
153 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
154 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
155 as the file \b conservation.dat:
156 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/conservation.dat
157 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
158 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
159 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
160 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
161 
162 Expected screen output:
163 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave/output.log \page linear_adv_sine_varyingadv 1D Linear Advection - Sine Wave with Spatially-Varying Advection Speed
164 
165 Location: \b Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection
166  (This directory contains all the input files needed
167  to run this case.)
168 
169 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
170 
171 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
172  boundary conditions
173 
174 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
175 
176 Advection speed: \f$a\left(x\right) = 1 + \frac{1}{2}\sin^2\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
177 
178 Numerical Method:
179  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
180  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
181 
182 Input files required:
183 ---------------------
184 
185 \b solver.inp
186 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/solver.inp
187 
188 \b boundary.inp
189 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/boundary.inp
190 
191 \b physics.inp (specifies filename for advection field)
192 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/physics.inp
193 \b Note: Do not include the ".inp" extension in the filename above.
194 
195 \b weno.inp (optional)
196 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/weno.inp
197 
198 To generate \b initial.inp and \b advection.inp, compile and run the
199 following code in the run directory.
200 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/aux/init.c
201 
202 Output:
203 -------
204 After running the code, there should be 101 output
205 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00100.dat;
206 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
207 is the solution at \f$t=2.5\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
208 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
209 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
210 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
211 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
212 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
213 
214 The following animation shows the solution vs. grid point index:
215 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv.gif
216 
217 In addition to the usual output files, the linear advection physics
218 module writes out the following files:
219 + \b advection_00000.dat, ..., \b advection_00100.dat: These files
220  share the same format as the solution output files \b op_*.dat
221  and contains the advection field \f$a\left(x\right)\f$.
222 The following figure shows the advection speed vs. grid point index:
223 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv.png
224 
225 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
226 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
227 as the file \b conservation.dat:
228 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/conservation.dat
229 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
230 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
231 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
232 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
233 
234 Expected screen output:
235 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/output.log \page linear_adv_disc 1D Linear Advection - Discontinuous Waves
236 
237 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves
238  (This directory contains all the input files needed
239  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
240  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
241  example).
242 
243 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
244 
245 References:
246  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
247  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
248  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
249 
250 Domain: \f$-1 \le x \le 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
251  boundary conditions
252 
253 Initial solution:
254  \f{equation}{
255  u\left(x,0\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{lc}
256  \exp\left(-\log\left(2\right)\frac{\left(x+7\right)^2}{0.0009}\right) & -0.8\le x \le -0.6 \\
257  1 & -0.4\le x \le -0.2 \\
258  1 - \left|10\left(x-0.1\right)\right| & 0\le x \le 0.2 \\
259  \sqrt{1-100\left(x-0.5\right)^2} & 0.4\le x \le 0.6 \\
260  0 & {\rm otherwise}
261  \end{array}\right.
262  \f}
263 
264 Numerical Method:
265  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
266  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
267 
268 Input files required:
269 ---------------------
270 
271 \b solver.inp
272 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/solver.inp
273 
274 \b boundary.inp
275 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/boundary.inp
276 
277 \b physics.inp
278 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/physics.inp
279 
280 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
281 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/lusolver.inp
282 
283 \b weno.inp (optional)
284 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/weno.inp
285 
286 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
287 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
288 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
289 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
290 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
291 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
292 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
293 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/aux/init.c
294 
295 Output:
296 -------
297 After running the code, there should be two solution output
298 files \b op_00000.dat and \b op_00001.dat; the first one is
299 the initial solution, and the latter is the final solution.
300 Both these files are ASCII text (#HyPar::op_file_format is
301 set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
302 
303 Final solution at t=2.0: The following figure is obtained
304 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (initial) and \a op_00001.dat
305 (final). In both these files, the first column is grid
306 index, the second column is x-coordinate, and the third
307 column is the solution.
308 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvDisc.png
309 
310 Expected screen output:
311 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves/output.log \page linear_diff_sine 1D Linear Diffusion - Sine Wave
312 
313 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave
314  (This directory contains all the input files needed
315  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
316  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
317  example).
318 
319 Governing equations: 1D Linear Diffusion Equation (linearadr.h)
320 
321 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
322  boundary conditions
323 
324 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
325 
326 Numerical Method:
327  + Spatial discretization (parabolic): 2nd order (Interp2PrimSecondOrder()),
328  conservative (ParabolicFunctionCons1Stage())
329  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
330 
331 Input files required:
332 ---------------------
333 
334 \b solver.inp
335 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/solver.inp
336 
337 \b boundary.inp
338 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/boundary.inp
339 
340 \b physics.inp
341 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/physics.inp
342 
343 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and
344 \b exact.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
345 following code in the run directory.
346 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/aux/exact.c
347 
348 Output:
349 -------
350 After running the code, there should be 11 output
351 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
352 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
353 is the solution at \f$t=10\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
354 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
355 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
356 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
357 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
358 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
359 
360 Solutions at t=0,2,4,6,8,10: The following figure is obtained
361 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (t=0, initial), \a op_00002.dat (t=2),
362 \a op_00004.dat (t=4), \a op_00006.dat (t=6), \a op_00008.dat
363 (t=8) and \a op_00010.dat (t=10, final).
364 @image html Solution_1DLinearDiffSine.png
365 
366 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
367 , the numerical
368 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
369 as well as \b errors.dat:
370 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/errors.dat
371 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
372 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
373 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
374 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
375 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
376 and cleaning up),
377 and total wall time.
378 
379 Expected screen output:
380 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/output.log \page burger_1d_sine 1D Inviscid Burgers Equation - Sine Wave
381 
382 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Burgers/SineWave
383  (This directory contains all the input files needed
384  to run this case.)
385 
386 Governing equations: 1D Burgers Equation (burgers.h)
387 
388 References:
389  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
390  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
391  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
392 
393 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
394  boundary conditions
395 
396 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \frac{1}{2 \pi t_s}\sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$,
397 \f$t_s=2\f$ (time to shock formation)
398 
399 Exact solution:
400  \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = \frac{1}{2 \pi t_s} \sin\left(2\pi \left(x-u t\right)\right)\f$ (needs to be computed iteratively)\n
401 
402 Numerical Method:
403  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
404  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
405 
406 Input files required:
407 ---------------------
408 
409 \b solver.inp
410 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/solver.inp
411 
412 \b boundary.inp
413 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/boundary.inp
414 
415 \b physics.inp
416 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/physics.inp
417 
418 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
419 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/lusolver.inp
420 
421 \b weno.inp (optional)
422 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/weno.inp
423 
424 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution)
425 and \b exact.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
426 following code in the run directory.
427 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/aux/init.c
428 \b Note: The exact solution is available only if the
429 final time is less than \f$t_s\f$ above.
430 
431 Output:
432 -------
433 After running the code, there should be 8 output
434 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00007.dat;
435 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
436 is the solution at \f$t=2\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
437 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
438 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
439 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
440 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
441 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
442 
443 Solutions at t=0,...,2: The following figure is obtained
444 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (initial), ..., \a op_00007.dat (t=2).
445 @image html Solution_1DBurgersSine.png
446 
447 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
448 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
449 as the file \b conservation.dat:
450 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/conservation.dat
451 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
452 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
453 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
454 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
455 
456 Expected screen output:
457 \include 1D/Burgers/SineWave/output.log \page sod_shock_tube 1D Euler Equations - Sod Shock Tube
458 
459 Description:
460 -------------------
461 
462 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube
463  (This directory contains all the input files needed
464  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
465  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
466  example).
467 
468 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
469 
470 References:
471  + G.A. Sod, "A survey of several finite difference methods
472  for systems of nonlinear hyperbolic conservation laws,"
473  J. Comput. Phys., 27, 1 (1978).
474  + C. B. Laney, "Computational Gasdynamics", Cambridge
475  University Press, 1998.
476 
477 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 1.0\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
478  boundary conditions
479 
480 Initial Solution:
481  + \f$ 0 \le x < 0.5\f$: \f$\rho = 1, u = 0, p = 1\f$
482  + \f$ 0.5 \le x \le 1\f$: \f$\rho = 0.125, u = 0, p = 0.1\f$
483 
484 Numerical Method:
485  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
486  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
487 
488 Input files required:
489 --------------------
490 \b solver.inp:
491 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube/solver.inp
492 
493 \b boundary.inp
494 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube/boundary.inp
495 
496 \b physics.inp
497 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube/physics.inp
498 
499 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
500 following code in the run directory:
501 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube/aux/init.c
502 
503 Output:
504 -------
505 After running the code, there should be two solution output
506 files \b op_00000.dat and \b op_00001.dat; the first one is
507 the initial solution, and the latter is the final solution.
508 Both these files are ASCII text (#HyPar::op_file_format is
509 set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
510 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second
511 column is x-coordinate, and the remaining columns are the
512 solution components.
513 
514 Final solution at t=0.2: The following figure is obtained
515 by plotting \a op_00001.dat. Note that the output is in
516 terms of the conserved variables, so they have to converted
517 to the primitive variables (density, velocity, and pressure).
518 @image html Solution_1DSodShockTube.png
519 
520 Expected screen output:
521 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube/output.log \page lax_shock_tube 1D Euler Equations - Lax Shock Tube
522 
523 Description:
524 -------------------
525 
526 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube
527  (This directory contains all the input files needed
528  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
529  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
530  example).
531 
532 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
533 
534 References:
535  + P.D. Lax, "Weak solutions of nonlinear hyperbolic
536  equations and their numerical computation," Comm.
537  Pure App. Math., 7, 159 (1954).
538  + C. B. Laney, "Computational Gasdynamics", Cambridge
539  University Press, 1998.
540 
541 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 1.0\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
542  boundary conditions
543 
544 Initial Solution:
545  + \f$ 0 \le x < 0.5\f$: \f$\rho = 0.445, \rho u = 0.311, e = 8.928\f$
546  + \f$ 0.5 \le x \le 1\f$: \f$\rho = 0.5, \rho u = 0, e = 1.4275\f$
547 
548 Numerical Method:
549  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
550  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
551 
552 Input files required:
553 --------------------
554 \b solver.inp:
555 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/solver.inp
556 
557 \b boundary.inp
558 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/boundary.inp
559 
560 \b physics.inp
561 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/physics.inp
562 
563 \b weno.inp (optional)
564 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/weno.inp
565 
566 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
567 following code in the run directory:
568 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/aux/init.c
569 
570 Output:
571 -------
572 Note that \b iproc = 2 in \b solver.inp, so run this with
573 2 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc to 1). After running the code,
574 there should be two solution output files \b op_00000.dat and
575 \b op_00001.dat; the first one is the initial solution, and the
576 latter is the final solution. Both these files are ASCII text
577 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
578 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second
579 column is x-coordinate, and the remaining columns are the
580 solution components.
581 
582 Final solution at t=0.08: The following figure is obtained
583 by plotting \a op_00001.dat. Note that the output is in
584 terms of the conserved variables, so they have to converted
585 to the primitive variables (density, velocity, and pressure).
586 @image html Solution_1DLaxShockTube.png
587 
588 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
589 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
590 as the file \b conservation.dat:
591 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/conservation.dat
592 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
593 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
594 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
595 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) for
596 each component.
597 
598 Expected screen output:
599 \include 1D/Euler1D/LaxShockTube/output.log
600 
601 
602 \page shu_osher 1D Euler Equations - Shu-Osher Problem
603 
604 Description:
605 ------------
606 
607 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem
608  (This directory contains all the input files needed
609  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
610  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
611  example).
612 
613 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
614 
615 References:
616  + C.-W. Shu and S. Osher, "Efficient implementation of
617  essentially non-oscillatory schemes ,II," J. Comput.
618  Phys., 83 (1989), pp. 32–78
619 
620 Domain: \f$-5 \le x \le 5\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
621  boundary conditions
622 
623 Initial Solution:
624  + \f$ -5 \le x < -4\f$: \f$\rho = 27/7, u = 4\sqrt{35}/7, p = 31/3\f$
625  + \f$ -4 \le x \le 5\f$: \f$\rho = 1 + 0.2\sin\left(5x\right), u = 0, p = 1\f$
626 
627 Numerical Method:
628  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
629  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
630 
631 Input files required:
632 --------------------
633 \b solver.inp:
634 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/solver.inp
635 
636 \b boundary.inp
637 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/boundary.inp
638 
639 \b physics.inp
640 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/physics.inp
641 
642 \b weno.inp (optional)
643 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/weno.inp
644 
645 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
646 following code in the run directory:
647 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/aux/init.c
648 
649 Output:
650 -------
651 After running the code,
652 there should be two solution output files \b op_00000.dat and
653 \b op_00001.dat; the first one is the initial solution, and the
654 latter is the final solution. Both these files are ASCII text
655 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
656 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second
657 column is x-coordinate, and the remaining columns are the
658 solution components.
659 
660 Final solution at t=1.8: The following figure is obtained
661 by plotting \a op_00001.dat. Note that the output is in
662 terms of the conserved variables, so they have to converted
663 to the primitive variables (density, velocity, and pressure).
664 @image html Solution_1DShuOsherProblem.png
665 
666 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
667 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
668 as the file \b conservation.dat:
669 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/conservation.dat
670 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
671 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
672 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
673 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) for
674 each component.
675 
676 Expected screen output:
677 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem/output.log
678 
679 
680 \page sod_shock_tube_wgrav 1D Euler Equations - Sod Shock Tube with Gravitational Force
681 
682 Description:
683 -------------------
684 
685 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/SodShockTubeWithGravity
686  (This directory contains all the input files needed
687  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
688  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
689  example).
690 
691 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
692 
693 References:
694  + Xing, Y., Shu, C.-W., "High Order Well-Balanced WENO Scheme
695  for the Gas Dynamics Equations Under Gravitational Fields",
696  Journal of Scientific Computing, 54, 2013, pp. 645-662.
697 
698 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 1.0\f$, \a "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_)
699  boundary conditions (wall velocity is zero), with
700  \b uniform \b gravitational \b force \f$g=1\f$.
701 
702 Initial Solution:
703  + \f$ 0 \le x < 0.5\f$: \f$\rho = 1, u = 0, p = 1\f$
704  + \f$ 0.5 \le x \le 1\f$: \f$\rho = 0.125, u = 0, p = 0.1\f$
705 
706 Numerical Method:
707  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENOChar())
708  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
709 
710 Input files required:
711 --------------------
712 \b solver.inp:
713 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTubeWithGravity/solver.inp
714 
715 \b boundary.inp
716 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTubeWithGravity/boundary.inp
717 
718 \b physics.inp
719 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTubeWithGravity/physics.inp
720 
721 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
722 following code in the run directory:
723 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTubeWithGravity/aux/init.c
724 
725 Output:
726 -------
727 After running the code, there should be two solution output
728 files \b op_00000.dat and \b op_00001.dat; the first one is
729 the initial solution, and the latter is the final solution.
730 Both these files are ASCII text (#HyPar::op_file_format is
731 set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
732 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second
733 column is x-coordinate, and the remaining columns are the
734 solution components.
735 
736 Final solution at t=0.2: The following figure is obtained
737 by plotting \a op_00001.dat. Note that the output is in
738 terms of the conserved variables, so they have to converted
739 to the primitive variables (density, velocity, and pressure).
740 @image html Solution_1DSodShockTubeWithGravity.png
741 
742 Expected screen output:
743 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTubeWithGravity/output.log \page sw_dambreak 1D Shallow Water Equations - Dam Breaking over Rectangular Bump
744 
745 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump
746  (This directory contains all the input files needed
747  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
748  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
749  example).
750 
751 Governing equations: 1D Shallow Water Equations (shallowwater1d.h)
752 
753 References:
754  + Xing, Y., Shu, C.-W., "High order finite difference WENO
755  schemes with the exact conservation property for the shallow
756  water equations", Journal of Computational Physics, 208, 2005,
757  pp. 206-227 (section 4.4).
758 
759 Domain: \f$ 0 \le x \le 1500\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
760  boundary conditions
761 
762 Initial solution:
763 \f{equation}{
764  h\left(x\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{lc} 20 - b\left(x\right) & x <= 750 \\ 15 - b\left(x\right) & {\rm otherwise}\end{array}\right., u\left(x\right) = 0
765 \f}
766 where \f$b\left(x\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{lc} 8 & \left|x-750.0\right| \le 1500/8 \\ 0 & {\rm otherwise} \end{array}\right.\f$ is the bottom topography.
767 
768 Numerical Method:
769  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
770  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
771 
772 Input files required:
773 ---------------------
774 
775 Note: in addition to the usual input files that HyPar needs, this
776 physical model needs the following input file(s):
777 + \b topography.inp : file containing the bottom topography (same
778  format as \b initial.inp).
779 
780 \b solver.inp
781 \include 1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump/solver.inp
782 
783 \b boundary.inp
784 \include 1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump/boundary.inp
785 
786 \b physics.inp
787 \include 1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump/physics.inp
788 
789 \b weno.inp (optional)
790 \include 1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump/weno.inp
791 
792 To generate \b initial.inp and \b topography.inp, compile and run the
793 following code in the run directory.
794 \include 1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump/aux/init.c
795 
796 Output:
797 -------
798 After running the code, there should be 5 solution output files
799 \b op_00000.dat, ..., \b op_00004.dat; the first one is the solution
800 at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one is the solution at \f$t=60\f$. Since
801 #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files
802 are written for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
803 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
804 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
805 is x-coordinate, and the third and fourth columns are the two
806 solution components.
807 
808 In addition to the usual output files, the shallow water physics
809 module writes out the following files:
810 + \b topography_00000.dat, ..., \b topography_00004.dat: These files
811  share the same format as the solution output files \b op_*.dat
812  and contains the topography \f$b\left(x\right)\f$.
813 
814 
815 Solutions at t=0,15,30,45,60: The following figure is obtained
816 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (initial), \a op_00005.dat (t=0.5),
817 and \a op_00010.dat (final). \b Note: the figure plots
818 \f$h\left(x\right)+b\left(x\right)\f$, i.e., it adds the third
819 column in \b op_*.dat and the third column in \b topography_*.dat.
820 @image html Solution_1DSWDamBreak.png
821 
822 Expected screen output:
823 \include 1D/ShallowWater1D/DamBreakingRectangularBump/output.log \page linear_adv_gauss 2D Linear Advection - Gaussian Pulse
824 
825 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse
826  (This directory contains all the input files needed
827  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
828  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
829  example).
830 
831 Governing equations: 2D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
832 
833 Domain: \f$-6 \le x < 6, -3 \le y < 3\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
834  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
835 
836 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \exp\left[-\left(\frac{x^2}{2}+\frac{y^2}{2}\right)\right]\f$\n
837 Exact solution: \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = u_0\left(x-a_xt,y-a_yt\right)\f$.
838 
839 Numerical Method:
840  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
841  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
842 
843 Input files required:
844 ---------------------
845 
846 \b solver.inp
847 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/solver.inp
848 
849 \b boundary.inp
850 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/boundary.inp
851 
852 \b physics.inp (specifies \f$a_x\f$ and \f$a_y\f$)
853 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/physics.inp
854 
855 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
856 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/lusolver.inp
857 
858 \b weno.inp (optional)
859 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/weno.inp
860 
861 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
862 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
863 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
864 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
865 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
866 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
867 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
868 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/aux/init.c
869 
870 Output:
871 -------
872 Note that \b iproc is set to
873 
874  4 2
875 
876 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 2
877 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
878 with 8 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
879 
880 After running the code, there should be 21 output
881 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00020.dat;
882 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
883 is the solution at \f$t=12\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
884 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
885 for solutions at each output time.
886 
887 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
888 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
889 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
890 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
891 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
892 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
893 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
894 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
895 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
896 MATLAB for example).
897 
898 The following animation was generated from the solution files:
899 @image html Solution_2DLinearAdvGauss.gif
900 
901 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
902 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
903 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
904 as well as \b errors.dat:
905 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/errors.dat
906 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
907 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
908 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
909 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
910 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
911 and cleaning up),
912 and total wall time.
913 
914 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
915 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
916 as the file \b conservation.dat:
917 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/conservation.dat
918 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
919 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
920 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
921 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
922 
923 Expected screen output:
924 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/output.log \page linear_adv_2d_sine_varyingadv 2D Linear Advection - Sine Wave with Spatially-Varying Advection Speed
925 
926 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01
927  (This directory contains all the input files needed
928  to run this case.)
929 
930 Governing equations: 2D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
931 
932 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
933  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
934 
935 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \cos\left(4\pi y\right)\f$\n
936 
937 Advection speed: \f$a_x\left(x,y\right) = \sin\left(4\pi y\right)\f$, \f$a_y\left(x,y\right) = -\cos\left(4\pi x\right)\f$
938 
939 Numerical Method:
940  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
941  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
942 
943 Input files required:
944 ---------------------
945 
946 \b solver.inp \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/boundary.inp \b physics.inp (specifies filename for advection field)
947 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/physics.inp \b Note: Do not include the ".inp" extension in the filename above.
948 
949 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
950 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/lusolver.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
951 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/weno.inp
952 
953 To generate \b initial.inp and \b advection.inp, compile and run the
954 following code in the run directory.
955 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/aux/init.c
956 
957 Output:
958 -------
959 Note that \b iproc is set to
960 
961  4 4
962 
963 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 2
964 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
965 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
966 
967 After running the code, there should be 101 output
968 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00100.dat;
969 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
970 is the solution at \f$t=4\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
971 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
972 for solutions at each output time.
973 
974 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
975 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
976 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
977 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
978 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
979 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
980 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
981 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
982 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
983 MATLAB for example).
984 
985 The following animation was generated from the solution files:
986 @image html Solution_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv.gif
987 
988 In addition to the usual output files, the linear advection physics
989 module writes out the following files:
990 + \b advection_00000.dat, ..., \b advection_00100.dat: These files
991  share the same format as the solution output files \b op_*.dat
992  and contains the advection field \f$a_x\left(x,y\right), a_y\left(x,y\right)\f$.
993 The following figure shows the vector plot of the velocity field:
994 @image html Solution_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv.png
995 
996 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
997 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
998 as the file \b conservation.dat:
999 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/conservation.dat
1000 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1001 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1002 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1003 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
1004 
1005 Expected screen output:
1006 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection/case_01/output.log \page linear_diff_sine2d 2D Linear Diffusion - Sine Wave
1007 
1008 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave
1009  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1010  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1011  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1012  example).
1013 
1014 Governing equations: 2D Linear Diffusion Equation (linearadr.h)
1015 
1016 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
1017  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
1018 
1019 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\sin\left(2\pi y\right)\f$\n
1020 Exact solution: \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = \exp\left[-\pi^2 \left(4\nu_x + 4\nu_y\right) t\right] u0\left(x,y\right)\f$.
1021 
1022 Numerical Method:
1023  + Spatial discretization (parabolic): 2nd order (Interp2PrimSecondOrder()),
1024  conservative (ParabolicFunctionCons1Stage())
1025  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
1026 
1027 Input files required:
1028 ---------------------
1029 
1030 \b solver.inp \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/boundary.inp \b physics.inp (specifies \f$\nu_x\f$ and \f$\nu_y\f$)
1031 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/physics.inp
1032 
1033 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and
1034 \b exact.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
1035 following code in the run directory.
1036 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/aux/exact.c
1037 
1038 Output:
1039 -------
1040 Note that \b iproc is set to
1041 
1042  2 2
1043 
1044 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1045 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1046 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1047 
1048 After running the code, there should be 11 output
1049 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
1050 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1051 is the solution at \f$t=10\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1052 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1053 for solutions at each output time.
1054 
1055 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1056 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1057 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1058 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1059 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1060 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1061 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
1062 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1063 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1064 MATLAB for example).
1065 
1066 The following animation was generated from the solution files:
1067 @image html Solution_2DLinearDiffSine.gif
1068 
1069 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
1070 , the numerical
1071 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
1072 as well as \b errors.dat:
1073 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/errors.dat
1074 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1075 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1076 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1077 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
1078 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
1079 and cleaning up),
1080 and total wall time.
1081 
1082 Expected screen output:
1083 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave/output.log \page burgers_2d_sine 2D Inviscid Burgers Equation - Sine Wave
1084 
1085 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/Burgers/SineWave
1086  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1087  to run this case.)
1088 
1089 Governing equations: 2D Burgers Equation (burgers.h)
1090 
1091 Domain: \f$1 \le x,y < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
1092  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
1093 
1094 Initial solution:
1095  \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = \frac{1}{2 \pi t_s} \sin\left(2\pi x\right) \sin\left(2\pi y\right)\f$,\n
1096  \f$t_s=2\f$ (time to shock formation)
1097 
1098 Exact solution:
1099  \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = \frac{1}{2 \pi t_s} \sin\left(2\pi \left(x-u t\right)\right) \sin\left(2\pi \left(y-u t\right)\right)\f$ (needs to be computed iteratively)\n
1100 
1101 Numerical Method:
1102  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
1103  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
1104 
1105 Input files required:
1106 ---------------------
1107 
1108 \b solver.inp
1109 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/solver.inp
1110 
1111 \b boundary.inp
1112 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/boundary.inp
1113 
1114 \b physics.inp (specifies \f$a_x\f$ and \f$a_y\f$)
1115 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/physics.inp
1116 
1117 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
1118 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/lusolver.inp
1119 
1120 \b weno.inp (optional)
1121 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/weno.inp
1122 
1123 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution)
1124 and \b exact.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
1125 following code in the run directory.
1126 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/aux/init.c
1127 \b Note: The exact solution is available only if the
1128 final time is less than \f$t_s\f$ above.
1129 
1130 Output:
1131 -------
1132 Note that \b iproc is set to
1133 
1134  2 2
1135 
1136 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1137 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1138 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1139 
1140 After running the code, there should be 5 output
1141 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00004.dat;
1142 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1143 is the solution at \f$t=2\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1144 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1145 for solutions at each output time.
1146 
1147 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1148 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1149 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1150 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1151 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1152 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1153 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
1154 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1155 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1156 MATLAB for example).
1157 
1158 The following figures show the solutions at each output time:
1159  + t = 0 (initial)
1160 @image html Solution_2DBurgersSineWave_0.png
1161  + t = 0.4)
1162 @image html Solution_2DBurgersSineWave_1.png
1163  + t = 0.8
1164 @image html Solution_2DBurgersSineWave_2.png
1165  + t = 1.2
1166 @image html Solution_2DBurgersSineWave_3.png
1167  + t = 1.6 (final)
1168 @image html Solution_2DBurgersSineWave_4.png
1169 
1170 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
1171 the errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
1172 as well as \b errors.dat:
1173 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/errors.dat
1174 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1175 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1176 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1177 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
1178 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
1179 and cleaning up),
1180 and total wall time.
1181 
1182 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
1183 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
1184 as the file \b conservation.dat:
1185 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/conservation.dat
1186 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1187 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1188 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1189 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
1190 
1191 Expected screen output:
1192 \include 2D/Burgers/SineWave/output.log \page vlasov_1d1v_prescribed 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation - Prescribed E-Field
1193 
1194 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField
1195  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1196  to run this case.)
1197 
1198 Governing equations: 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation (vlasov.h)
1199 
1200 Domain:
1201  + \f$0 \le x < 2\pi\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
1202  + \f$-6 \le y < 6\f$, \a "dirichlet" (#_DIRICHLET_) (\f$f = 0\f$)
1203 
1204 
1205 Initial solution: \f$f\left(x,v\right) = \left[1 + \frac{1}{10} \cos\left(x\right)\right] \exp\left(- \frac{1}{2}v^2\right)\f$
1206 
1207 Prescribed electric field: \f$\frac{1}{10}\cos\left(x\right)\f$
1208 
1209 Numerical Method:
1210  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order compact upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind())
1211  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
1212 
1213 Input files required:
1214 ---------------------
1215 
1216 \b solver.inp
1217 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField/solver.inp
1218 
1219 \b boundary.inp
1220 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField/boundary.inp
1221 
1222 \b physics.inp
1223 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField/physics.inp
1224 
1225 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile and run the
1226 following code in the run directory.
1227 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField/aux/init.c
1228 
1229 Output:
1230 -------
1231 Note that \b iproc is set to
1232 
1233  4 4
1234 
1235 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
1236 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1237 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1238 
1239 After running the code, there should be 257 output
1240 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00257.dat;
1241 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1242 is the solution at \f$t=128\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1243 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1244 for solutions at each output time.
1245 
1246 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1247 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1248 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1249 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1250 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1251 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1252 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
1253 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1254 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1255 MATLAB for example).
1256 
1257 The following animation shows the evolution of the solution:
1258 @image html Solution_1D1VVlasov_PrescribedE.gif
1259 
1260 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
1261 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
1262 as the file \b conservation.dat:
1263 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField/conservation.dat
1264 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1265 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1266 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1267 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
1268 
1269 Expected screen output:
1270 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/PrescribedElectricField/output.log \page vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation - Two-Stream Instability
1271 
1272 \b Note: this example requires HyPar to be compiled with the FFTW library (https://www.fftw.org/).
1273 While compiling, make sure that the configure step included the <B>\--enable-fftw</B> option
1274 (and if necessary, <B>\--with-fftw-dir=/path/to/fftw</B>).
1275 
1276 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField
1277  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1278  to run this case.)
1279 
1280 Governing equations: 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation (vlasov.h)
1281 
1282 Domain:
1283  + \f$0 \le x < 2\pi\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
1284  + \f$-7 \le y < 7\f$, \a "dirichlet" (#_DIRICHLET_) (\f$f = 0\f$)
1285 
1286 
1287 Initial solution:
1288 \f$f\left(x,v\right) = \frac{4}{\pi T}\left(1+\frac{1}{10}\cos\left(2k\pi\frac{x}{L}\right)\right)\left[\exp\left(-\frac{\left(v-2\right)^2}{2T}\right) + \exp\left(-\frac{\left(v+2\right)^2}{2T}\right)\right]\f$, \f$k=1,T=1,L=2\pi\f$.
1289 
1290 Self-consistent electric field is computed by solving the Poisson equation
1291 in a periodic domain using Fourier transforms. This examples *requires* HyPar
1292 to be compiled with FFTW (http://www.fftw.org/).
1293 
1294 Numerical Method:
1295  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
1296  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
1297 
1298 Input files required:
1299 ---------------------
1300 
1301 \b solver.inp
1302 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField/solver.inp
1303 
1304 \b boundary.inp
1305 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField/boundary.inp
1306 
1307 \b physics.inp
1308 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField/physics.inp
1309 
1310 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile and run the
1311 following code in the run directory.
1312 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField/aux/init.c
1313 
1314 Output:
1315 -------
1316 Note that \b iproc is set to
1317 
1318  4 4
1319 
1320 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
1321 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1322 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1323 
1324 After running the code, there should be 201 output
1325 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00201.dat;
1326 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1327 is the solution at \f$t=40\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1328 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1329 for solutions at each output time.
1330 
1331 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1332 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1333 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1334 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1335 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1336 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1337 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
1338 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1339 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1340 MATLAB for example).
1341 
1342 The following animation shows the evolution of the solution:
1343 @image html Solution_1D1VVlasov_SelfConsistentE.gif
1344 
1345 HyPar will also write out 1D text files named \b efield_00000.dat, ...,
1346 \b efield_00200.dat that contain the electric field at each time
1347 instant the solution was written. In this example, the electric
1348 field is a 1D scalar quantity, and the columns of these files are:
1349 grid index, x-coordinate, electric field value.
1350 The following plot shows the electric field at \f$t=40\f$, obtained
1351 by plotting \b efield_00200.dat:
1352 @image html Solution_E_1D1VVlasov_SelfConsistentE.png
1353 
1354 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
1355 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
1356 as the file \b conservation.dat:
1357 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField/conservation.dat
1358 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1359 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1360 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1361 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
1362 
1363 Expected screen output:
1364 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField/output.log \page euler2d_riemann4 2D Euler Equations - Riemann Problem Case 4
1365 
1366 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4
1367  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1368  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1369  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1370  example).
1371 
1372 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
1373  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
1374  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
1375  equations are solved.)
1376 
1377 Reference:
1378  + P. Lax and X.-D. Liu, "Solution of two-dimensional Riemann
1379  problems of gas dynamics by positive schemes," SIAM J Sci
1380  Comp 19 (1998), 319–340.
1381 
1382 Domain: \f$-0.5 \le x,y \le 0.5\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
1383  boundary conditions.
1384 
1385 Initial solution: see \b Case \b 4 in the reference.
1386 
1387 Numerical method:
1388  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
1389  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
1390 
1391 Input files required:
1392 ---------------------
1393 
1394 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/physics.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
1395 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/weno.inp
1396 
1397 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
1398 following code in the run directory.
1399 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/aux/init.c
1400 
1401 Output:
1402 -------
1403 Note that \b iproc is set to
1404 
1405  2 2
1406 
1407 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1408 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1409 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1410 
1411 After running the code, there should be 11 output
1412 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
1413 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1414 is the solution at \f$t=0.25\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1415 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1416 for solutions at each output time.
1417 
1418 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1419 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1420 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1421 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1422 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1423 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1424 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
1425 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1426 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1427 MATLAB for example).
1428 
1429 The following plot shows the density contours at the final time t=0.25,
1430 obtained from plotting \b op_00010.dat:
1431 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRiemann4.png
1432 
1433 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
1434 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
1435 as the file \b conservation.dat:
1436 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/conservation.dat
1437 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1438 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1439 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1440 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) for each component.
1441 
1442 Expected screen output:
1443 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4/output.log \page euler2d_riemann6 2D Euler Equations - Riemann Problem Case 6
1444 
1445 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase6
1446  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1447  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1448  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1449  example).
1450 
1451 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
1452  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
1453  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
1454  equations are solved.)
1455 
1456 Reference:
1457  + P. Lax and X.-D. Liu, "Solution of two-dimensional Riemann
1458  problems of gas dynamics by positive schemes," SIAM J Sci
1459  Comp 19 (1998), 319–340.
1460 
1461 Domain: \f$-0.5 \le x,y \le 0.5\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
1462  boundary conditions.
1463 
1464 Initial solution: see \b Case \b 6 in the reference.
1465 
1466 Numerical method:
1467  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 3rd order MUSCL (Interp1PrimThirdOrderMUSCLChar())
1468  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
1469 
1470 Input files required:
1471 ---------------------
1472 
1473 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase6/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase6/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase6/physics.inp
1474 
1475 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
1476 following code in the run directory.
1477 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase6/aux/init.c
1478 
1479 Output:
1480 -------
1481 Note that \b iproc is set to
1482 
1483  2 2
1484 
1485 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1486 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1487 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1488 
1489 After running the code, there should be 11 output
1490 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
1491 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1492 is the solution at \f$t=0.3\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1493 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1494 for solutions at each output time.
1495 
1496 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1497 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1498 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1499 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1500 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1501 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1502 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
1503 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1504 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1505 MATLAB for example).
1506 
1507 The following plot shows the density contours at the final time t=0.3,
1508 obtained from plotting \b op_00010.dat:
1509 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRiemann6.png
1510 
1511 Expected screen output:
1512 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase6/output.log \page euler2d_radexp 2D Euler Equations - Radial Expansion Wave
1513 
1514 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave
1515  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1516  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1517  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1518  example).
1519 
1520 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
1521  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
1522  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
1523  equations are solved.)
1524 
1525 Reference: http://www.as.dlr.de/hiocfd/case_c1.5.html
1526 
1527 Domain: \f$-0.4 \le x,y \le 0.4\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
1528  boundary conditions (supersonic outflow).
1529 
1530 Initial solution: see reference above.
1531 
1532 Numerical method:
1533  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 3rd order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
1534  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
1535 
1536 Input files required:
1537 ---------------------
1538 
1539 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave/physics.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
1540 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave/weno.inp
1541 
1542 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
1543 following code in the run directory.
1544 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave/aux/init.c
1545 
1546 Output:
1547 -------
1548 Note that \b iproc is set to
1549 
1550  2 2
1551 
1552 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1553 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1554 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1555 
1556 After running the code, there should be 11 output
1557 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
1558 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1559 is the solution at \f$t=1\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1560 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1561 for solutions at each output time.
1562 
1563 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1564 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1565 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1566 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1567 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1568 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1569 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
1570 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1571 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1572 MATLAB for example).
1573 
1574 The following plot shows the density contours at the final time t=1,
1575 obtained from plotting \b op_00010.dat:
1576 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRadialExpansion.png
1577 
1578 Expected screen output:
1579 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RadialExpansionWave/output.log \page euler2d_vortex 2D Euler Equations - Isentropic Vortex Convection
1580 
1581 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection
1582  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1583  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1584  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1585  example).
1586 
1587 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
1588  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
1589  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
1590  equations are solved.)
1591 
1592 Reference: C.-W. Shu, "Essentially Non-oscillatory and Weighted Essentially
1593  Non-oscillatory Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
1594  ICASE Report 97-65, 1997
1595 
1596 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
1597  boundary conditions.
1598 
1599 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
1600 \f{equation}{
1601  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.1,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
1602 \f}
1603 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
1604 \f{align}{
1605 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
1606 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
1607 \f}
1608 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
1609 
1610 Numerical method:
1611  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
1612  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
1613 
1614 Input files required:
1615 ---------------------
1616 
1617 \b solver.inp
1618 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/solver.inp
1619 
1620 \b boundary.inp
1621 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/boundary.inp
1622 
1623 \b physics.inp
1624 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/physics.inp
1625 
1626 \b weno.inp (optional)
1627 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/weno.inp
1628 
1629 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
1630 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/lusolver.inp
1631 
1632 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp
1633 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
1634 directory.
1635 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/aux/exact.c
1636 
1637 Output:
1638 -------
1639 Note that \b iproc is set to
1640 
1641  2 2
1642 
1643 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1644 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1645 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1646 
1647 After running the code, there should be 11 output
1648 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
1649 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
1650 is the solution at \f$t=20\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1651 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1652 for solutions at each output time.
1653 
1654 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
1655 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
1656 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
1657 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
1658 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
1659 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
1660 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
1661 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
1662 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
1663 MATLAB for example).
1664 
1665 The following animation shows the density contours as the vortex
1666 convects over the domain:,
1667 @image html Solution_2DNavStokVortex.gif
1668 
1669 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
1670 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
1671 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
1672 as well as \b errors.dat:
1673 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/errors.dat
1674 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1675 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1676 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1677 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
1678 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
1679 and cleaning up),
1680 and total wall time.
1681 
1682 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
1683 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
1684 as the file \b conservation.dat:
1685 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/conservation.dat
1686 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
1687 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
1688 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
1689 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) of each component.
1690 
1691 Expected screen output:
1692 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection/output.log \page euler2d_igwave 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Inertia-Gravity Waves
1693 
1694 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave
1695  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1696  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1697  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1698  example).
1699 
1700 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
1701  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
1702  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
1703  equations are solved.)
1704 
1705 Reference:
1706  + W. C. Skamarock and J. B. Klemp, "Efficiency and accuracy of
1707  the Klemp-Wilhelmson timesplitting technique", Monthly Weather
1708  Review, 122 (1994), pp. 2623–2630.
1709  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
1710  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
1711  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
1712  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
1713  (Section 3.1).
1714 
1715 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 300,000\,m, 0 \le y \le 10,000\,m\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
1716  boundary conditions along \f$x\f$, "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions along \f$y\f$.
1717 
1718 Initial solution: See references above.
1719 
1720 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
1721  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
1722  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
1723  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
1724  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
1725  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
1726  + Hydrostatic balance type 3 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
1727  + Brunt-Vaisala frequency 0.01 (#NavierStokes2D::N_bv)
1728 
1729 Numerical method:
1730  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
1731  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
1732 
1733 Input files required:
1734 ---------------------
1735 
1736 \b solver.inp
1737 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/solver.inp
1738 
1739 \b boundary.inp
1740 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/boundary.inp
1741 
1742 \b physics.inp
1743 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/physics.inp
1744 
1745 \b weno.inp (optional)
1746 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/weno.inp
1747 \b Note: \a no_limiting is set to 1, i.e., since this is a
1748 smooth problem, WENO limiting is turned off, and the spatial
1749 discretization uses a 5th order polynomial.
1750 
1751 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
1752 and run the following code in the run directory.
1753 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/aux/init.c
1754 
1755 Output:
1756 -------
1757 Note that \b iproc is set to
1758 
1759  12 1
1760 
1761 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 12 processors along \a x, and 1
1762 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1763 with 12 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1764 
1765 After running the code, there should be 26 output
1766 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00025.bin;
1767 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0s\f$ and the final one
1768 is the solution at \f$t=3000s\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1769 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1770 for solutions at each output time.
1771 
1772 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
1773 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
1774 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
1775 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
1776 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
1777 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
1778 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
1779 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
1780 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
1781 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
1782 a tecplot2d or text file.
1783 (compile and run it in the run directory):
1784 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/aux/PostProcess.c
1785 
1786 The following plot shows the potential temperature perturbation
1787 contours at the final time t=3000. It was plotted using VisIt
1788 (https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/) with
1789 tecplot2d format chosen in the above postprocessing code.
1790 @image html Solution_2DNavStokIGWave.png
1791 
1792 If the postprocessing code above was used to write out files in
1793 text format, the following MATLAB script can be used to generate
1794 plots and visualize the solution:
1795 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/PlotSolution.m
1796 
1797 Expected screen output:
1798 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave/output.log \page euler2d_rtb 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Rising Thermal Bubble
1799 
1800 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble
1801  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1802  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1803  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1804  example).
1805 
1806 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
1807  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
1808  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
1809  equations are solved.)
1810 
1811 Reference:
1812  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
1813  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
1814  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
1815  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
1816  (Section 3.2).
1817 
1818 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 1000\,m\f$,
1819  "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions on all sides.
1820 
1821 Initial solution: See references above.
1822 
1823 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
1824  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
1825  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
1826  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
1827  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
1828  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
1829  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
1830 
1831 Numerical method:
1832  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
1833  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
