1834 
1835 Input files required:
1836 ---------------------
1837 
1838 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/physics.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
1839 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/weno.inp
1840 
1841 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
1842 and run the following code in the run directory.
1843 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/aux/init.c
1844 
1845 Output:
1846 -------
1847 Note that \b iproc is set to
1848 
1849  4 3
1850 
1851 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 3
1852 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1853 with 12 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1854 
1855 After running the code, there should be 41 output
1856 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00040.bin;
1857 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0s\f$ and the final one
1858 is the solution at \f$t=700s\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
1859 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
1860 for solutions at each output time.
1861 
1862 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
1863 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
1864 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
1865 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
1866 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
1867 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
1868 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
1869 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
1870 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
1871 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
1872 a tecplot2d or text file.
1873 (compile and run it in the run directory):
1874 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/aux/PostProcess.c
1875 
1876 The following plot shows the potential temperature perturbation
1877 contours at the final time t=700s. It was plotted using VisIt
1878 (https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/) with
1879 tecplot2d format chosen in the above postprocessing code.
1880 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRTB.png
1881 
1882 The following animation was created using all the transient files:
1883 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRTB.gif
1884 
1885 If the postprocessing code above was used to write out files in
1886 text format, the following MATLAB script can be used to generate
1887 plots and visualize the solution:
1888 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/PlotSolution.m
1889 
1890 Expected screen output:
1891 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble/output.log \page navstok2d_ldsc 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Lid-Driven Square Cavity
1892 
1893 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity
1894  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1895  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1896  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1897  example).
1898 
1899 Governing equations: 2D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
1900 
1901 Reference:
1902 + Erturk, E., Corke, T.C., and Gokcol, C., "Numerical Solutions of
1903  2-D Steady Incompressible Driven Cavity Flow at High Reynolds Numbers",
1904  International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids, 48, 2005,
1905  http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/fld.953.
1906 + Ghia, U., Ghia, K.N., Shin, C.T., "High-Re Solutions for Incompressible
1907  Flow using the Navier-Stokes Equations and a Multigrid Method", Journal
1908  of Computational Physics, 48, 1982, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0021-9991(82)90058-4.
1909 
1910 Note that this is an incompressible problem being solved here using the compressible
1911 Navier-Stokes equations in terms of non-dimensional flow variables. The density and
1912 pressure are taken such that the speed of sound is 1.0, and the flow velocities
1913 specified in the initial and boundary conditions correspond to a characteristic
1914 Mach number of 0.1 (thus, they are 0.1 times the values in the above reference).
1915 
1916 Domain: \f$0 \le x, y \le 1\f$
1917 
1918 Boundary conditions:
1919 + No-slip wall BC on \f$x=0,1, 0 \le y \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
1920 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
1921 + Moving no-slip wall BC on \f$y=1, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with specified
1922  wall velocity of 0.1 in the x-direction).
1923 
1924 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, p=1/\gamma\f$. The velocities are specified according to
1925 the references above, but scaled by a factor of 0.1 to ensure that the characteristic
1926 Mach number is 0.1.
1927 
1928 Other parameters:
1929  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
1930  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100, 1000, 3200\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
1931  where \f$L=1\f$ is the cavity length and width.
1932  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
1933  + \f$M_\infty = 0.1\f$ (characteristic Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
1934 
1935 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
1936 speed of sound is 1.
1937 
1938 Numerical method:
1939  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
1940  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
1941  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
1942  + Time integration: 4th order, 4-stage Runge-Kutta (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
1943 
1944 Input files required:
1945 ---------------------
1946 
1947 \b solver.inp
1948 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity/solver.inp
1949 
1950 \b boundary.inp
1951 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity/boundary.inp
1952 
1953 \b physics.inp (\b Note: this file specifies \f$Re = 3200\f$,
1954 change \a Re here for other Reynolds numbers.)
1955 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity/physics.inp
1956 
1957 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
1958 and run the following code in the run directory.
1959 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity/aux/init.c
1960 
1961 Output:
1962 -------
1963 Note that \b iproc is set to
1964 
1965  2 2
1966 
1967 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
1968 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
1969 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
1970 
1971 After running the code, there should be one output file
1972 \b op.dat, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
1973 Since #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp,
1974 this file is in the ASCII Tecplot format and can be viewed in any
1975 software that supports this format (e.g. VisIt).
1976 
1977 Following plots show the streamlines (colored by the velocity magnitude)
1978 for the solutions with Reynolds number 100, 1000, and 3200, respectively.
1979 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re0100.png
1980 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re1000.png
1981 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re3200.png
1982 
1983 Expected screen output (for Reynolds number 3200):
1984 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity/output.log
1985 
1986 
1987 \page navstok2d_flatplate 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Laminar Flow over Flat Plate
1988 
1989 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid
1990  (This directory contains all the input files needed
1991  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
1992  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
1993  example).
1994 
1995 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
1996 
1997 Reference:
1998 + Hirsch, "Numerical Computation of Internal & External Flows",
1999  Volume 1 (Fundamentals of Computational Fluid Dynamics), 2nd
2000  Edition, Elsevier, Section 12.3.2 (page 618-625).
2001 
2002 Domain: \f$-0.25 \le x \le 1\f$, \f$0 \le y \le 0.25\f$
2003 
2004 Boundary conditions:
2005 + Symmetry BC on \f$y=0, -0.25 \le x < 0\f$ (imposed through "slip-wall"
2006  #_SLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
2007 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0
2008  wall velocity).
2009 + Subsonic outflow on \f$y=0.25\f$ (#_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_) with pressure
2010  \f$p=1/\gamma\f$.
2011 + Subsonic inflow on \f$x=0\f$ (#_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_) with density \f$\rho=1\f$,
2012  and velocity \f$(u,v) = (0.3,0)\f$.
2013 + Subsonic outflow on \f$x=1\f$ (#_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_) with pressure
2014  \f$p=1/\gamma\f$.
2015 
2016 Initial solution: Uniform flow with \f$\rho=1, u=0.3, v=0, p=1/\gamma\f$.
2017 
2018 Other parameters:
2019  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
2020  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100,000\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
2021  where \f$L=1\f$ is the plate length .
2022  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
2023  + \f$M_\infty = 0.3\f$ (freestream Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
2024 
2025 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
2026 speed of sound is 1.
2027 
2028 Numerical method:
2029  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
2030  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
2031  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
2032  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
2033 
2034 This is a steady state problem - the solution converges to a steady laminar flow over a
2035 flat plate, and the residuals decrease with time. The skin friction coefficient is given by
2036 \f{equation}{
2037  c_f = \frac {0.664} {\sqrt{Re_x}}, Re_x = \frac {\rho u x} {\mu}
2038 \f}
2039 (Blasius solution).
2040 
2041 Input files required:
2042 ---------------------
2043 
2044 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/physics.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
2045 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/weno.inp
2046 
2047 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
2048 and run the following code in the run directory.
2049 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/aux/init.c
2050 
2051 Output:
2052 -------
2053 Note that \b iproc is set to
2054 
2055  2 4
2056 
2057 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 4
2058 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
2059 with 8 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2060 
2061 After running the code, there should be one output file
2062 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
2063 
2064 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
2065 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
2066 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
2067 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
2068 are available to convert the binary output file:
2069 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
2070  Tecplot file (works only for 2D and 3D).
2071 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
2072  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
2073 
2074 The following plot was obtained by converting the binary file to the
2075 Tecplot format, and using VisIt to plot it (it shows the density
2076 and velocity):
2077 @image html Solution_2DNavStokFlatPlate.png
2078 The following plot shows a magnified view of the boundary layer:
2079 @image html Solution_2DNavStokFlatPlateMagnified.png
2080 
2081 The following file computes the skin friction as a function of the
2082 Reynolds number and writes to to a text file \b SkinFriction.dat with 4
2083 columns: Reynolds number, computed skin friction coefficient, exact skin
2084 friction coefficient (\f$0.664/\sqrt{Re_x}\f$), and normal velocity gradient
2085 on the plate surface (\f$\left.\partial u/\partial y\right|_{y=0}\f$).
2086 Compile and run it in the run directory.
2087 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/aux/SkinFriction.c
2088 The following figure showing the exact and computed skin friction coefficients
2089 was obtained by plotting \b SkinFriction.dat:
2090 @image html Solution_2DNavStokFlatPlateSkinFriction.png
2091 
2092 Expected screen output:
2093 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar/UniformGrid/output.log \page sw_circdambreak 2D Shallow Water Equations - Circular Dam Break
2094 
2095 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak
2096  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2097  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2098  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2099  example).
2100 
2101 Governing equations: 2D Shallow Water Equations (shallowwater2d.h)
2102 
2103 References:
2104  + Delis, Katsaounis, "Numerical solution of the two-dimensional
2105  shallow water equations by the application of relaxation methods",
2106  Applied Mathematical Modelling, 29 (2005), pp. 754-783 (Section 6.3).
2107 
2108 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 50 \f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_) boundary
2109  conditions everywhere
2110 
2111 Initial solution:
2112 \f{equation}{
2113  h\left(x,y\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}10 & r \le 11.0\\1 & {\rm otherwise}\end{array}\right., u\left(x,y\right) = 0.
2114 \f}
2115 with the bottom topography as \f$b\left(x,y\right) = 0\f$, and
2116 \f$r^2=\left(x-25\right)^2+\left(y-25\right)^2\f$.
2117 
2118 Other parameters:
2119  + \f$g=9.8\f$ (#ShallowWater2D::g)
2120 
2121 Numerical Method:
2122  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
2123  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
2124 
2125 Input files required:
2126 ---------------------
2127 
2128 Note: in addition to the usual input files that HyPar needs, this
2129 physical model needs the following input file(s):
2130 + \b topography.inp : file containing the bottom topography (same
2131  format as \b initial.inp).
2132 
2133 However, this case has a constant (zero) bottom topography, and thus
2134 this file can be skipped.
2135 
2136 \b solver.inp
2137 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/solver.inp
2138 
2139 \b boundary.inp
2140 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/boundary.inp
2141 
2142 \b physics.inp
2143 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/physics.inp
2144 
2145 \b weno.inp (optional)
2146 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/weno.inp
2147 
2148 To generate \b initial.inp and \b topography.inp, compile and run the
2149 following code in the run directory (note: topography.inp can be skipped
2150 since this case involves a uniform topography).
2151 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/aux/init.c
2152 
2153 Output:
2154 -------
2155 Note that \b iproc is set to
2156 
2157  2 2
2158 
2159 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
2160 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
2161 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2162 
2163 After running the code, there should be 6 solution output files
2164 \b op_00000.dat, ..., \b op_00005.dat; the first one is the solution
2165 at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one is the solution at \f$t=0.69\f$. Since
2166 #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files
2167 are written for solutions at each output time.
2168 
2169 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp, and
2170 thus, all the files are in plain text (ASCII) format. In these files,
2171 the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices, the
2172 next two columns are the x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns
2173 are the three solution components.
2174 #HyPar::op_file_format can also be set to \a tecplot2d to get the solution
2175 files in the Tecplot format (that can be read using any visualization
2176 software that supports Tecplot format).
2177 
2178 In addition to the usual output files, the shallow water physics
2179 module writes out the following files:
2180 + \b topography_00000.dat, ..., \b topography_00005.dat: These files
2181  share the same format as the solution output files \b op_*.dat
2182  and contains the topography \f$b\left(x\right)\f$ (for this example,
2183  they do not matter since the topography is flat).
2184 
2185 The following plot shows the final solution (water height):
2186 @image html Solution_2DShallowWater_CircDamBreak.png
2187 It was obtained by using the following MATLAB code to plot \b op_00005.dat:
2188 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/PlotSolution.m
2189 
2190 Expected screen output:
2191 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/CircularDamBreak/output.log
2192 
2193 
2194 \page sw_latbelt 2D Shallow Water Equations - Latitude Belt Flow
2195 
2196 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow
2197  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2198  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2199  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2200  example).
2201 
2202 Governing equations: 2D Shallow Water Equations (shallowwater2d.h)
2203 
2204 References:
2205  + Zhu, Et. al., "Variational Data Assimilation with a Variable Resolution
2206  Finite-Element Shallow-Water Equations Model", Monthly Weather Review,
2207  122, 1994, pp. 946--965.\n
2208  Govering equations and approximation of Coriolis forces: Eqns (2.1)-(2.4)\n
2209  Problem definition: Eqns. (4.1)-(4.3)
2210 
2211 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 6,000,000\,{\rm m}, 0\le y \le 4,400,000\,{\rm m}\f$,
2212  \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_) boundaries along \a x,
2213  \a "slip wall" (#_SW_SLIP_WALL_) boundaries along \a y.
2214 
2215 Initial solution: See equations (4.1) and (4.2) in reference,
2216  constant (zero) bottom topography
2217 
2218 Other parameters:
2219  + \f$g=10\f$ (#ShallowWater2D::g)
2220  + \f$\hat{f}=0.0001\f$ (#ShallowWater2D::fhat)
2221  + \f$\beta = 1.5\times 10^{-11}\f$ (#ShallowWater2D::beta)
2222  + \f$D=4400000\f$ (#ShallowWater2D::D)
2223 
2224 Numerical Method:
2225  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
2226  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
2227 
2228 Input files required:
2229 ---------------------
2230 
2231 Note: in addition to the usual input files that HyPar needs, this
2232 physical model needs the following input file(s):
2233 + \b topography.inp : file containing the bottom topography (same
2234  format as \b initial.inp).
2235 
2236 However, this case has a constant (zero) bottom topography, and thus
2237 this file can be skipped.
2238 
2239 \b solver.inp
2240 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/solver.inp
2241 
2242 \b boundary.inp
2243 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/boundary.inp
2244 
2245 \b physics.inp
2246 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/physics.inp
2247 
2248 \b weno.inp (optional)
2249 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/weno.inp
2250 
2251 To generate \b initial.inp and \b topography.inp, compile and run the
2252 following code in the run directory (note: topography.inp can be skipped
2253 since this case involves a uniform topography).
2254 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/aux/init.c
2255 
2256 Output:
2257 -------
2258 Note that \b iproc is set to
2259 
2260  2 2
2261 
2262 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
2263 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
2264 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2265 
2266 After running the code, there should be 101 solution output files
2267 \b op_00000.dat, ..., \b op_00100.dat; the first one is the solution
2268 at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one is the solution at \f$t=360000\f$. Since
2269 #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files
2270 are written for solutions at each output time.
2271 
2272 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp, and
2273 thus, all the files are in plain text (ASCII) format. In these files,
2274 the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices, the
2275 next two columns are the x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns
2276 are the three solution components.
2277 #HyPar::op_file_format can also be set to \a tecplot2d to get the solution
2278 files in the Tecplot format (that can be read using any visualization
2279 software that supports Tecplot format).
2280 
2281 The following plot shows an animation of the solution:
2282 @image html Solution_2DShallowWater_LatitudeBelt.gif
2283 It was obtained by using the following MATLAB code:
2284 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/PlotSolution.m
2285 
2286 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
2287 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
2288 as the file \b conservation.dat:
2289 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/conservation.dat
2290 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
2291 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
2292 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
2293 and conservation error of each component(#HyPar::ConservationError).
2294 Note that that conservation error for the water height is zero to machine
2295 precision (the non-zero conservation "error" for the momentum components
2296 is due to the non-zero source term - Coriolis force).
2297 
2298 Expected screen output:
2299 \include 2D/ShallowWater2D/LatitudeBeltFlow/output.log \page linear_adv_3dgauss 3D Linear Advection - Gaussian Pulse
2300 
2301 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse
2302  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2303  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2304  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2305  example).
2306 
2307 Governing equations: 3D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
2308 
2309 Domain: \f$-3 \le x,y,z < 3\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
2310  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
2311 
2312 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \exp\left[-\left(\frac{x^2}{2}+\frac{y^2}{2}+\frac{z^2}{2}\right)\right]\f$\n
2313 Exact solution: \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = u_0\left(x-a_xt,y-a_yt,z-a_zt\right)\f$.
2314 
2315 Numerical Method:
2316  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
2317  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
2318 
2319 Input files required:
2320 ---------------------
2321 
2322 \b solver.inp
2323 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/solver.inp
2324 
2325 \b boundary.inp
2326 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/boundary.inp
2327 
2328 \b physics.inp (specifies \f$a_x\f$, \f$a_y\f$, and \f$a_z\f$)
2329 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/physics.inp
2330 
2331 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
2332 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/lusolver.inp
2333 
2334 \b weno.inp (optional)
2335 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/weno.inp
2336 
2337 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
2338 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
2339 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
2340 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
2341 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
2342 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
2343 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
2344 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/aux/init.c
2345 
2346 Output:
2347 -------
2348 Note that \b iproc is set to
2349 
2350  2 2 2
2351 
2352 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, \a y, and \a z).
2353 Thus, this example should be run with 8 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2354 
2355 After running the code, there should be 11 output
2356 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
2357 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
2358 is the solution at \f$t=6\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
2359 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
2360 for solutions at each output time.
2361 
2362 All the files are binary (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
2363 The code \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c can be used to convert the binary
2364 solution files to 3D Tecplot files that can be visualized in any software
2365 supporting the Tecplot format. Similarly, the code \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c
2366 can be used to convert the binary solution files to ASCII text files with the
2367 following data layout: the first three columns are grid indices, the next three
2368 columns are x, y, and z coordinates, and the last column is the solution \a u.
2369 
2370 The following animation was generated from the solution files
2371 (after converting to Tecplot format and plotting the iso-surface
2372 in VisIt):
2373 @image html Solution_3DLinearAdvGauss.gif
2374 
2375 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
2376 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
2377 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
2378 as well as \b errors.dat:
2379 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/errors.dat
2380 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
2381 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
2382 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
2383 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
2384 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
2385 and cleaning up),
2386 and total wall time.
2387 
2388 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
2389 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
2390 as the file \b conservation.dat:
2391 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/conservation.dat
2392 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
2393 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
2394 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
2395 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
2396 
2397 Expected screen output:
2398 \include 3D/LinearAdvection/GaussianPulse/output.log
2399 
2400 
2401 \page ns3d_isoturb 3D Navier-Stokes Equations - Isotropic Turbulence Decay
2402 
2403 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay
2404  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2405  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2406  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2407  example).
2408 
2409 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
2410 
2411 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y,z < 2\pi\f$, "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_) boundaries
2412  everywhere.
2413 
2414 Initial solution: Isotropic turbulent flow - The initial solution is
2415 specified in the Fourier space (with an energy
2416 distribution similar to that of turbulent flow), and then transformed
2417 to the physical space through an inverse transform.
2418 
2419 Other parameters:
2420  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
2421  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 333.33\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re)
2422  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
2423  + \f$M_\infty = 0.3\f$ (turbulence fluctuation Mach number) (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
2424 
2425 Numerical Method:
2426  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
2427  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
2428  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
2429  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
2430 
2431 Input files required:
2432 ---------------------
2433 
2434 \b solver.inp
2435 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/solver.inp
2436 
2437 \b boundary.inp
2438 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/boundary.inp
2439 
2440 \b physics.inp
2441 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/physics.inp
2442 
2443 \b weno.inp (optional)
2444 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/weno.inp
2445 
2446 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
2447 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/lusolver.inp
2448 
2449 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
2450 and run the following code in the run directory.
2451 \b Note: this code requires the \b FFTW library installed (http://www.fftw.org/).
2452 To compile:
2453 
2454  gcc -I/path/to/fftw3.h -L/path/to/libfftw3.a -lfftw3 init.c
2455 
2456 (see the FFTW website on ways to install it).
2457 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/aux/init.c
2458 
2459 Output:
2460 -------
2461 Note that \b iproc is set to
2462 
2463  2 2 1
2464 
2465 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, 2
2466 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
2467 this example should be run with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2468 
2469 After running the code, there should be 11 output
2470 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
2471 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
2472 is the solution at \f$t=5\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
2473 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
2474 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
2475 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
2476 
2477 To generate compute the energy spectrum from a given solution, compile
2478 and run the following code in the run directory. This code wants to read
2479 a file called \b op.bin, so make a symbolic link with that name pointing
2480 to the solution file whose energy spectrum is to be computed. (If #HyPar::op_overwrite
2481 is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp, then the solution file itself is called
2482 \b op.bin). Also note that the solution must be in binary format
2483 (#HyPar::op_file_format must be \a binary in \b solver.inp). It will write out a
2484 ASCII text file \b spectrum.dat with two columns: \f$k\f$ and \f$E\left(k\right)\f$.
2485 \b Note: this code requires the \b FFTW library installed (http://www.fftw.org/).
2486 To compile:
2487 
2488  gcc -I/path/to/fftw3.h -L/path/to/libfftw3.a -lfftw3 fourier.c
2489 
2490 (see the FFTW website on ways to install it).
2491 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/aux/fourier.c
2492 
2493 The following figure shows the initial and final (t=5) energy spectra:
2494 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_IsoTurb_Spectrum.png
2495 
2496 The following file computes the kinetic energy as a function of time
2497 from the solution files. It writes out an ASCII text file \b energy.dat
2498 with two colums: time and kinetic energy.
2499 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/aux/kineticenergy.c
2500 
2501 The following figure shows the kinetic energy decay:
2502 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_IsoTurb_Energy.png
2503 
2504 The code \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c can be used to convert the binary
2505 solution files to 3D Tecplot files that can be visualized in any software
2506 supporting the Tecplot format. Similarly, the code \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c
2507 can be used to convert the binary solution files to ASCII text files with the
2508 following data layout: the first three columns are grid indices, the next three
2509 columns are x, y, and z coordinates, and the remaining columns are the solution
2510 components (\f$\rho, \rho u, \rho v, \rho w, e\f$).
2511 
2512 The following figure shows the density iso-surface colored by the internal energy
2513 (plotted in ParaView after converting the binary solution to a Tecplot file):
2514 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_IsoTurb.png
2515 
2516 Expected screen output:
2517 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/DNS_IsotropicTurbulenceDecay/output.log
2518 
2519 
2520 
2521 \page ns3d_bubble 3D Navier-Stokes Equations - Rising Thermal Bubble
2522 
2523 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1
2524  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2525  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2526  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2527  example).
2528 
2529 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
2530 
2531 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y,z < 1000\,{\rm m}\f$, \a "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundaries
2532  everywhere, with zero wall velocity.
2533 
2534 Reference:
2535  + Kelly, J. F., Giraldo, F. X., "Continuous and discontinuous Galerkin methods for a scalable
2536  three-dimensional nonhydrostatic atmospheric model: Limited-area mode", J. Comput. Phys., 231,
2537  2012, pp. 7988-8008 (see section 5.1.2).
2538  + Giraldo, F. X., Kelly, J. F., Constantinescu, E. M., "Implicit-Explicit Formulations of a
2539  Three-Dimensional Nonhydrostatic Unified Model of the Atmosphere (NUMA)", SIAM J. Sci. Comput.,
2540  35 (5), 2013, pp. B1162-B1194 (see section 4.1).
2541 
2542 Initial solution: A warm bubble in cool ambient atmosphere. Note that in this example, the
2543 gravitational forces and rising of the bubble is along the \a y-axis.
2544 
2545 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
2546  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
2547  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::R)
2548  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes3D::grav_y)
2549  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::rho0)
2550  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::p0)
2551  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes3D::HB)
2552 
2553 Numerical Method:
2554  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
2555  + Time integration: SSP RK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
2556 
2557 Input files required:
2558 ---------------------
2559 
2560 \b solver.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/physics.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
2561 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/weno.inp
2562 
2563 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
2564 and run the following code in the run directory.
2565 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/aux/init.c
2566 
2567 Output:
2568 -------
2569 Note that \b iproc is set to
2570 
2571  4 4 4
2572 
2573 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, 4
2574 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
2575 this example should be run with 64 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2576 
2577 After running the code, there should be 11 output
2578 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
2579 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
2580 is the solution at \f$t=200\,{\rm s}\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
2581 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
2582 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
2583 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
2584 
2585 The following code (<B>Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/aux/PostProcess.c</B>)
2586 can be used to convert the binary solution file (with conserved variables
2587 \f$\rho,\rho u,\rho v,\rho w,e\f$) to Tecplot or plain text files with the primitive
2588 and reference variables \f$\rho,u,v,w,P,\theta,\rho_0,P_0,\pi,\theta_0\f$ where the
2589 subscript \f$0\f$ indicates the hydrostatic mean value.
2590 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/aux/PostProcess.c
2591 
2592 The following figure shows the potential temperature iso-surface for the initial
2593 and final solutions (plotted in VisIt):
2594 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_Bubble3D.png
2595 
2596 The file \b Extras/ExtractSlice.c can be used to extract a slice perpendicular to any dimension
2597 at a specified location along that dimension. The extract slice is written out in the same
2598 binary format as the original solutions files (with the same names op_xxxxx.bin) in a
2599 subdirectory called \b slices (\b Note: make the subdirectory called \a slices before running
2600 this code). The following code (<B>Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/aux/PostProcessSlice.c</B>)
2601 can then be used (in the \b slices subdirectory) to convert the binary slice solution file (with conserved variables
2602 \f$\rho,\rho u,\rho v,\rho w,e\f$) to Tecplot or plain text files with the primitive
2603 and reference variables \f$\rho,u,v,w,P,\theta,\rho_0,P_0,\pi,\theta_0\f$.
2604 \b Note that it needs the relevant \b solver.inp and \b physics.inp that can be created
2605 as follows:
2606 + Copy the original solver.inp and physics.inp to the slices subdirectory.
2607 + In solver.inp, set \b ndims as \b 2, and remove the component of \b size and \b iproc
2608  corresponding to the dimension being eliminated while extracting the slices (in this case,
2609  it is \a z or the 3rd component).
2610 + In physics.inp, remove the component of \b gravity corresponding to the dimension perpendicular
2611  to the slice.
2612 
2613 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/aux/PostProcessSlice.c
2614 
2615 The following figure shows the potential temperature \f$\theta\f$ along a slice at \f$z=500\,{\rm m}\f$
2616 (plotted in VisIt):
2617 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_Bubble.gif
2618 
2619 Expected screen output:
2620 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_Config1/output.log \page numa3d_bubble 3D NUMA (Nonhydrostatic Unified Model of the Atmosphere) Equations - Rising Thermal Bubble
2621 
2622 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble
2623  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2624  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2625  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2626  example).
2627 
2628 Governing equations: 3D NUMA (Nonhydrostatic Unified Model of the Atmosphere) Equations (numa3d.h)
2629 
2630 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y,z < 1000\,{\rm m}\f$, \a "numa-nfbc" (#_NO_FLUX_BC_) boundaries
2631  everywhere.
2632 
2633 Reference:
2634  + Kelly, J. F., Giraldo, F. X., "Continuous and discontinuous Galerkin methods for a scalable
2635  three-dimensional nonhydrostatic atmospheric model: Limited-area mode", J. Comput. Phys., 231,
2636  2012, pp. 7988-8008 (see section 5.1.2).
2637  + Giraldo, F. X., Kelly, J. F., Constantinescu, E. M., "Implicit-Explicit Formulations of a
2638  Three-Dimensional Nonhydrostatic Unified Model of the Atmosphere (NUMA)", SIAM J. Sci. Comput.,
2639  35 (5), 2013, pp. B1162-B1194 (see section 4.1).
2640 
2641 Initial solution: A warm bubble in cool ambient atmosphere.
2642 
2643 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
2644  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#Numa3D::gamma)
2645  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#Numa3D::R)
2646  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ (#Numa3D::g)
2647  + Angular speed of earth \f$\Omega = 0\f$ (#Numa3D::Omega)
2648  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#Numa3D::Pref)
2649  + Reference temperature (at zero altitude) \f$T_{ref} = 300\f$ (#Numa3D::Tref)
2650 
2651 Numerical Method:
2652  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
2653  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
2654 
2655 Input files required:
2656 ---------------------
2657 
2658 \b solver.inp
2659 \include 3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble/solver.inp
2660 
2661 \b boundary.inp
2662 \include 3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble/boundary.inp
2663 
2664 \b physics.inp
2665 \include 3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble/physics.inp
2666 
2667 \b weno.inp (optional)
2668 \include 3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble/weno.inp
2669 
2670 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
2671 and run the following code in the run directory.
2672 \include 3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble/aux/init.c
2673 
2674 Output:
2675 -------
2676 Note that \b iproc is set to
2677 
2678  2 2 2
2679 
2680 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, 2
2681 processors along \a y, and 2 processor along \a z). Thus,
2682 this example should be run with 8 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
2683 
2684 After running the code, there should be 41 output
2685 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00040.bin;
2686 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
2687 is the solution at \f$t=200\,{\rm s}\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
2688 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
2689 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
2690 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
2691 
2692 The code \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c can be used to convert the binary
2693 solution files to 3D Tecplot files that can be visualized in any software
2694 supporting the Tecplot format. Similarly, the code \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c
2695 can be used to convert the binary solution files to ASCII text files with the
2696 following data layout: the first three columns are grid indices, the next three
2697 columns are x, y, and z coordinates, and the remaining columns are the solution
2698 components (\f$\rho{'}, \rho u, \rho v, \rho w, \Theta{'}\f$).
2699 
2700 The following figure shows the density pertubation iso-surface for the initial
2701 and final solutions (plotted in VisIt):
2702 @image html Solution_3DNUMA_Bubble3D.png
2703 
2704 The code \b hypar/Extras/ExtractSlice.c can be used to extract a slice along at a specified location
2705 along any of the dimensions (\b Note: make a subdirectory \a slices before using this).
2706 It will write out 2D slice solutions in binary format in the \a slices subdirectory
2707 with the same names as the original solution files. The codes \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c
2708 and \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c can then be used to convert these to text or Tecplot
2709 formats for visualization. (\b Note: A copy of the original \a solver.inp is required in the \a slices subdirectory
2710 with \b ndims reduced by 1, and \b size and \b iproc with the appropriate component removed such that
2711 they have 2 components.)
2712 
2713 The following figure shows the density pertubation along a slice at \f$y=500\,{\rm m}\f$
2714 (plotted in VisIt):
2715 @image html Solution_3DNUMA_Bubble.gif
2716 
2717 Expected screen output:
2718 \include 3D/NUMA/RisingThermalBubble/output.log \page petsc_examples PETSc Examples
2719 
2720 The following are some examples that use explicit, implicit or semi-implicit (IMEX) time
2721 integration methods implemented in PETSc (https://petsc.org/release/). To run them,
2722 HyPar needs to be compiled \b with \b PETSc. Familiarity with using PETSc is assumed.
2723 
2724 \b Note:
2725 + In general, any example or simulation can use PETSc time-integrators (assuming
2726  HyPar is compiled with PETSc) by specifying the PETSc inputs through a
2727  <B>.petscrc</B> file, similar to the ones in the examples below.
2728  The following file is an example of a .petscrc file (with explanatory comments).
2729  - <B>hypar/Examples/PETScInputs/.petscrc_Example</B>
2730 + The PETSc example directories have a file <B>.petscrc</B> and a sym link \b petscrc
2731 pointing to .petscrc. The file .petscrc is the actual input file; \a petscrc is needed to generate
2732 this documentation because Doxygen does not seem to include files with names starting with a dot!
2733 + The inputs in the .petscrc files (any lines not starting with a #) can also be specified in the
2734 command line, for example,
2735 
2736  /path/to/hypar/bin/HyPar -use-petscts -ts_type rk -ts_rk_type 4 ...
2737 
2738 
2739 Explicit time integration:
2740 --------------------------
2741 \subpage linear_adv_sine_petsc \n
2742 \subpage linear_adv_disc_petsc (with local truncation error-based adaptive time-step)
2743 
2744 Implicit time integration:
2745 --------------------------
2746 \subpage linear_diff_sine_petsc \n
2747 \subpage linear_diff_sine2d_petsc (with local truncation error-based adaptive time-step) \n
2748 \subpage euler2d_vortex_petsc \n
2749 \subpage ns2d_ldsc_petsc_implicit (with local truncation error-based adaptive time-step) \n
2750 \subpage navstok2d_flatplate_petsc
2751 
2752 Implicit-Explicit (IMEX) time integration:
2753 ------------------------------------------
2754 \subpage euler2d_low_mach_vortex_petsc \n
2755 \subpage euler2d_igwave_petsc \n
2756 \subpage euler2d_rtb_petsc_imex (with local truncation error-based adaptive time-step) \n
2757 \subpage ns2d_ldsc_petsc_imex \n
2758 \subpage ns3d_bubble_petsc
2759 
2760 
2761 \page linear_adv_sine_petsc 1D Linear Advection - Sine Wave
2762 
2763 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc
2764  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2765  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2766  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2767  example).
2768 
2769 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
2770 
2771 References:
2772  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
2773  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
2774  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
2775 
2776 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
2777  boundary conditions
2778 
2779 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
2780 
2781 Numerical Method:
2782  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
2783  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
2784  - Method class: <B>Runge-Kutta</B> (TSRK - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSRK.html)
2785  - Specific method: <B>Classical 4th-order RK</B> (TSRK4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSRK4.html#TSRK4)
2786 
2787 Input files required:
2788 ---------------------
2789 
2790 <B>.petscrc</B>
2791 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/petscrc
2792 
2793 \b solver.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/physics.inp \b lusolver.inp (optional)
2794 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/lusolver.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
2795 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/weno.inp
2796 
2797 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
2798 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
2799 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
2800 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
2801 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
2802 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
2803 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
2804 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/aux/init.c
2805 
2806 Output:
2807 -------
2808 After running the code, there should be 11 output
2809 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
2810 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
2811 is the solution at \f$t=1\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
2812 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
2813 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
2814 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
2815 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
2816 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
2817 
2818 Solutions at t=0,0.5,1: The following figure is obtained
2819 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (initial), \a op_00005.dat (t=0.5),
2820 and \a op_00010.dat (final).
2821 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSinePETSc.png
2822 
2823 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
2824 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
2825 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
2826 as well as \b errors.dat:
2827 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/errors.dat
2828 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
2829 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
2830 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
2831 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
2832 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
2833 and cleaning up),
2834 and total wall time.
2835 
2836 Expected screen output:
2837 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_PETSc/output.log \page linear_adv_disc_petsc 1D Linear Advection - Discontinuous Waves
2838 
2839 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc
2840  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2841  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2842  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2843  example).
2844 
2845 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
2846 
2847 References:
2848  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
2849  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
2850  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
2851 
2852 Domain: \f$-1 \le x \le 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
2853  boundary conditions
2854 
2855 Initial solution:
2856  \f{equation}{
2857  u\left(x,0\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{lc}
2858  \exp\left(-\log\left(2\right)\frac{\left(x+7\right)^2}{0.0009}\right) & -0.8\le x \le -0.6 \\
2859  1 & -0.4\le x \le -0.2 \\
2860  1 - \left|10\left(x-0.1\right)\right| & 0\le x \le 0.2 \\
2861  \sqrt{1-100\left(x-0.5\right)^2} & 0.4\le x \le 0.6 \\
2862  0 & {\rm otherwise}
2863  \end{array}\right.
2864  \f}
2865 
2866 Numerical Method:
2867  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
2868  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
2869  - Method class: <B>Runge-Kutta</B> (TSRK - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSRK.html)
2870  - Specific method: <B>Dormand-Prince</B> (TSRK5DP - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSRK5DP.html#TSRK5DP)
2871 
2872 Input files required:
2873 ---------------------
2874 
2875 <B>.petscrc</B>
2876 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/petscrc
2877 
2878 \b solver.inp
2879 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/solver.inp
2880 
2881 \b boundary.inp
2882 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/boundary.inp
2883 
2884 \b physics.inp
2885 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/physics.inp
2886 
2887 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
2888 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/lusolver.inp
2889 
2890 \b weno.inp (optional)
2891 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/weno.inp
2892 
2893 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
2894 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
2895 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
2896 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
2897 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
2898 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
2899 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
2900 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/aux/init.c
2901 
2902 Output:
2903 -------
2904 After running the code, there should be two solution output
2905 files \b op_00000.dat and \b op_00001.dat; the first one is
2906 the initial solution, and the latter is the final solution.
2907 Both these files are ASCII text (#HyPar::op_file_format is
2908 set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
2909 
2910 Final solution at t=2.0: The following figure is obtained
2911 by plotting \a op_00000.dat (initial) and \a op_00001.dat
2912 (final). In both these files, the first column is grid
2913 index, the second column is x-coordinate, and the third
2914 column is the solution.
2915 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvDiscPETSc.png
2916 
2917 Expected screen output:
2918 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_PETSc/output.log \page linear_diff_sine_petsc 1D Linear Diffusion - Sine Wave
2919 
2920 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc
2921  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2922  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2923  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2924  example).
2925 
2926 Governing equations: 1D Linear Diffusion Equation (linearadr.h)
2927 
2928 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
2929  boundary conditions
2930 
2931 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
2932 
2933 Numerical Method:
2934  + Spatial discretization (parabolic): 2nd order (Interp2PrimSecondOrder()),
2935  conservative (ParabolicFunctionCons1Stage())
2936  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc()) - <B>Crank-Nicholson</B> (TSCN - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSCN.html)
2937 
2938 Input files required:
2939 ---------------------
2940 
2941 <B>.petscrc</B>
2942 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/petscrc
2943 
2944 \b solver.inp
2945 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/solver.inp
2946 
2947 \b boundary.inp
2948 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/boundary.inp
2949 
2950 \b physics.inp
2951 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/physics.inp
2952 
2953 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and
2954 \b exact.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
2955 following code in the run directory.
2956 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/aux/exact.c
2957 
2958 Output:
2959 -------
2960 After running the code, there should be 6 output
2961 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00005.dat;
2962 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
2963 is the solution at \f$t=10\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
2964 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
2965 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
2966 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
2967 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
2968 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
2969 
2970 Solutions at t=0,2,4,6,8,10: The following figure is obtained
2971 by plotting the solution files.
2972 @image html Solution_1DLinearDiffSinePETSc.png
2973 
2974 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
2975 , the numerical
2976 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
2977 as well as \b errors.dat:
2978 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/errors.dat
2979 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
2980 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
2981 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
2982 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
2983 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
2984 and cleaning up),
2985 and total wall time.
2986 
2987 Expected screen output:
2988 \include 1D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/output.log \page linear_diff_sine2d_petsc 2D Linear Diffusion - Sine Wave
2989 
2990 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc
2991  (This directory contains all the input files needed
2992  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
2993  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
2994  example).
2995 
2996 Governing equations: 2D Linear Diffusion Equation (linearadr.h)
2997 
2998 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
2999  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
3000 
3001 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\sin\left(2\pi y\right)\f$\n
3002 Exact solution: \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = \exp\left[-\pi^2 \left(4\nu_x + 4\nu_y\right) t\right] u0\left(x,y\right)\f$.
3003 
3004 Numerical Method:
3005  + Spatial discretization (parabolic): 2nd order (Interp2PrimSecondOrder()),
3006  conservative (ParabolicFunctionCons1Stage())
3007  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3008  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html) -
3009  Although the ARK methods are semi-implicit (IMEX), here they are used in the "fully implicit" mode, i.e., the implicit
3010  method is used to solve the complete equation (Note the flag \b -ts_arkimex_fully_implicit in <B>.petscrc</B>).
3011  - Specific method: <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
3012 
3013 
3014 Input files required:
3015 ---------------------
3016 
3017 <B>.petscrc</B>
3018 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/petscrc
3019 
3020 \b solver.inp
3021 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/solver.inp
3022 
3023 \b boundary.inp
3024 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/boundary.inp
3025 
3026 \b physics.inp (specifies \f$\nu_x\f$ and \f$\nu_y\f$)
3027 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/physics.inp
3028 
3029 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and
3030 \b exact.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
3031 following code in the run directory.
3032 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/aux/exact.c
3033 
3034 Output:
3035 -------
3036 Note that \b iproc is set to
3037 
3038  2 2
3039 
3040 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
3041 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3042 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3043 
3044 After running the code, there should be 2 output
3045 files: \b op_00000.dat (initial solution at t=0) and
3046 \b op_00001.dat (final solution at t=10). Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
3047 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
3048 for solutions at each output time.
3049 
3050 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
3051 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
3052 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
3053 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
3054 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
3055 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
3056 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
3057 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
3058 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
3059 MATLAB for example).
3060 
3061 The following plots show the initial and final solutions:
3062 @image html Solution_2DLinearDiffSinePETSc.png
3063 
3064 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
3065 , the numerical
3066 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
3067 as well as \b errors.dat:
3068 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/errors.dat
3069 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
3070 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
3071 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
3072 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
3073 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
3074 and cleaning up),
3075 and total wall time.
3076 
3077 Expected screen output:
3078 \include 2D/LinearDiffusion/SineWave_PETSc/output.log
3079 
3080 
3081 \page euler2d_rtb_petsc_imex 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Rising Thermal Bubble
3082 
3083 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX
3084  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3085  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
3086  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
3087  example).
3088 
3089 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
3090  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
3091  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
3092  equations are solved.)
3093 
3094 Reference:
3095  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
3096  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
3097  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
3098  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
3099  (Section 3.2).
3100 
3101 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
3102 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
3103 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
3104 latter integrated implicitly. See the following reference:
3105 + Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
3106  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
3107  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
3108  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
3109 
3110 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 1000\,m\f$,
3111  "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions on all sides.
3112 
3113 Initial solution: See references above.
3114 
3115 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
3116  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
3117  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
3118  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
3119  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
3120  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
3121  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
3122 
3123 Numerical method:
3124  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
3125  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3126  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
3127  - Specific method: <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
3128 
3129 
3130 Input files required:
3131 ---------------------
3132 
3133 <B>.petscrc</B>
3134 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/petscrc
3135 
3136 \b solver.inp
3137 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/solver.inp
3138 
3139 \b boundary.inp
3140 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/boundary.inp
3141 
3142 \b physics.inp
3143 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/physics.inp
3144 
3145 \b weno.inp (optional)
3146 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/weno.inp
3147 
3148 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
3149 and run the following code in the run directory.
3150 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/aux/init.c
3151 
3152 Output:
3153 -------
3154 Note that \b iproc is set to
3155 
3156  1 1
3157 
3158 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 1 processor along \a x, and 1
3159 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3160 with 1 MPI rank (or change \b iproc).
3161 
3162 After running the code, there should be a output
3163 file \b op.bin (final solution),
3164 since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
3165 
3166 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
3167 thus, the file is written out in the binary format, see
3168 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
3169 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
3170 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
3171 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
3172 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
3173 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
3174 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
3175 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
3176 a tecplot2d or text file.
3177 (compile and run it in the run directory):
3178 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/aux/PostProcess.c
3179 
3180 The following plot shows the potential temperature perturbation
3181 contours at the final time t=200s.
3182 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRTBPETSc.png
3183 It was plotted by using the
3184 above postprocessing code to write the solution in text format
3185 and using the following MATLAB script:
3186 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/PlotSolution.m
3187 
3188 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3189 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3190 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/function_counts.dat
3191 The numbers are, respectively,
3192 + Time iterations
3193 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3194 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3195 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3196 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3197 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3198 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3199 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3200 
3201 Expected screen output:
3202 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/output.log
3203 
3204 
3205 \page navstok2d_flatplate_petsc 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Laminar Flow over Flat Plate
3206 
3207 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit
3208  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3209  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
3210  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
3211  example).
3212 
3213 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
3214 
3215 Reference:
3216 + Hirsch, "Numerical Computation of Internal & External Flows",
3217  Volume 1 (Fundamentals of Computational Fluid Dynamics), 2nd
3218  Edition, Elsevier, Section 12.3.2 (page 618-625).
3219 
3220 Domain: \f$-0.25 \le x \le 1\f$, \f$0 \le y \le 0.25\f$
3221 
3222 Boundary conditions:
3223 + Symmetry BC on \f$y=0, -0.25 \le x < 0\f$ (imposed through "slip-wall"
3224  #_SLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
3225 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0
3226  wall velocity).
3227 + Subsonic outflow on \f$y=0.25\f$ (#_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_) with pressure
3228  \f$p=1/\gamma\f$.
3229 + Subsonic inflow on \f$x=0\f$ (#_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_) with density \f$\rho=1\f$,
3230  and velocity \f$(u,v) = (0.3,0)\f$.
3231 + Subsonic outflow on \f$x=1\f$ (#_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_) with pressure
3232  \f$p=1/\gamma\f$.
3233 
3234 Initial solution: Uniform flow with \f$\rho=1, u=0.3, v=0, p=1/\gamma\f$.
3235 
3236 Other parameters:
3237  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
3238  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100,000\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
3239  where \f$L=1\f$ is the plate length .
3240  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
3241  + \f$M_\infty = 0.3\f$ (freestream Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
3242 
3243 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
3244 speed of sound is 1.
3245 
3246 Numerical method:
3247  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
3248  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
3249  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
3250  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3251  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html) -
3252  Although the ARK methods are semi-implicit (IMEX), here they are used in the "fully implicit" mode, i.e., the implicit
3253  method is used to solve the complete equation (Note the flag \b -ts_arkimex_fully_implicit in <B>.petscrc</B>).
3254  - Specific method: <B>ARK2e</B> (TSARKIMEX2E - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX2E.html)
3255 
3256 This is a steady state problem - the solution converges to a steady laminar flow over a
3257 flat plate, and the residuals decrease with time. The skin friction coefficient is given by
3258 \f{equation}{
3259  c_f = \frac {0.664} {\sqrt{Re_x}}, Re_x = \frac {\rho u x} {\mu}
3260 \f}
3261 (Blasius solution).
3262 
3263 Input files required:
3264 ---------------------
3265 
3266 <B>.petscrc</B>
3267 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/petscrc
3268 
3269 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/physics.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
3270 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/weno.inp
3271 
3272 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
3273 and run the following code in the run directory.
3274 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/aux/init.c
3275 
3276 Output:
3277 -------
3278 Note that \b iproc is set to
3279 
3280  2 3
3281 
3282 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processor along \a x, and 3
3283 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3284 with 6 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3285 
3286 After running the code, there should be one output file
3287 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
3288 
3289 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
3290 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
3291 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
3292 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
3293 are available to convert the binary output file:
3294 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
3295  Tecplot file (works only for 2D and 3D).
3296 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
3297  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
3298 
3299 The following plot was obtained by converting the binary file to the
3300 Tecplot format, and using VisIt to plot it (it shows the density
3301 and velocity):
3302 @image html Solution_2DNavStokFlatPlate.png
3303 The following plot shows a magnified view of the boundary layer:
3304 @image html Solution_2DNavStokFlatPlateMagnified.png
3305 
3306 The following file computes the skin friction as a function of the
3307 Reynolds number and writes to to a text file \b SkinFriction.dat with 4
3308 columns: Reynolds number, computed skin friction coefficient, exact skin
3309 friction coefficient (\f$0.664/\sqrt{Re_x}\f$), and normal velocity gradient
3310 on the plate surface (\f$\left.\partial u/\partial y\right|_{y=0}\f$).
3311 Compile and run it in the run directory.
3312 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/aux/SkinFriction.c
3313 The following figure showing the exact and computed skin friction coefficients
3314 was obtained by plotting \b SkinFriction.dat:
3315 @image html Solution_2DNavStokFlatPlateSkinFrictionPETSc.png
3316 
3317 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3318 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3319 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/function_counts.dat
3320 The numbers are, respectively,
3321 + Time iterations
3322 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3323 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3324 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3325 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3326 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3327 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3328 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3329 
3330 Expected screen output:
3331 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/FlatPlateLaminar_PETSc_Implicit/output.log
3332 
3333 \page ns2d_ldsc_petsc_imex 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Lid-Driven Square Cavity
3334 
3335 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX
3336  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3337  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
3338  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
3339  example).
3340 
3341 Governing equations: 2D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
3342 
3343 Reference:
3344 + Erturk, E., Corke, T.C., and Gokcol, C., "Numerical Solutions of
3345  2-D Steady Incompressible Driven Cavity Flow at High Reynolds Numbers",
3346  International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids, 48, 2005,
3347  http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/fld.953.
3348 + Ghia, U., Ghia, K.N., Shin, C.T., "High-Re Solutions for Incompressible
3349  Flow using the Navier-Stokes Equations and a Multigrid Method", Journal
3350  of Computational Physics, 48, 1982, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0021-9991(82)90058-4.
3351 
3352 Note that this is an incompressible problem being solved here using the compressible
3353 Navier-Stokes equations in terms of non-dimensional flow variables. The density and
3354 pressure are taken such that the speed of sound is 1.0, and the flow velocities
3355 specified in the initial and boundary conditions correspond to a characteristic
3356 Mach number of 0.1 (thus, they are 0.1 times the values in the above reference).
3357 
3358 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
3359 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
3360 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
3361 latter integrated implicitly. See:
3362 + Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
3363  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
3364  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
3365  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
3366 
3367 Domain: \f$0 \le x, y \le 1\f$
3368 
3369 Boundary conditions:
3370 + No-slip wall BC on \f$x=0,1, 0 \le y \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
3371 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
3372 + Moving no-slip wall BC on \f$y=1, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with specified
3373  wall velocity of 0.1 in the x-direction).
3374 
3375 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, p=1/\gamma\f$. The velocities are specified according to
3376 the references above, but scaled by a factor of 0.1 to ensure that the characteristic
3377 Mach number is 0.1.
3378 
3379 Other parameters:
3380  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
3381  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 3200\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
3382  where \f$L=1\f$ is the cavity length and width.
3383  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
3384  + \f$M_\infty = 0.1\f$ (characteristic Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
3385 
3386 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
3387 speed of sound is 1.
3388 
3389 Numerical method:
3390  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
3391  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
3392  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
3393  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3394  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
3395  - Specific method: <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
3396 
3397 Input files required:
3398 ---------------------
3399 
3400 <B>.petscrc</B>
3401 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/petscrc
3402 
3403 \b solver.inp
3404 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/solver.inp
3405 
3406 \b boundary.inp
3407 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/boundary.inp
3408 
3409 \b physics.inp (\b Note: this file specifies \f$Re = 3200\f$,
3410 change \a Re here for other Reynolds numbers.)
3411 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/physics.inp
3412 
3413 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
3414 and run the following code in the run directory.
3415 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/aux/init.c
3416 
3417 Output:
3418 -------
3419 Note that \b iproc is set to
3420 
3421  2 2
3422 
3423 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
3424 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3425 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3426 
3427 After running the code, there should be one output file
3428 \b op.dat, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
3429 Since #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp,
3430 this file is in the ASCII Tecplot format and can be viewed in any
3431 software that supports this format (e.g. VisIt).
3432 
3433 The following plot shows the streamlines (colored by the velocity magnitude):
3434 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re3200_PETSc_IMEX.png
3435 
3436 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3437 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3438 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/function_counts.dat
3439 The numbers are, respectively,
3440 + Time iterations
3441 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3442 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3443 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3444 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3445 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3446 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3447 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3448 
3449 Expected screen output (for Reynolds number 3200):
3450 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_IMEX/output.log
3451 
3452 \page ns3d_bubble_petsc 3D Navier-Stokes Equations - Rising Thermal Bubble
3453 
3454 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX
3455  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3456  to run this case.)
3457 
3458 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
3459 
3460 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y,z < 1000\,{\rm m}\f$, \a "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundaries
3461  everywhere, with zero wall velocity.
3462 
3463 Reference:
3464  + Kelly, J. F., Giraldo, F. X., "Continuous and discontinuous Galerkin methods for a scalable
3465  three-dimensional nonhydrostatic atmospheric model: Limited-area mode", J. Comput. Phys., 231,
3466  2012, pp. 7988-8008 (see section 5.1.2).
3467  + Giraldo, F. X., Kelly, J. F., Constantinescu, E. M., "Implicit-Explicit Formulations of a
3468  Three-Dimensional Nonhydrostatic Unified Model of the Atmosphere (NUMA)", SIAM J. Sci. Comput.,
3469  35 (5), 2013, pp. B1162-B1194 (see section 4.1).
3470 
3471 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
3472 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
3473 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
3474 latter integrated implicitly. See the following reference:
3475 + Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
3476  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
3477  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
3478  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
3479 
3480 Initial solution: A warm bubble in cool ambient atmosphere. Note that in this example, the
3481 gravitational forces and rising of the bubble is along the \a y-axis.
3482 
3483 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
3484  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
3485  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::R)
