3486  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes3D::grav_y)
3487  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::rho0)
3488  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::p0)
3489  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes3D::HB)
3490 
3491 Numerical Method:
3492  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
3493  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3494  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
3495  - Specific method: <B>ARK 2e</B> (TSARKIMEX2E - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX2E.html)
3496 
3497 Input files required:
3498 ---------------------
3499 
3500 <B>.petscrc</B>
3501 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/petscrc
3502 
3503 \b solver.inp
3504 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/solver.inp
3505 
3506 \b boundary.inp
3507 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/boundary.inp
3508 
3509 \b physics.inp
3510 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/physics.inp
3511 
3512 \b weno.inp (optional)
3513 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/weno.inp
3514 
3515 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
3516 and run the following code in the run directory.
3517 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/aux/init.c
3518 
3519 Output:
3520 -------
3521 Note that \b iproc is set to
3522 
3523  4 4 4
3524 
3525 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, 4
3526 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
3527 this example should be run with 64 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3528 
3529 After running the code, there should be 11 output
3530 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
3531 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
3532 is the solution at \f$t=200\,{\rm s}\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
3533 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
3534 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
3535 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
3536 
3537 The binary solution file contains the conserved variables
3538 (\f$\rho,\rho u,\rho v,\rho w,e\f$). The Python script
3539 plotSolution.py calculates the primitive
3540 and reference variables
3541 \f$\rho,u,v,w,P,\theta,\rho_0,P_0,\pi,\theta_0\f$ (where the
3542 subscript \f$0\f$ indicates the hydrostatic mean value) and plots
3543 3D figures for \f$\theta\f$ (potential temperature).
3544 
3545 The following figure shows the potential temperature at the final time. Colored
3546 contours are plotted in the X-Y plane, and contour lines are plotted in the Z-Y
3547 plane:
3548 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_Bubble3D_PETSc.png
3549 
3550 The code <B>Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/aux/PostProcess.c</B>
3551 can be used to convert the binary solution files to Tecplot or plain text files with the
3552 primitive and reference variables.
3553 
3554 The file \b Extras/ExtractSlice.c can be used to extract a slice perpendicular to any dimension
3555 at a specified location along that dimension. The extract slice is written out in the same
3556 binary format as the original solutions files (with the same names op_xxxxx.bin) in a
3557 subdirectory called \b slices (\b Note: make the subdirectory called \a slices before running
3558 this code). The following code (<B>Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/aux/PostProcessSlice.c</B>)
3559 can then be used (in the \b slices subdirectory) to convert the binary slice solution file (with conserved variables
3560 \f$\rho,\rho u,\rho v,\rho w,e\f$) to Tecplot or plain text files with the primitive
3561 and reference variables \f$\rho,u,v,w,P,\theta,\rho_0,P_0,\pi,\theta_0\f$.
3562 \b Note that it needs the relevant \b solver.inp and \b physics.inp that can be created
3563 as follows:
3564 + Copy the original solver.inp and physics.inp to the slices subdirectory.
3565 + In solver.inp, set \b ndims as \b 2, and remove the component of \b size and \b iproc
3566  corresponding to the dimension being eliminated while extracting the slices (in this case,
3567  it is \a z or the 3rd component).
3568 + In physics.inp, remove the component of \b gravity corresponding to the dimension perpendicular
3569  to the slice.
3570 
3571 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3572 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3573 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/function_counts.dat
3574 The numbers are, respectively,
3575 + Time iterations
3576 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3577 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3578 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3579 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3580 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3581 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3582 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3583 
3584 Expected screen output:
3585 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX/output.log
3586 
3587 
3588 \page euler2d_vortex_petsc 2D Euler Equations - Isentropic Vortex Convection
3589 
3590 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit
3591  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3592  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
3593  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
3594  example).
3595 
3596 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
3597  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
3598  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
3599  equations are solved.)
3600 
3601 Reference: C.-W. Shu, "Essentially Non-oscillatory and Weighted Essentially
3602  Non-oscillatory Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
3603  ICASE Report 97-65, 1997
3604 
3605 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
3606  boundary conditions.
3607 
3608 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
3609 \f{equation}{
3610  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.5,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
3611 \f}
3612 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
3613 \f{align}{
3614 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
3615 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
3616 \f}
3617 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
3618 
3619 Numerical method:
3620  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order compact upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind())
3621  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc()) - <B>Crank-Nicholson</B> (TSCN - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSCN.html)
3622 
3623 Input files required:
3624 ---------------------
3625 
3626 <B>.petscrc</B>
3627 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/petscrc
3628 
3629 \b solver.inp
3630 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/solver.inp
3631 
3632 \b boundary.inp
3633 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/boundary.inp
3634 
3635 \b physics.inp
3636 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/physics.inp
3637 
3638 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
3639 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/lusolver.inp
3640 
3641 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp
3642 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
3643 directory.
3644 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/aux/exact.c
3645 
3646 Output:
3647 -------
3648 Note that \b iproc is set to
3649 
3650  2 2
3651 
3652 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
3653 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3654 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3655 
3656 After running the code, there should be 11 output
3657 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
3658 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
3659 is the solution at \f$t=20\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
3660 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
3661 for solutions at each output time.
3662 
3663 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
3664 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
3665 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
3666 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
3667 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
3668 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
3669 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
3670 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
3671 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
3672 MATLAB for example).
3673 
3674 The following plot shows the density contours at the final time t=1,
3675 obtained from plotting \b op_00010.dat:
3676 @image html Solution_2DNavStokVortexPETSc.gif
3677 
3678 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
3679 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
3680 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
3681 as well as \b errors.dat:
3682 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/errors.dat
3683 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
3684 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
3685 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
3686 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
3687 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
3688 and cleaning up),
3689 and total wall time.
3690 
3691 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
3692 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
3693 as the file \b conservation.dat:
3694 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/conservation.dat
3695 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
3696 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
3697 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
3698 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) of each component.
3699 \b Note that the conservation error depends on the accuracy with which the
3700 implicit systems are solved. Since the systems are solved with relaxed tolerances
3701 here (see \a ksp_atol, \a ksp_rtol, \a snes_atol, \a snes_rtol in <B>.petscrc</B>),
3702 the conservation error is zero within round-off.
3703 
3704 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3705 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3706 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/function_counts.dat
3707 The numbers are, respectively,
3708 + Time iterations
3709 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3710 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3711 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3712 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3713 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3714 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3715 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3716 
3717 Expected screen output:
3718 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_PETSc_Implicit/output.log \page euler2d_low_mach_vortex_petsc 2D Euler Equations - Low-Mach Isentropic Vortex Convection
3719 
3720 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX
3721  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3722  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
3723  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
3724  example).
3725 
3726 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
3727  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
3728  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
3729  equations are solved.)
3730 
3731 Reference: Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
3732  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
3733  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
3734  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
3735 
3736 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
3737 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
3738 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
3739 latter integrated implicitly. See the above reference.
3740 
3741 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
3742  boundary conditions.
3743 
3744 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
3745 \f{equation}{
3746  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.1,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
3747 \f}
3748 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
3749 \f{align}{
3750 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
3751 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
3752 \f}
3753 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
3754 
3755 Numerical method:
3756  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
3757  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3758  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
3759  - Specific method: <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
3760 
3761 Input files required:
3762 ---------------------
3763 
3764 <B>.petscrc</B>
3765 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/petscrc
3766 
3767 \b solver.inp
3768 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/solver.inp
3769 
3770 \b boundary.inp
3771 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/boundary.inp
3772 
3773 \b physics.inp
3774 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/physics.inp
3775 
3776 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp (exact solution),
3777 compile and run the following code in the run
3778 directory:
3779 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/aux/exact.c
3780 
3781 Output:
3782 -------
3783 Note that \b iproc is set to
3784 
3785  2 2
3786 
3787 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, and 2
3788 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3789 with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3790 
3791 After running the code, there should be 11 output
3792 files \b op_00000.dat, \b op_00001.dat, ... \b op_00010.dat;
3793 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
3794 is the solution at \f$t=100\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
3795 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
3796 for solutions at each output time.
3797 
3798 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
3799 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
3800 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
3801 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
3802 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
3803 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
3804 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
3805 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
3806 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
3807 MATLAB for example).
3808 
3809 The following plot shows the density contours at the final time t=1,
3810 obtained from plotting \b op_00010.dat:
3811 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLowMachVortexPETSc.gif
3812 
3813 Since the exact solution is available at the final time
3814 (\a exact.inp is a copy of \a initial.inp), the numerical
3815 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
3816 as well as \b errors.dat:
3817 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/errors.dat
3818 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
3819 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
3820 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
3821 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
3822 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
3823 and cleaning up),
3824 and total wall time.
3825 
3826 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
3827 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
3828 as the file \b conservation.dat:
3829 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/conservation.dat
3830 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
3831 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
3832 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
3833 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) of each component.
3834 \b Note that the conservation error depends on the accuracy with which the
3835 implicit systems are solved (see \a ksp_atol, \a ksp_rtol, \a snes_atol,
3836 \a snes_rtol in <B>.petscrc</B>).
3837 
3838 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3839 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3840 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/function_counts.dat
3841 The numbers are, respectively,
3842 + Time iterations
3843 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3844 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3845 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3846 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3847 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3848 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3849 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3850 
3851 Expected screen output:
3852 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LowMachVortexConvection_PETSc_IMEX/output.log \page euler2d_igwave_petsc 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Inertia-Gravity Waves
3853 
3854 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX
3855  (This directory contains all the input files needed
3856  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
3857  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
3858  example).
3859 
3860 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
3861  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
3862  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
3863  equations are solved.)
3864 
3865 Reference:
3866  + W. C. Skamarock and J. B. Klemp, "Efficiency and accuracy of
3867  the Klemp-Wilhelmson timesplitting technique", Monthly Weather
3868  Review, 122 (1994), pp. 2623–2630.
3869  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
3870  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
3871  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
3872  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
3873  (Section 3.1).
3874 
3875 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
3876 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
3877 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
3878 latter integrated implicitly. See the following reference:
3879 + Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
3880  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
3881  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
3882  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
3883 
3884 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 300,000\,m, 0 \le y \le 10,000\,m\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
3885  boundary conditions along \f$x\f$, "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions along \f$y\f$.
3886 
3887 Initial solution: See references above.
3888 
3889 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
3890  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
3891  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
3892  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
3893  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
3894  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
3895  + Hydrostatic balance type 3 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
3896  + Brunt-Vaisala frequency 0.01 (#NavierStokes2D::N_bv)
3897 
3898 Numerical method:
3899  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order compact upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind())
3900  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
3901  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
3902  - Specific method: <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
3903 
3904 
3905 Input files required:
3906 ---------------------
3907 
3908 <B>.petscrc</B>
3909 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/petscrc
3910 
3911 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/physics.inp
3912 
3913 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
3914 and run the following code in the run directory.
3915 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/aux/init.c
3916 
3917 Output:
3918 -------
3919 Note that \b iproc is set to
3920 
3921  12 1
3922 
3923 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 12 processors along \a x, and 1
3924 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
3925 with 12 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
3926 
3927 After running the code, there should be 16 output
3928 files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00015.bin;
3929 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0s\f$ and the final one
3930 is the solution at \f$t=3000s\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
3931 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
3932 for solutions at each output time.
3933 
3934 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
3935 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
3936 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
3937 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
3938 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
3939 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
3940 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
3941 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
3942 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
3943 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
3944 a tecplot2d or text file.
3945 (compile and run it in the run directory):
3946 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/aux/PostProcess.c
3947 
3948 The following plot shows the potential temperature perturbation
3949 contours at the final time t=3000. It was plotted using VisIt
3950 (https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/) with
3951 tecplot2d format chosen in the above postprocessing code.
3952 @image html Solution_2DNavStokIGWavePETSc.png
3953 
3954 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
3955 (in terms of the number of function counts):
3956 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/function_counts.dat
3957 The numbers are, respectively,
3958 + Time iterations
3959 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
3960 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
3961 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
3962 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
3963 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
3964 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
3965 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
3966 
3967 Expected screen output:
3968 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX/output.log
3969 
3970 
3971 
3972 \page ib_examples Immersed Boundaries Examples
3973 
3974 The following are some examples are use the immersed boundary methodology to solve the PDE in the presence of
3975 various geometries. To use the immersed boundary implementation in HyPar, an STL (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/STL_%28file_format%29)
3976 representation of the immersed body is necessary. Note:
3977 + The immersed boundary method is \b only implemented for 3-dimensional simulations (#HyPar::ndims = 3).
3978 + It can be used with only those physical models that define an immersed boundary implementation (#HyPar::IBFunction()), for
3979  example, the 3D Navier-Stokes (#NavierStokes3D) equations (NavierStokes3DIBAdiabatic(), NavierStokes3DIBIsothermal()).
3980 
3981 3D Navier-Stokes Equations:
3982 ---------------------------
3983 
3984 \subpage ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous \n
3985 \subpage ns3d_cylinder_unsteady_incompressible_viscous
3986 
3987 \subpage ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction
3988 
3989 \subpage ns3d_sphere_steady_incompressible_viscous_adiabatic \n
3990 \subpage ns3d_sphere_steady_incompressible_viscous_isothermal \n
3991 \subpage ns3d_sphere_steady_incompressible_viscous_isothermal_warm \n
3992 \subpage ns3d_sphere_unsteady_compressible_viscous_adiabatic \n
3993 \subpage ns3d_sphere_unsteady_compressible_viscous_isothermal
3994 
3995 \page ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous Steady, incompressible, viscous flow around a cylinder
3996 
3997 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible
3998 
3999 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4000 
4001 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the cylinder defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2],
4002  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4003 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
4004  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
4005  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
4006 
4007 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
4008  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
4009 
4010 The following images shows the grid and the cylinder:
4011 @image html Domain3D_Cylinder.png
4012 @image html Domain2D_Cylinder.png
4013 
4014 Boundary conditions:
4015  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4016  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4017  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4018  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
4019  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
4020  (this is the default).
4021 
4022 Reference:
4023  + Taneda, S., "Experimental Investigation of the Wakes behind Cylinders and Plates at Low
4024  Reynolds Numbers," Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, Vol. 11, 302–307, 1956.
4025  + Dennis, S. C. R., Chang, G.-Z., "Numerical solutions for steady flow past a circular
4026  cylinder at Reynolds numbers up to 100", Journal of Fluid Mechanics, 42 (3), 1970,
4027  pp. 471-489.
4028 
4029 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4030 
4031 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4032  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4033  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4034  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4035  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 10,15,20\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re) (\b Note:
4036  since the diameter of the cylinder is 2.0, the cylinder-diameter-based Reynolds number is
4037  \f$Re_D = 2Re = 20,30,40\f$.
4038 
4039 Numerical Method:
4040  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4041  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4042  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4043  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4044 
4045 Input files required:
4046 ---------------------
4047 
4048 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible/
4049 
4050 \b solver.inp
4051 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible/solver.inp
4052 
4053 \b boundary.inp
4054 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible/boundary.inp
4055 
4056 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
4057 of 10 (corresponding to \f$Re_D\f$ of 20). To try other Reynolds
4058 numbers, change it here.
4059 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible/physics.inp
4060 
4061 \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
4062 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4063 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
4064 
4065 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4066 and run the following code in the run directory.
4067 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible/aux/init.c
4068 
4069 Output:
4070 -------
4071 
4072 Note that \b iproc is set to
4073 
4074  2 2 1
4075 
4076 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, 2
4077 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
4078 this example should be run with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4079 
4080 After running the code, there should be one output file
4081 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
4082 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4083 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4084 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4085 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4086 are available to convert the binary output file:
4087 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4088  Tecplot file.
4089 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4090  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4091 
4092 The file \b Extras/ExtractSlice.c can be used to extract a slice perpendicular to any dimension
4093 at a specified location along that dimension. The extracted slice is written out in the same
4094 binary format as the original solutions files (with the same names op_xxxxx.bin) in a
4095 subdirectory called \b slices (\b Note: make the subdirectory called \a slices before running
4096 this code). The codes Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c and Extras/BinaryToText.c
4097 can then be used (in the \b slices subdirectory) to convert the binary slice solution file
4098 to Tecplot or plain text files.
4099 \b Note that it needs the relevant \b solver.inp that can be created as follows:
4100 + Copy the original solver.inp to the slices subdirectory.
4101 + In solver.inp, set \b ndims as \b 2, and remove the component of \b size and \b iproc
4102  corresponding to the dimension being eliminated while extracting the slices (in this case,
4103  it is \a z or the 3rd component).
4104 
4105 The following figure shows the flow (density and streamlines) at \f$Re_D=20\f$:
4106 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_ReD020.png
4107 The parameter \a Re can be changed to 20 in \a physics.inp to run this simulation for
4108 \f$Re_D=40\f$, and following figure shows the solution:
4109 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_ReD040.png
4110 
4111 The following plot shows the wake length (\f$L/D\f$) as a function of the Reynolds
4112 number (\f$Re_D\f$) for the computed solutions and experimental results reported
4113 in the reference above:
4114 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_WL.png
4115 
4116 In addition to the main solution, the code also writes out a file with the aerodynamic
4117 forces on the immersed body. This file is called \a surface.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite
4118 is "yes") or \a surface_nnnnn.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite is "no", "nnnnn" is a numerical
4119 index) (in this example, the file \b surface.dat is written out). This is an ASCII file in
4120 the Tecplot format, where the immersed body and the forces on it are represented using the
4121 "FETRIANGLE" type. The following image shows the surface pressure on the cylinder (front-view):
4122 @image html IBSurface_3DNavStokCylinder.png
4123 Since this is a 2D simulation, the value of the surface pressure on the end-surfaces of the
4124 cylinder (zmin and zmax) are not physically relevant.
4125 
4126 Expected screen output (for \f$Re_D = 20\f$):
4127 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible/output.log
4128 
4129 
4130 \page ns3d_cylinder_unsteady_incompressible_viscous Unsteady, incompressible, viscous flow around a cylinder (vortex shedding)
4131 
4132 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible
4133 
4134 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4135 
4136 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the cylinder defined by [-4,12] X [-2,2],
4137  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4138 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
4139  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
4140  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
4141 
4142 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
4143  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
4144 
4145 The following images shows the grid and the cylinder:
4146 @image html Domain3D_Cylinder2.png
4147 @image html Domain2D_Cylinder2.png
4148 
4149 Boundary conditions:
4150  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4151  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4152  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4153  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
4154  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
4155  (this is the default).
4156 
4157 Reference:
4158  + Taneda, S., "Experimental Investigation of the Wakes behind Cylinders and Plates at Low
4159  Reynolds Numbers," Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, Vol. 11, 302–307, 1956.
4160 
4161 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4162 
4163 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4164  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4165  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4166  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4167  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 50\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re) (\b Note:
4168  since the diameter of the cylinder is 2.0, the cylinder-diameter-based Reynolds number is
4169  \f$Re_D = 2Re = 100\f$.
4170 
4171 Numerical Method:
4172  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4173  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4174  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4175  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4176 
4177 Input files required:
4178 ---------------------
4179 
4180 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible/
4181 
4182 \b solver.inp
4183 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible/solver.inp
4184 
4185 \b boundary.inp
4186 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible/boundary.inp
4187 
4188 \b physics.inp
4189 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible/physics.inp
4190 
4191 \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
4192 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4193 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
4194 
4195 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4196 and run the following code in the run directory.
4197 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible/aux/init.c
4198 
4199 Output:
4200 -------
4201 
4202 Note that \b iproc is set to
4203 
4204  4 2 1
4205 
4206 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, 2
4207 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
4208 this example should be run with 8 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4209 
4210 After running the code, there should be 401 solution files \b op_00000.bin,
4211 \b op_00001.bin, ..., \b op_00400.bin. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to
4212 \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written for solutions at each
4213 output time.
4214 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4215 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4216 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4217 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4218 are available to convert the binary output file:
4219 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4220  Tecplot file.
4221 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4222  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4223 
4224 The file \b Extras/ExtractSlice.c can be used to extract a slice perpendicular to any dimension
4225 at a specified location along that dimension. The extracted slice is written out in the same
4226 binary format as the original solutions files (with the same names op_xxxxx.bin) in a
4227 subdirectory called \b slices (\b Note: make the subdirectory called \a slices before running
4228 this code). The codes Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c and Extras/BinaryToText.c
4229 can then be used (in the \b slices subdirectory) to convert the binary slice solution file
4230 to Tecplot or plain text files.
4231 \b Note that it needs the relevant \b solver.inp that can be created as follows:
4232 + Copy the original solver.inp to the slices subdirectory.
4233 + In solver.inp, set \b ndims as \b 2, and remove the component of \b size and \b iproc
4234  corresponding to the dimension being eliminated while extracting the slices (in this case,
4235  it is \a z or the 3rd component).
4236 
4237 The following animation shows the vorticity magnitude and has been created by
4238 plotting op_00301.bin through op_00400.bin, and shows the vortex shedding:
4239 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_Shedding.gif
4240 
4241 Expected screen output:
4242 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible/output.log
4243 
4244 
4245 \page ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction Inviscid Shock-Cylinder Interaction
4246 
4247 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction
4248 
4249 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h - by default
4250  #NavierStokes3D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
4251  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 3D Euler
4252  equations are solved.)
4253 
4254 Domain: \f$-2.5 \le x \le 7.5\f$, \f$-5 \le y \le 5\f$
4255 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
4256  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
4257  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
4258 
4259 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
4260  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
4261 
4262 Boundary conditions:
4263  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_ (with post-shock flow conditions)
4264  + xmax: Supersonic inflow #_SUPERSONIC_OUTFLOW_ (with pre-shock flow conditions)
4265  + ymin and ymax: Slip walls #_SLIP_WALL_
4266  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
4267  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
4268  (this is the default).
4269 
4270 Reference:
4271 + O. Boiron, G. Chiavassa, R. Donat, A high-resolution penalization method for large Mach number
4272  flows in the presence of obstacles, Computers & Fluids, 38 (2009), pp. 703-714, Section 5.1
4273 
4274 Initial solution: see reference
4275 
4276 Other parameters:
4277  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4278 
4279 Numerical Method:
4280  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4281  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4282 
4283 Input files required:
4284 ---------------------
4285 
4286 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction/
4287 
4288 \b solver.inp
4289 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction/solver.inp
4290 
4291 \b boundary.inp
4292 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction/boundary.inp
4293 
4294 \b physics.inp
4295 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction/physics.inp
4296 
4297 \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
4298 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4299 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
4300 
4301 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4302 and run the following code in the run directory.
4303 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction/aux/init.c
4304 
4305 Output:
4306 -------
4307 
4308 Note that \b iproc is set to
4309 
4310  2 2 1
4311 
4312 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 2 processors along \a x, 2
4313 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
4314 this example should be run with 4 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4315 
4316 After running the code, there should be 81 solution files \b op_00000.bin
4317 (initial solution),
4318 \b op_00001.bin, ..., \b op_00080.bin (solution at t=2).
4319 Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to
4320 \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written for solutions at each
4321 output time.
4322 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4323 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4324 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4325 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4326 are available to convert the binary output file:
4327 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4328  Tecplot file.
4329 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4330  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4331 
4332 The file \b Extras/ExtractSlice.c can be used to extract a slice perpendicular to any dimension
4333 at a specified location along that dimension. The extracted slice is written out in the same
4334 binary format as the original solutions files (with the same names op_xxxxx.bin) in a
4335 subdirectory called \b slices (\b Note: make the subdirectory called \a slices before running
4336 this code). The codes Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c and Extras/BinaryToText.c
4337 can then be used (in the \b slices subdirectory) to convert the binary slice solution file
4338 to Tecplot or plain text files.
4339 \b Note that it needs the relevant \b solver.inp that can be created as follows:
4340 + Copy the original solver.inp to the slices subdirectory.
4341 + In solver.inp, set \b ndims as \b 2, and remove the component of \b size and \b iproc
4342  corresponding to the dimension being eliminated while extracting the slices (in this case,
4343  it is \a z or the 3rd component).
4344 
4345 The following plot shows the density contours for the final solution (t=2):
4346 @image html Solution_3DNavStokShockCyl_Density.png
4347 and the following is the numerical Schlieren image (contour plot of \f$\|\nabla\rho\|_2\f$):
4348 @image html Solution_3DNavStokShockCyl_Schlieren.png
4349 @image html Solution_3DNavStokShockCyl_Schlieren2.png
4350 
4351 Expected screen output:
4352 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction/output.log
4353 
4354 \page ns3d_sphere_steady_incompressible_viscous_adiabatic Steady, incompressible, viscous flow around an adiabatic sphere
4355 
4356 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic
4357 
4358 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4359 
4360 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the sphere defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2] X [-2,2],
4361  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4362 
4363 Geometry: A sphere of radius 0.5 centered at (0,0)
4364  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl)
4365 
4366 The following image shows the sphere:
4367 @image html Surface3D_Sphere.png
4368 
4369 The following images shows the grid and the sphere:
4370 @image html Domain3D_Sphere1.png
4371 @image html Domain3D_Sphere2.png
4372 
4373 Boundary conditions:
4374  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4375  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4376  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4377  + zmin and zmax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4378  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
4379  (this is the default).
4380 
4381 Reference:
4382  + Taneda, S., “Experimental Investigation of Wake behind a Sphere at Low Reynolds Numbers,”
4383  Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, Vol. 11, 1956.
4384  + Johnson, T.A. and Patel, V.C., “Flow Past a Sphere up to a Reynolds Number of 300,”
4385  Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 378, 1999.
4386 
4387 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4388 
4389 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4390  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4391  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4392  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4393  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re)
4394  (\b Note: since the diameter of the sphere is 1.0, the diameter-based Reynolds number
4395  is the same as the specified Reynolds number \f$Re_D = Re = 100\f$).
4396 
4397 Numerical Method:
4398  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4399  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4400  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4401  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4402 
4403 Input files required:
4404 ---------------------
4405 
4406 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic/
4407 
4408 \b solver.inp
4409 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic/solver.inp
4410 
4411 \b boundary.inp
4412 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic/boundary.inp
4413 
4414 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
4415 of 100. To try other Reynolds numbers, change it here.
4416 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic/physics.inp
4417 
4418 \b sphere.stl : the filename "sphere.stl" \b must match
4419 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4420 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl
4421 
4422 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4423 and run the following code in the run directory.
4424 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic/aux/init.c
4425 
4426 Output:
4427 -------
4428 
4429 Note that \b iproc is set to
4430 
4431  8 4 4
4432 
4433 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
4434 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
4435 this example should be run with 128 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4436 
4437 After running the code, there should be one output file
4438 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
4439 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4440 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4441 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4442 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4443 are available to convert the binary output file:
4444 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4445  Tecplot file.
4446 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4447  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4448 
4449 The following figure shows the flow (pressure and streamlines) at \f$Re_D=100\f$:
4450 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphere_ReD100.png
4451 
4452 In addition to the main solution, the code also writes out a file with the aerodynamic
4453 forces on the immersed body. This file is called \a surface.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite
4454 is "yes") or \a surface_nnnnn.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite is "no", "nnnnn" is a numerical
4455 index) (in this example, the file \b surface.dat is written out). This is an ASCII file in
4456 the Tecplot format, where the immersed body and the forces on it are represented using the
4457 "FETRIANGLE" type. The following image shows the surface pressure and temperature
4458 on the sphere (front-view):
4459 @image html IBSurface_3DNavStokSphereAdiabatic_Pressure.png
4460 @image html IBSurface_3DNavStokSphereAdiabatic_Temperature.png
4461 
4462 Expected screen output:
4463 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Adiabatic/output.log
4464 
4465 \page ns3d_sphere_steady_incompressible_viscous_isothermal Steady, incompressible, viscous flow around an isothermal sphere
4466 
4467 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal
4468 
4469 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4470 
4471 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the sphere defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2] X [-2,2],
4472  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4473 
4474 Geometry: A sphere of radius 0.5 centered at (0,0)
4475  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl)
4476 
4477 The following image shows the sphere:
4478 @image html Surface3D_Sphere.png
4479 
4480 The following images shows the grid and the sphere:
4481 @image html Domain3D_Sphere1.png
4482 @image html Domain3D_Sphere2.png
4483 
4484 Boundary conditions:
4485  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4486  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4487  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4488  + zmin and zmax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4489  + The immersed body wall is specified as isothermal (#_IB_ISOTHERMAL_)
4490  with specified wall temperature \f$T_{\rm wall} = 1/\gamma\f$.
4491 
4492 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4493 
4494 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4495  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4496  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4497  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4498  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re)
4499  (\b Note: since the diameter of the sphere is 1.0, the diameter-based Reynolds number
4500  is the same as the specified Reynolds number \f$Re_D = Re = 100\f$).
4501 
4502 Numerical Method:
4503  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4504  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4505  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4506  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4507 
4508 Input files required:
4509 ---------------------
4510 
4511 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal/
4512 
4513 \b solver.inp
4514 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal/solver.inp
4515 
4516 \b boundary.inp
4517 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal/boundary.inp
4518 
4519 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
4520 of 100. To try other Reynolds numbers, change it here. This file
4521 also specifies the sphere wall temperature as the same as the
4522 freestream temperature.
4523 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal/physics.inp
4524 
4525 \b sphere.stl : the filename "sphere.stl" \b must match
4526 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4527 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl
4528 
4529 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4530 and run the following code in the run directory.
4531 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal/aux/init.c
4532 
4533 Output:
4534 -------
4535 
4536 Note that \b iproc is set to
4537 
4538  8 4 4
4539 
4540 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
4541 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
4542 this example should be run with 128 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4543 
4544 After running the code, there should be one output file
4545 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
4546 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4547 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4548 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4549 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4550 are available to convert the binary output file:
4551 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4552  Tecplot file.
4553 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4554  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4555 
4556 The following figure shows the flow (pressure and streamlines) at \f$Re_D=100\f$:
4557 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphereIsothermal_ReD100.png
4558 
4559 In addition to the main solution, the code also writes out a file with the aerodynamic
4560 forces on the immersed body. This file is called \a surface.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite
4561 is "yes") or \a surface_nnnnn.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite is "no", "nnnnn" is a numerical
4562 index) (in this example, the file \b surface.dat is written out). This is an ASCII file in
4563 the Tecplot format, where the immersed body and the forces on it are represented using the
4564 "FETRIANGLE" type. The following image shows the surface pressure and temperature
4565 on the sphere (front-view):
4566 @image html IBSurface_3DNavStokSphereIsothermal_Pressure.png
4567 @image html IBSurface_3DNavStokSphereIsothermal_Temperature.png
4568 
4569 Expected screen output:
4570 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal/output.log
4571 
4572 \page ns3d_sphere_steady_incompressible_viscous_isothermal_warm Steady, incompressible, viscous flow around an isothermal warm sphere
4573 
4574 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere
4575 
4576 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4577 
4578 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the sphere defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2] X [-2,2],
4579  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4580 
4581 Geometry: A sphere of radius 0.5 centered at (0,0)
4582  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl)
4583 
4584 The following image shows the sphere:
4585 @image html Surface3D_Sphere.png
4586 
4587 The following images shows the grid and the sphere:
4588 @image html Domain3D_Sphere1.png
4589 @image html Domain3D_Sphere2.png
4590 
4591 Boundary conditions:
4592  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4593  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4594  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4595  + zmin and zmax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4596  + The immersed body wall is specified as isothermal (#_IB_ISOTHERMAL_)
4597  with specified wall temperature \f$T_{\rm wall} = 2/\gamma\f$
4598  (twice the freestream temperature).
4599 
4600 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4601 
4602 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4603  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4604  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4605  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4606  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re)
4607  (\b Note: since the diameter of the sphere is 1.0, the diameter-based Reynolds number
4608  is the same as the specified Reynolds number \f$Re_D = Re = 100\f$).
4609 
4610 Numerical Method:
4611  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4612  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4613  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4614  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4615 
4616 Input files required:
4617 ---------------------
4618 
4619 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere/
4620 
4621 \b solver.inp
4622 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere/solver.inp
4623 
4624 \b boundary.inp
4625 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere/boundary.inp
4626 
4627 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
4628 of 100. To try other Reynolds numbers, change it here. This file
4629 also specifies the sphere wall temperature that is twice the freestream
4630 temperature.
4631 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere/physics.inp
4632 
4633 \b sphere.stl : the filename "sphere.stl" \b must match
4634 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4635 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl
4636 
4637 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4638 and run the following code in the run directory.
4639 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere/aux/init.c
4640 
4641 Output:
4642 -------
4643 
4644 Note that \b iproc is set to
4645 
4646  8 4 4
4647 
4648 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
4649 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
4650 this example should be run with 128 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4651 
4652 After running the code, there should be one output file
4653 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
4654 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4655 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4656 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4657 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4658 are available to convert the binary output file:
4659 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4660  Tecplot file.
4661 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4662  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4663 
4664 In addition to the main solution, the code also writes out a file with the aerodynamic
4665 forces on the immersed body. This file is called \a surface.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite
4666 is "yes") or \a surface_nnnnn.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite is "no", "nnnnn" is a numerical
4667 index) (in this example, the file \b surface.dat is written out). This is an ASCII file in
4668 the Tecplot format, where the immersed body and the forces on it are represented using the
4669 "FETRIANGLE" type.
4670 
4671 The following figure shows the flow (pressure and velocity vectors) at \f$Re_D=100\f$
4672 (A 2D x-y slice through the middle of the domain and the sphere surface are shown):
4673 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphereIsothermal_ReD100_WarmSphere.png
4674 
4675 The following figure shows the temperature:
4676 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphereIsothermal_ReD100_T_WarmSphere.png
4677 
4678 Expected screen output:
4679 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_Isothermal_WarmSphere/output.log
4680 
4681 \page ns3d_sphere_unsteady_compressible_viscous_adiabatic Unsteady, compressible, viscous flow around an adiabatic sphere
4682 
4683 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic
4684 
4685 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4686 
4687 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the sphere defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2] X [-2,2],
4688  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4689 
4690 Geometry: A sphere of radius 0.5 centered at (0,0)
4691  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl)
4692 
4693 The following image shows the sphere:
4694 @image html Surface3D_Sphere.png
4695 
4696 The following images shows the grid and the sphere:
4697 @image html Domain3D_Sphere1.png
4698 @image html Domain3D_Sphere2.png
4699 
4700 Boundary conditions:
4701  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4702  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4703  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4704  + zmin and zmax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4705  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
4706  (this is the default).
4707 
4708 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.8, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4709 
4710 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4711  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4712  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.8\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4713  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4714  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 1000000\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re)
4715  (\b Note: since the diameter of the sphere is 1.0, the diameter-based Reynolds number
4716  is the same as the specified Reynolds number \f$Re_D = Re = 1000000\f$).
4717 
4718 Numerical Method:
4719  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4720  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4721  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4722  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4723 
4724 Input files required:
4725 ---------------------
4726 
4727 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic/
4728 
4729 \b solver.inp
4730 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic/solver.inp
4731 
4732 \b boundary.inp
4733 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic/boundary.inp
4734 
4735 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
4736 of 1,000,000. To try other Reynolds numbers, change it here.
4737 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic/physics.inp
4738 
4739 \b sphere.stl : the filename "sphere.stl" \b must match
4740 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4741 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl
4742 
4743 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4744 and run the following code in the run directory.
4745 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic/aux/init.c
4746 
4747 Output:
4748 -------
4749 
4750 Note that \b iproc is set to
4751 
4752  8 4 4
4753 
4754 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
4755 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
4756 this example should be run with 128 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4757 
4758 After running the code, there should be 101 output files
4759 \b op_nnnnn.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp.
4760 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4761 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4762 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4763 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4764 are available to convert the binary output file:
4765 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4766  Tecplot file.
4767 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4768  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4769 
4770 In addition to the main solution, the code also writes out a file with the aerodynamic
4771 forces on the immersed body. This file is called \a surface_nnnnn.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite
4772 is "no") or \a surface.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite is "yes") (in this example, the files
4773 \b surface_nnnnn.dat are written out). This is an ASCII file in
4774 the Tecplot format, where the immersed body and the forces on it are represented using the
4775 "FETRIANGLE" type.
4776 
4777 The following visualizations were generated using these solution files.
4778  + Pressure and velocity vector on a 2D x-y plane:
4779 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphere_ReD1mil_2Dflow.gif
4780  + Streamlines colored by velocity magnitude and sphere
4781  surface colored by temperature:
4782 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphere_ReD1mil_3Dflow.gif
4783 
4784 Expected screen output:
4785 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Adiabatic/output.log
4786 
4787 \page ns3d_sphere_unsteady_compressible_viscous_isothermal Unsteady, compressible, viscous flow around an isothermal sphere
4788 
4789 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal
4790 
4791 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
4792 
4793 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the sphere defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2] X [-2,2],
4794  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
4795 
4796 Geometry: A sphere of radius 0.5 centered at (0,0)
4797  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl)
4798 
4799 The following image shows the sphere:
4800 @image html Surface3D_Sphere.png
4801 
4802 The following images shows the grid and the sphere:
4803 @image html Domain3D_Sphere1.png
4804 @image html Domain3D_Sphere2.png
4805 
4806 Boundary conditions:
4807  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
4808  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
4809  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4810  + zmin and zmax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
4811  + The immersed body wall is specified as isothermal (#_IB_ISOTHERMAL_)
4812  with surface temperature \f$T_{\rm wall}=1/\gamma\f$.
4813 
4814 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.8, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
4815 
4816 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
4817  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
4818  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.8\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
4819  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
4820  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 1000000\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re)
4821  (\b Note: since the diameter of the sphere is 1.0, the diameter-based Reynolds number
4822  is the same as the specified Reynolds number \f$Re_D = Re = 1000000\f$).
4823 
4824 Numerical Method:
4825  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
4826  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
4827  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
4828  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4829 
4830 Input files required:
4831 ---------------------
4832 
4833 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal/
4834 
4835 \b solver.inp
4836 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal/solver.inp
4837 
4838 \b boundary.inp
4839 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal/boundary.inp
4840 
4841 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
4842 of 1,000,000. To try other Reynolds numbers, change it here.
4843 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal/physics.inp
4844 
4845 \b sphere.stl : the filename "sphere.stl" \b must match
4846 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
4847 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/sphere.stl
4848 
4849 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
4850 and run the following code in the run directory.
4851 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal/aux/init.c
4852 
4853 Output:
4854 -------
4855 
4856 Note that \b iproc is set to
4857 
4858  8 4 4
4859 
4860 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
4861 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
4862 this example should be run with 128 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
4863 
4864 After running the code, there should be 101 output files
4865 \b op_nnnnn.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp.
4866 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
4867 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
4868 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
4869 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following two codes
4870 are available to convert the binary output file:
4871 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToTecplot.c - convert binary output file to
4872  Tecplot file.
4873 + \b hypar/Extras/BinaryToText.c - convert binary output file to
4874  an ASCII text file (to visualize in, for example, MATLAB).
4875 
4876 In addition to the main solution, the code also writes out a file with the aerodynamic
4877 forces on the immersed body. This file is called \a surface_nnnnn.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite
4878 is "no") or \a surface.dat (if #HyPar::op_overwrite is "yes") (in this example, the files
4879 \b surface_nnnnn.dat are written out). This is an ASCII file in
4880 the Tecplot format, where the immersed body and the forces on it are represented using the
4881 "FETRIANGLE" type.
4882 
4883 The following visualizations were generated using these solution files.
4884  + Pressure and velocity vector on a 2D x-y plane and sphere surface:
4885 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphere_ReD1mil_P_and_V.gif
4886  + Temperature on a 2D x-y plane and sphere surface:
4887 @image html Solution_3DNavStokSphere_ReD1mil_T.gif
4888 
4889 Expected screen output:
4890 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/Sphere/Unsteady_Viscous_Compressible_Isothermal/output.log
4891 
4892 \page md_examples Multidomain Examples
4893 HyPar has the capability to run ensemble simulations on multiple domains that
4894 of varying sizes and initial solution using the same discretization methods,
4895 time step sizes, final time, physics parameters, and boundary conditions. The following examples
4896 demonstrate this functionality:
4897 
4898 \subpage md_linadv_1d_sine\n
4899 \subpage md_euler2d_vortex
4900 
4901 Other examples can also be run with this feature; the modifications needed are as follows:
4902  + Need to have an input file \b simulation.inp that specifies the number of
4903  simulations.
4904  + Modify the code to generate the intial solution (and exact solution, if available)
4905  to write out initial solution files for each simulation with the filenames
4906  properly indexed, i.e., \b initial_<n>.inp, where n = 0, 1, ...,
4907  number of simulations-1.
4908  + Modify \a size and \a iproc in \b solver.inp to specify the grid dimensions
4909  and MPI rank distribution for each simulation.
4910  + Note that multiple output files will be written, one set for each simulation.
4911 
4912 \page md_linadv_1d_sine 1D Linear Advection - Sine Wave - Ensemble Simulation
4913 
4914 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble
4915  (This directory contains all the input files needed
4916  to run this case.)
4917 
4918 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
4919 
4920 References:
4921  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
4922  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
4923  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
4924 
4925 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
4926  boundary conditions
4927 
4928 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
4929 
4930 Ensemble Runs: 4 simulations on grids with 40, 80, 160, and 320 points.
4931 
4932 Numerical Method:
4933  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
4934  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
4935 
4936 Input files required:
4937 ---------------------
4938 
4939 \b simulation.inp
4940 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/simulation.inp
4941 
4942 \b solver.inp
4943 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/solver.inp
4944 
4945 \b boundary.inp
4946 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/boundary.inp
4947 
4948 \b physics.inp
4949 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/physics.inp
4950 
4951 To generate \b initial_<n>.inp (initial solution) and
4952 \b exact_<n>.inp (exact solution), compile and run the
4953 following code in the run directory.
4954 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/aux/init.c
4955 The index \a n is the simulation index (0, ..., 3 in
4956 this case).
4957 
4958 Output:
4959 -------
4960 After running the code, there should be 24 output
4961 files \b op_<n>_00000.dat, ... \b op_<n>_00005.dat, with
4962 6 files for each of the 4 simulations in the set;
4963 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
4964 is the solution at \f$t=1\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
4965 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
4966 for solutions at each output time. All the files are ASCII
4967 text (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a text in \b solver.inp).
4968 In these files, the first column is grid index, the second column
4969 is x-coordinate, and the third column is the solution.
4970 
4971 Solutions for each simulation: The following figure is obtained
4972 by plotting \a op_<n>_00005.dat (n=0,1,2,3):
4973 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSine_Ensemble.png
4974 
4975 Since the exact solution is available at the final time,
4976 the errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
4977 as well as \b errors_<n>.dat. The errors for each of the
4978 simulation are as follows:
4979 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/errors_0.dat \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/errors_1.dat \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/errors_2.dat \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/errors_3.dat
4980 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
4981 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
4982 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
4983 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
4984 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
4985 and cleaning up),
4986 and total wall time.
4987 
4988 \b Note: the errors above show 5th order convergence with grid size,
4989 as expected.
4990 
4991 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
4992 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
4993 as the file \b conservation_<n>.dat:
4994 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/conservation_0.dat \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/conservation_1.dat \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/conservation_2.dat \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/conservation_3.dat
4995 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
4996 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
4997 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
4998 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
4999 
5000 Expected screen output:
5001 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_Ensemble/output.log \page md_euler2d_vortex 2D Euler Equations - Isentropic Vortex Convection - Ensemble Simulation
5002 
5003 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble
5004  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5005  to run this case.)
5006 
5007 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
5008  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
5009  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
5010  equations are solved.)
5011 
5012 Reference: C.-W. Shu, "Essentially Non-oscillatory and Weighted Essentially
5013  Non-oscillatory Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
5014  ICASE Report 97-65, 1997
5015 
5016 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5017  boundary conditions.
5018 
5019 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
5020 \f{equation}{
5021  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.1,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
5022 \f}
5023 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
5024 \f{align}{
5025 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
5026 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
5027 \f}
5028 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
5029 
5030 Ensemble Runs: 4 simulations on grids with (128,16), (64,32), (32,64), and (16,128) points.
5031 
5032 Numerical method:
5033  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
5034  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
5035 
5036 Input files required:
5037 ---------------------
5038
