5039 \b simulation.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/simulation.inp \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/physics.inp
5040 
5041 To generate \b initial_<n>.inp (initial solution) and \b exact_<n>.inp
5042 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
5043 directory.
5044 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/aux/exact.c
5045 The index \a n is the simulation index (0, ..., 3 in
5046 this case).
5047 
5048 Output:
5049 -------
5050 Note that \b iproc for each simulation are specified as:
5051 
5052  8 1
5053  4 2
5054  2 4
5055  1 8
5056 
5057 in \b solver.inp Thus, this example should be run
5058 with 8 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
5059 
5060 After running the code, there should be 44 output
5061 files \b op_<n>_00000.dat, \b op_<n>_00001.dat, ... \b op_<n>_00010.dat,
5062 with 11 files for each of the 4 simulations in the set;
5063 the first one is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and the final one
5064 is the solution at \f$t=20\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
5065 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, separate files are written
5066 for solutions at each output time.
5067 
5068 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
5069 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
5070 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
5071 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
5072 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
5073 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
5074 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
5075 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
5076 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
5077 MATLAB for example).
5078 
5079 The following animation shows the density contours as the vortex
5080 convects over the domain, for each of the 4 simulations:
5081 @image html Solution_md_2DNavStokVortex_0.gif
5082 @image html Solution_md_2DNavStokVortex_1.gif
5083 @image html Solution_md_2DNavStokVortex_2.gif
5084 @image html Solution_md_2DNavStokVortex_3.gif
5085 
5086 Since the exact solution is available at the final time, the numerical
5087 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
5088 as well as \b errors_<n>.dat:
5089 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/errors_0.dat \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/errors_1.dat \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/errors_2.dat \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/errors_3.dat
5090 The numbers for each simulation are: number of grid points in each dimension
5091 (#HyPar::dim_global),
5092 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5093 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5094 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
5095 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
5096 and cleaning up),
5097 and total wall time.
5098 
5099 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
5100 the code checks for conservation error and prints it to screen, as well
5101 as the file \b conservation_<n>.dat:
5102 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/conservation_0.dat \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/conservation_1.dat \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/conservation_2.dat \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/conservation_3.dat
5103 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
5104 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5105 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5106 and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError) of each component.
5107 
5108 Expected screen output:
5109 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_Ensemble/output.log \page sg_examples Sparse Grids Examples
5110 The following are some examples are simulated using the <B>sparse grids</B>
5111 method. Familiarity with the sparse grids approach (specifically the combination
5112 technique approach) is assumed.
5113 
5114 \subpage sg_linear_adv_sinewave \n
5115 \subpage sg_linear_adv_2d_sine_varyingadv
5116 
5117 \subpage sg_euler2d_density_sinewave\n
5118 \subpage sg_euler2d_vortconv\n
5119 \subpage sg_euler2d_bubble
5120 
5121 Any other simulation can also be run with the sparse grids method (as long as
5122 the number of spatial dimensions is greater than 1); only the following is needed:
5123  + Input file \b sparse_grids.inp that specifies parameters related to the sparse
5124  grids method.
5125 
5126 As for the output, instead of \b op*.*, the full grid solution will be written
5127 to \b op_fg*.*, and it will be in the same format/structure as the op*.* files.
5128 If specified in the inputs, the sparse grid solution files will also be
5129 written to \b op_sg_<n>*.*.
5130 
5131 \b Note: Sparse grids work well with smooth, linear simulations. Adapting them
5132 for hyperbolic simulations with shocks and discontinuities is an area of active
5133 research.
5134 
5135 \page sg_linear_adv_sinewave 2D Linear Advection - Sine Wave
5136 
5137 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids
5138  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5139  to run this case.)
5140 
5141 Governing equations: 2D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
5142 
5143 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5144  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
5145 
5146 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\cos\left(2\pi y\right)\f$\n
5147 Exact solution: \f$u\left(x,y,t\right) = u_0\left(x-a_xt,y-a_yt\right)\f$.
5148 
5149 Numerical Method:
5150  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
5151  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
5152 
5153 Input files required:
5154 ---------------------
5155 
5156 \b sparse_grids.inp
5157 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/sparse_grids.inp
5158 
5159 \b Note: The remaining files are the same as what would be
5160 required for a conventional (non-sparse-grids) simulation.
5161 
5162 \b solver.inp
5163 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/solver.inp
5164 
5165 \b boundary.inp
5166 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/boundary.inp
5167 
5168 \b physics.inp (specifies \f$a_x\f$ and \f$a_y\f$)
5169 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/physics.inp
5170 
5171 To generate \b initial.inp and \b exact.inp, compile and run
5172 the following code in the run directory. (It is the same file
5173 as the one used in running a conventional non-sparse-grids
5174 simulation).
5175 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/aux/exact.c
5176 
5177 Output:
5178 -------
5179 Note that \b iproc does \b not need to be set for simulations
5180 using sparse grids. HyPar will automatically calculate the load
5181 balanced processor distribution for each sparse grid. If too
5182 many processors are specified, then it will return an error.
5183 
5184 After running the code, there should be the following output
5185 files:
5186 
5187  + op_fg_00000.dat, ..., op_fg_00010.dat: these contain the full
5188  grid solution at \f$t=0, ..., 1\f$.
5189  + op_sg_<n>_00000.dat, ..., op_sg_<n>_00010.dat: these contain
5190  the solution on each of the sparse grids in the combination
5191  technique. These are written out because \b write_sg_solutions
5192  is set to \b yes in \b sparse_grids.inp
5193  (SparseGridsSimulation::m_write_sg_solutions).
5194 
5195 
5196 Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp,
5197 separate files are written for solutions at each output time.
5198 
5199 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
5200 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
5201 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
5202 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
5203 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
5204 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
5205 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
5206 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
5207 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
5208 MATLAB for example).
5209 
5210 The following animation was generated from the full grid solution files
5211 that were computed by using the combination technique on the sparse grids:
5212 @image html Solution_SG_full_2DLinearAdvSineWave.gif
5213 
5214 The following animations show the solution on some of the sparse grids
5215 in the combination technique. The simulation was actually carried out on
5216 these grids. Note the different grid sizes.
5217 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSineWave_00.gif
5218 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSineWave_02.gif
5219 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSineWave_04.gif
5220 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSineWave_06.gif
5221 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSineWave_08.gif
5222 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSineWave_10.gif
5223 
5224 Since the exact solution is available at the final time, the numerical
5225 errors are calculated for the recombined full grid solution and reported
5226 on screen (see below) as well as \b errors_fg.dat:
5227 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_fg.dat
5228 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
5229 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5230 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5231 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
5232 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
5233 and cleaning up),
5234 and total wall time.
5235 
5236 Since \b write_sg_errors is set to to \b yes in \b sparse_grids.inp,
5237 (SparseGridsSimulation::m_print_sg_errors), the errors are also
5238 calculated and reported (on screen and in the files \b errors_<n>.dat )
5239 for each of the sparse grids. Following are the errors corresponding
5240 to the sparse grids whose solutions are shown above.
5241 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_00.dat
5242 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_02.dat
5243 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_04.dat
5244 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_06.dat
5245 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_08.dat
5246 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/errors_10.dat
5247 
5248 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
5249 the code checks for conservation errors for each of the sparse grids
5250 and prints it to screen, as well as the files \b conservation_<n>.dat:
5251 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/conservation_00.dat
5252 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/conservation_02.dat
5253 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/conservation_04.dat
5254 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/conservation_06.dat
5255 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/conservation_08.dat
5256 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/conservation_10.dat
5257 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
5258 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5259 time step size (#HyPar::dt), and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
5260 
5261 Expected screen output:
5262 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_SparseGrids/output.log
5263 
5264 \page sg_linear_adv_2d_sine_varyingadv 2D Linear Advection - Sine Wave with Spatially-Varying Advection Speed
5265 
5266 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids
5267  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5268  to run this case.)
5269 
5270 Governing equations: 2D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
5271 
5272 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5273  boundary conditions on all boundaries.
5274 
5275 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,y,0\right) = u_0\left(x,y\right)= \cos\left(4\pi y\right)\f$\n
5276 
5277 Advection speed: \f$a_x\left(x,y\right) = \sin\left(4\pi y\right)\f$, \f$a_y\left(x,y\right) = -\cos\left(4\pi x\right)\f$
5278 
5279 Numerical Method:
5280  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
5281  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
5282 
5283 Input files required:
5284 ---------------------
5285 
5286 \b sparse_grids.inp
5287 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/sparse_grids.inp
5288 
5289 \b Note: The remaining files are the same as what would be
5290 required for a conventional (non-sparse-grids) simulation.
5291 
5292 \b solver.inp
5293 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/solver.inp
5294 
5295 \b boundary.inp
5296 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/boundary.inp
5297 
5298 \b physics.inp (specifies filename for advection field)
5299 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/physics.inp
5300 \b Note: Do not include the ".inp" extension in the filename above.
5301 
5302 To generate \b initial.inp and \b advection.inp, compile and run the
5303 following code in the run directory.
5304 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/aux/init.c
5305 
5306 Output:
5307 -------
5308 Note that \b iproc does \b not need to be set for simulations
5309 using sparse grids. HyPar will automatically calculate the load
5310 balanced processor distribution for each sparse grid. If too
5311 many processors are specified, then it will return an error.
5312 
5313 After running the code, there should be the following output
5314 files:
5315 
5316  + op_fg_00000.dat, ..., op_fg_00020.dat: these contain the full
5317  grid solution at \f$t=0, ..., 4\f$.
5318  + op_sg_<n>_00000.dat, ..., op_sg_<n>_00020.dat: these contain
5319  the solution on each of the sparse grids in the combination
5320  technique. These are written out because \b write_sg_solutions
5321  is set to \b yes in \b sparse_grids.inp
5322  (SparseGridsSimulation::m_write_sg_solutions).
5323 
5324 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
5325 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
5326 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
5327 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
5328 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
5329 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
5330 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the final column is the
5331 solution. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
5332 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
5333 MATLAB for example).
5334 
5335 The following animation was generated from the full grid solution files
5336 that were computed by using the combination technique on the sparse grids:
5337 @image html Solution_SG_full_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv.gif
5338 
5339 The following animations show the solution on some of the sparse grids
5340 in the combination technique. The simulation was actually carried out on
5341 these grids. Note the different grid sizes.
5342 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_0.gif
5343 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_2.gif
5344 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_4.gif
5345 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_6.gif
5346 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_8.gif
5347 
5348 In addition to the usual output files, the linear advection physics
5349 module writes out the following files:
5350 + \b advection_field_<n>_00000.dat, ..., \b advection_field_<n>_00020.dat:
5351  These files
5352  share the same format as the solution output files \b op_*.dat
5353  and contains the advection field \f$a_x\left(x,y\right), a_y\left(x,y\right)\f$.
5354 
5355 The following figure shows the vector plot of the velocity field on
5356 some of the sparse grids:
5357 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_0.png
5358 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_2.png
5359 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_4.png
5360 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_6.png
5361 @image html Solution_SG_sg_2DLinearAdvSine_VaryingAdv_8.png
5362 
5363 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
5364 the code checks for conservation errors for each of the sparse grids
5365 and prints it to screen, as well as the files \b conservation_<n>.dat:
5366 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/conservation_0.dat
5367 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/conservation_2.dat
5368 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/conservation_4.dat
5369 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/conservation_6.dat
5370 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/conservation_8.dat
5371 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
5372 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5373 time step size (#HyPar::dt), and conservation error (#HyPar::ConservationError).
5374 
5375 Expected screen output:
5376 \include 2D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_NonConstantAdvection_SparseGrids/output.log
5377 
5378 \page sg_euler2d_density_sinewave 2D Euler Equations - Density Sine Wave
5379 
5380 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids
5381  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5382  to run this case.)
5383 
5384 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
5385  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
5386  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
5387  equations are solved.)
5388 
5389 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5390  boundary conditions.
5391 
5392 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
5393 \f{equation}{
5394  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 1,\ v_\infty = 1,\ p_\infty = \frac{1}{\gamma}
5395 \f}
5396 and the density wave is
5397 \f{align}{
5398 \rho = \rho_\infty + \frac{1}{10} \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\cos\left(2\pi y\right)
5399 \f}
5400 
5401 Numerical method:
5402  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order compact upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind())
5403  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
5404 
5405 Input files required:
5406 ---------------------
5407 
5408 \b sparse_grids.inp
5409 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/sparse_grids.inp
5410 
5411 \b Note: The remaining files are the same as what would be
5412 required for a conventional (non-sparse-grids) simulation.
5413 
5414 \b solver.inp
5415 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/solver.inp
5416 
5417 \b boundary.inp
5418 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/boundary.inp
5419 
5420 \b physics.inp
5421 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/physics.inp
5422 
5423 \b lusolver.inp
5424 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/lusolver.inp
5425 
5426 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp
5427 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
5428 directory. (It is the same file as the one used in running a
5429 conventional non-sparse-grids simulation).
5430 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/aux/exact.c
5431 
5432 Output:
5433 -------
5434 Note that \b iproc does \b not need to be set for simulations
5435 using sparse grids. HyPar will automatically calculate the load
5436 balanced processor distribution for each sparse grid. If too
5437 many processors are specified, then it will return an error.
5438 
5439 After running the code, there should be the following output
5440 files:
5441  + op_fg_00000.dat, ..., op_fg_00010.dat: these contain the full
5442  grid solution at \f$t=0, ..., 1\f$.
5443 
5444 Since \b write_sg_solutions is set to \b no in \b sparse_grids.inp
5445 (SparseGridsSimulation::m_write_sg_solutions), sparse grid solution
5446 files are not written out.
5447 
5448 Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp,
5449 separate files are written for solutions at each output time.
5450 
5451 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
5452 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
5453 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
5454 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
5455 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
5456 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
5457 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
5458 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
5459 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
5460 MATLAB for example).
5461 
5462 The following animation shows the density contours as the vortex
5463 convects over the domain:,
5464 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokDensityWave.gif
5465 
5466 Since the exact solution is available at the final time, the numerical
5467 errors are calculated for the recombined full grid solution and reported
5468 on screen (see below) as well as \b errors_fg.dat:
5469 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/errors_fg.dat
5470 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
5471 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5472 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5473 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
5474 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
5475 and cleaning up),
5476 and total wall time.
5477 
5478 Since \b write_sg_errors is set to to \b no in \b sparse_grids.inp
5479 (SparseGridsSimulation::m_print_sg_errors),
5480 the errors for each of the sparse grids are not computed or reported.
5481 
5482 Expected screen output:
5483 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/DensitySineWave_SparseGrids/output.log
5484 
5485 \page sg_euler2d_vortconv 2D Euler Equations - Isentropic Vortex Convection
5486 
5487 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids
5488  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5489  to run this case.)
5490 
5491 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
5492  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
5493  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
5494  equations are solved.)
5495 
5496 Reference: C.-W. Shu, "Essentially Non-oscillatory and Weighted Essentially
5497  Non-oscillatory Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
5498  ICASE Report 97-65, 1997
5499 
5500 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5501  boundary conditions.
5502 
5503 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
5504 \f{equation}{
5505  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.1,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
5506 \f}
5507 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
5508 \f{align}{
5509 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
5510 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
5511 \f}
5512 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
5513 
5514 Numerical method:
5515  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
5516  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
5517 
5518 Input files required:
5519 ---------------------
5520 
5521 \b sparse_grids.inp
5522 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/sparse_grids.inp
5523 
5524 \b Note: The remaining files are the same as what would be
5525 required for a conventional (non-sparse-grids) simulation.
5526 
5527 \b solver.inp
5528 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/solver.inp
5529 
5530 \b boundary.inp
5531 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/boundary.inp
5532 
5533 \b physics.inp
5534 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/physics.inp
5535 
5536 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp
5537 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
5538 directory. (It is the same file as the one used in running a
5539 conventional non-sparse-grids simulation).
5540 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/aux/exact.c
5541 
5542 Output:
5543 -------
5544 Note that \b iproc does \b not need to be set for simulations
5545 using sparse grids. HyPar will automatically calculate the load
5546 balanced processor distribution for each sparse grid. If too
5547 many processors are specified, then it will return an error.
5548 
5549 After running the code, there should be the following output
5550 files:
5551 
5552  + op_fg_00000.dat, ..., op_fg_00010.dat: these contain the full
5553  grid solution at \f$t=0, ..., 20\f$.
5554  + op_sg_<n>_00000.dat, ..., op_sg_<n>_00010.dat: these contain
5555  the solution on each of the sparse grids in the combination
5556  technique. These are written out because \b write_sg_solutions
5557  is set to \b yes in \b sparse_grids.inp
5558  (SparseGridsSimulation::m_write_sg_solutions).
5559 
5560 Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a no in \b solver.inp,
5561 separate files are written for solutions at each output time.
5562 
5563 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a tecplot2d in \b solver.inp, and
5564 thus, all the files are in a format that Tecplot (http://www.tecplot.com/)
5565 or other visualization software supporting the Tecplot format
5566 (e.g. VisIt - https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/)
5567 can read. In these files, the first two lines are the Tecplot headers,
5568 after which the data is written out as: the first two columns are grid indices,
5569 the next two columns are x and y coordinates, and the remaining columns are the
5570 solution components. #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text to get the solution
5571 files in plain text format (which can be read in and visualized in
5572 MATLAB for example).
5573 
5574 The following animation shows the density contours as the vortex
5575 convects over the domain:,
5576 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex.gif
5577 
5578 The following animations show the solution on some of the sparse grids
5579 in the combination technique. The simulation was actually carried out on
5580 these grids. Note the different grid sizes.
5581 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex_00.gif
5582 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex_02.gif
5583 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex_04.gif
5584 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex_06.gif
5585 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex_08.gif
5586 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokVortex_10.gif
5587 
5588 \b Note: Some of the coarse grid solutions look like nonsense, but they are
5589 still important constituents of the combination technique and contribute
5590 towards the full grid solution.
5591 
5592 Since the exact solution is available at the final time, the numerical
5593 errors are calculated for the recombined full grid solution and reported
5594 on screen (see below) as well as \b errors_fg.dat:
5595 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/errors_fg.dat
5596 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
5597 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5598 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5599 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
5600 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
5601 and cleaning up),
5602 and total wall time.
5603 
5604 Since \b write_sg_errors is set to to \b no in \b sparse_grids.inp
5605 (SparseGridsSimulation::m_print_sg_errors),
5606 the errors for each of the sparse grids are not computed or reported.
5607 
5608 
5609 Since #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp,
5610 the code checks for conservation errors for each of the sparse grids
5611 and prints it to screen, but does not write it to files because
5612 \b write_sg_errors is set to to \b no in \b sparse_grids.inp.
5613 
5614 Expected screen output:
5615 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_SparseGrids/output.log
5616 
5617 \page sg_euler2d_bubble 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Rising Thermal Bubble
5618 
5619 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids
5620  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5621  to run this case.)
5622 
5623 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
5624  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
5625  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
5626  equations are solved.)
5627 
5628 Reference:
5629  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
5630  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
5631  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
5632  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
5633  (Section 3.2).
5634 
5635 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 1000\,m\f$,
5636  "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions on all sides.
5637 
5638 Initial solution: See references above.
5639 
5640 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
5641  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
5642  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
5643  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
5644  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
5645  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
5646  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
5647 
5648 Numerical method:
5649  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
5650  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
5651 
5652 Input files required:
5653 ---------------------
5654 
5655 \b sparse_grids.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/sparse_grids.inp \b Note: The remaining files are the same as what would be
5656 required for a conventional (non-sparse-grids) simulation.
5657 
5658 \b solver.inp
5659 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/solver.inp
5660 
5661 \b boundary.inp
5662 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/boundary.inp
5663 
5664 \b physics.inp
5665 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/physics.inp
5666 
5667 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
5668 and run the following code in the run directory.
5669 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/aux/init.c
5670 
5671 Output:
5672 -------
5673 Note that \b iproc does \b not need to be set for simulations
5674 using sparse grids. HyPar will automatically calculate the load
5675 balanced processor distribution for each sparse grid. If too
5676 many processors are specified, then it will return an error.
5677 
5678 After running the code, there should be the following output
5679 files:
5680  + op_fg_00000.dat, ..., op_fg_00030.dat: these contain the full
5681  grid solution at \f$t=0, ..., 300\f$.
5682 
5683 Since \b write_sg_solutions is set to \b no in \b sparse_grids.inp
5684 (SparseGridsSimulation::m_write_sg_solutions), sparse grid solution
5685 files are not written out.
5686 
5687 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
5688 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
5689 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
5690 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
5691 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
5692 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
5693 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
5694 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
5695 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
5696 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
5697 a tecplot2d or text file.
5698 (compile and run it in the run directory):
5699 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/aux/PostProcess.c
5700 
5701 The following animation shows the potential temperature perturbation.
5702 It was plotted using VisIt
5703 (https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/) with
5704 tecplot2d format chosen in the above postprocessing code.
5705 @image html Solution_SG_2DNavStokRTB.gif
5706 
5707 Expected screen output:
5708 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_SparseGrids/output.log \page librom_examples libROM Examples
5709 
5710 The following are some examples that use the reduced-order modeling capabilities
5711 implemented in the \b libROM library (https://www.librom.net/). To run them,
5712 HyPar needs to be compiled \b with \b libROM. Familiarity with using libROM and
5713 the mathematical concepts implemented in it is assumed.
5714 
5715 \b Note:
5716 + In general, any other example or simulation can use the capabilities of libROM
5717  by providing the libROM-specific input file (librom.inp).
5718 + If HyPar is not compiled with libROM, these examples will run as a regular
5719  HyPar simulation.
5720 
5721 These examples may come with a Python script to plot the solutions from the binary
5722 solution file. This script will need the environment variable
5723 \b HYPAR_DIR (/path/to/hypar) to be defined, so make sure this variable exists.
5724 
5725 Dynamic Mode Decomposition
5726 ==========================
5727 
5728 Training Examples
5729 -----------------
5730 
5731 The following examples demonstrate training a #DMDROMObject using the solutions
5732 from a PDE simulation. The same procedure (i.e. providing the libROM input file
5733 \b librom.inp with the appropriate inputs) can be used with any other simulation.\n \n \subpage linear_adv_sine_librom_dmd_train \n
5734 \subpage linear_adv_disc_librom_dmd_train \n
5735 \subpage sod_shock_tube_librom_dmd_train \n
5736 \subpage shu_osher_librom_dmd_train \n
5737 \n
5738 \subpage euler2d_vortex_librom_dmd_train \n
5739 \subpage euler2d_riemann4_librom_dmd_train \n
5740 \subpage euler2d_rtb_librom_dmd_train \n
5741 \subpage euler2d_igwave_petsc_librom_dmd_train (Requires PETSc)\n
5742 \subpage navstok2d_ldsc_librom_dmd_train \n
5743 \subpage vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent_librom_dmd_train \n
5744 \n
5745 \subpage ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_train \n
5746 \subpage ns3d_cylinder_unsteady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_train \n
5747 \subpage ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction_librom_dmd_train \n
5748 \subpage ns3d_bubble_petsc_librom_dmd_train (Requires PETSc)\n
5749 
5750 Prediction Examples
5751 -------------------
5752 
5753 The following examples demonstrate using a trained #DMDROMObject to compute the
5754 solution instead of the discretizing the PDE in space and time. The same steps
5755 (i.e. providing the libROM input file \b librom.inp and trained DMD objects
5756 consistent with the computational domain) can be used for any other simulation.\n \n \subpage linear_adv_sine_librom_dmd_predict \n
5757 \subpage linear_adv_disc_librom_dmd_predict \n
5758 \subpage sod_shock_tube_librom_dmd_predict \n
5759 \n
5760 \subpage euler2d_vortex_librom_dmd_predict \n
5761 \subpage navstok2d_ldsc_librom_dmd_predict \n
5762 \subpage vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent_librom_dmd_predict \n
5763 \n
5764 \subpage ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_predict \n
5765 \subpage ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction_librom_dmd_predict \n
5766 
5767 \page linear_adv_sine_librom_dmd_train 1D Linear Advection - Sine Wave
5768 
5769 See \ref linear_adv_sine to familiarize yourself with this case.
5770 
5771 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train
5772  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5773  to run this case.)
5774 
5775 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
5776 
5777 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
5778 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
5779 actual HyPar solution is written at.
5780 
5781 References:
5782  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
5783  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
5784  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
5785 
5786 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5787  boundary conditions
5788 
5789 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
5790 
5791 Numerical method:
5792  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
5793  + Time integration: 3rd order SSP RK3 (TimeRK(), _RK_SSP3_)
5794 
5795 Reduced Order Modeling:
5796  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
5797  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
5798  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
5799  + Latent subspace dimension: 2 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
5800 
5801 Input files required:
5802 ---------------------
5803 
5804 \b librom.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp \b solver.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp \b lusolver.inp (optional)
5805 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/lusolver.inp \b weno.inp (optional)
5806 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
5807 
5808 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
5809 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
5810 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
5811 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
5812 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
5813 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
5814 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
5815 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
5816 
5817 Output:
5818 -------
5819 After running the code, there should be the following output
5820 files:
5821 
5822 + 11 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
5823 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
5824 
5825 + 11 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00010.bin;
5826 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
5827 
5828 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
5829 the final one is the solution at \f$t=1\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
5830 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
5831 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
5832 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
5833 
5834 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
5835 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
5836 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
5837 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
5838 
5839 The following plot shows the final solution - FOM (full-order model) refers to
5840 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution.
5841 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSinelibROM_DMD.png
5842 
5843 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
5844 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
5845 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
5846 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
5847 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
5848 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5849 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5850 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
5851 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
5852 and cleaning up), and total wall time.
5853 
5854 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
5855 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
5856 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
5857 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
5858 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
5859 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
5860 is readable by libROM.
5861 
5862 Expected screen output:
5863 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page linear_adv_disc_librom_dmd_train 1D Linear Advection - Discontinuous Waves (Time Windowed DMD)
5864 
5865 See \ref linear_adv_disc to familiarize yourself with this case.
5866 
5867 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train
5868  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5869  to run this case.)
5870 
5871 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
5872 
5873 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains time-windowed DMD objects and
5874 then predicts the solution using the DMDs at the same times that the
5875 actual HyPar solution is written at.
5876 
5877 References:
5878  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
5879  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
5880  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
5881 
5882 Domain: \f$-1 \le x \le 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
5883  boundary conditions
5884 
5885 Initial solution:
5886  \f{equation}{
5887  u\left(x,0\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{lc}
5888  \exp\left(-\log\left(2\right)\frac{\left(x+7\right)^2}{0.0009}\right) & -0.8\le x \le -0.6 \\
5889  1 & -0.4\le x \le -0.2 \\
5890  1 - \left|10\left(x-0.1\right)\right| & 0\le x \le 0.2 \\
5891  \sqrt{1-100\left(x-0.5\right)^2} & 0.4\le x \le 0.6 \\
5892  0 & {\rm otherwise}
5893  \end{array}\right.
5894  \f}
5895 
5896 Numerical Method:
5897  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
5898  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
5899 
5900 Reduced Order Modeling:
5901  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
5902  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
5903  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
5904  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
5905  + Number of samples per time window: 100 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
5906 
5907 Input files required:
5908 ---------------------
5909 
5910 \b librom.inp
5911 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
5912 
5913 \b solver.inp
5914 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
5915 
5916 \b boundary.inp
5917 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
5918 
5919 \b physics.inp
5920 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
5921 
5922 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
5923 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/lusolver.inp
5924 
5925 \b weno.inp (optional)
5926 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
5927 
5928 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
5929 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
5930 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
5931 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
5932 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
5933 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
5934 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
5935 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
5936 
5937 Output:
5938 -------
5939 After running the code, there should be the following output
5940 files:
5941 
5942 + 51 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00050.bin;
5943 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
5944 
5945 + 51 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00050.bin;
5946 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
5947 
5948 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
5949 the final one is the solution at \f$t=2\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
5950 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
5951 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
5952 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
5953 
5954 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
5955 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
5956 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
5957 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
5958 
5959 The following plot shows the final solution - FOM (full-order model) refers to
5960 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution.
5961 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvDisclibROM_DMD.png
5962 
5963 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
5964 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
5965 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
5966 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
5967 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
5968 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
5969 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
5970 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
5971 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
5972 and cleaning up), and total wall time.
5973 
5974 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
5975 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
5976 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
5977 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
5978 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
5979 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
5980 is readable by libROM.
5981 
5982 Expected screen output:
5983 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page sod_shock_tube_librom_dmd_train 1D Euler Equations - Sod Shock Tube (Time Windowed DMD)
5984 
5985 See \ref sod_shock_tube to familiarize yourself with this case.
5986 
5987 Description:
5988 -------------------
5989 
5990 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train
5991  (This directory contains all the input files needed
5992  to run this case.)
5993 
5994 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
5995 
5996 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
5997 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
5998 actual HyPar solution is written at.
5999 
6000 References:
6001  + G.A. Sod, "A survey of several finite difference methods
6002  for systems of nonlinear hyperbolic conservation laws,"
6003  J. Comput. Phys., 27, 1 (1978).
6004  + C. B. Laney, "Computational Gasdynamics", Cambridge
6005  University Press, 1998.
6006 
6007 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 1.0\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
6008  boundary conditions
6009 
6010 Initial Solution:
6011  + \f$ 0 \le x < 0.5\f$: \f$\rho = 1, u = 0, p = 1\f$
6012  + \f$ 0.5 \le x \le 1\f$: \f$\rho = 0.125, u = 0, p = 0.1\f$
6013 
6014 Numerical Method:
6015  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
6016  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
6017 
6018 Reduced Order Modeling:
6019  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6020  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6021  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6022  + Latent subspace dimension: 8 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6023  + Number of samples per time window: 40 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6024 
6025 Input files required:
6026 --------------------
6027 
6028 \b librom.inp
6029 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6030 
6031 \b solver.inp:
6032 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6033 
6034 \b boundary.inp
6035 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6036 
6037 \b physics.inp
6038 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6039 
6040 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
6041 following code in the run directory:
6042 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6043 
6044 Output:
6045 -------
6046 After running the code, there should be the following output
6047 files:
6048 
6049 + 9 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00008.bin;
6050 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6051 
6052 + 9 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00008.bin;
6053 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6054 
6055 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
6056 the final one is the solution at \f$t=2\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
6057 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
6058 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
6059 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6060 
6061 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
6062 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6063 solutions. It will plot the 3 conserved variables - density, momentum, and energy.
6064 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
6065 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
6066 
6067 The following plot shows the final solution (density) - FOM (full-order model) refers to
6068 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution.
6069 @image html Solution_1DSodShockTubeROM_DMD.png
6070 
6071 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6072 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6073 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6074 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6075 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
6076 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6077 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6078 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6079 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6080 and cleaning up), and total wall time.
6081 
6082 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
6083 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
6084 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
6085 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
6086 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
6087 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
6088 is readable by libROM.
6089 
6090 Expected screen output:
6091 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page euler2d_vortex_librom_dmd_train 2D Euler Equations - Isentropic Vortex Convection
6092 
6093 See \ref euler2d_vortex to familiarize yourself with this case.
6094 
6095 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train
6096  (This directory contains all the input files needed
6097  to run this case.)
6098 
6099 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
6100  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
6101  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
6102  equations are solved.)
6103 
6104 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6105 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6106 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6107 
6108 Reference: C.-W. Shu, "Essentially Non-oscillatory and Weighted Essentially
6109  Non-oscillatory Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
6110  ICASE Report 97-65, 1997
6111 
6112 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
6113  boundary conditions.
6114 
6115 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
6116 \f{equation}{
6117  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.1,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
6118 \f}
6119 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
6120 \f{align}{
6121 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
6122 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
6123 \f}
6124 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
6125 
6126 Numerical method:
6127  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order CRWENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCRWENO())
6128  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
6129 
6130 Reduced Order Modeling:
6131  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6132  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6133  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6134  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6135 
6136 Input files required:
6137 ---------------------
6138 
6139 \b librom.inp
6140 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6141 
6142 \b solver.inp
6143 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6144 
6145 \b boundary.inp
6146 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6147 
6148 \b physics.inp
6149 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6150 
6151 \b weno.inp (optional)
6152 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
6153 
6154 \b lusolver.inp (optional)
6155 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/lusolver.inp
6156 
6157 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp
6158 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
6159 directory.
6160 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/exact.c
6161 
6162 Output:
6163 -------
6164 Note that \b iproc is set to
6165 
6166  4 4
6167 
6168 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
6169 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
6170 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6171 
6172 After running the code, there should be the following output
6173 files:
6174 
6175 + 21 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00020.bin;
6176 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6177 
6178 + 21 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00020.bin;
6179 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6180 
6181 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
6182 the final one is the solution at \f$t=20\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
6183 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
6184 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
6185 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6186 
6187 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
6188 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6189 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d, and Tecplot/VisIt
6190 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting files.
6191 
6192 The following plot shows evolution of the density - FOM (full-order model) refers to
6193 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution, and "Diff" is
6194 their difference.
6195 @image html Solution_2DNavStokVortex_libROM_DMD.gif \b Wall \b clock \b times:
6196 - PDE solution: 5.85 seconds
6197 - DMD training time: 5.25 seconds
6198 - DMD prediction/query time: 0.28 seconds
6199 
6200 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6201 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6202 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6203 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6204 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
6205 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6206 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6207 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6208 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6209 and cleaning up),
6210 and total wall time.
6211 
6212 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
6213 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
6214 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
6215 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
6216 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
6217 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
6218 is readable by libROM.
6219 
6220 Expected screen output:
6221 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page euler2d_riemann4_librom_dmd_train 2D Euler Equations - Riemann Problem Case 4 (Time Windowed DMD)
6222 
6223 See \ref euler2d_riemann4 to familiarize yourself with this case.
6224 
6225 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train
6226  (This directory contains all the input files needed
6227  to run this case.)
6228 
6229 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
6230  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
6231  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
6232  equations are solved.)
6233 
6234 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6235 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6236 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6237 
6238 Reference:
6239  + P. Lax and X.-D. Liu, "Solution of two-dimensional Riemann
6240  problems of gas dynamics by positive schemes," SIAM J Sci
6241  Comp 19 (1998), 319–340.
6242 
6243 Domain: \f$-0.5 \le x,y \le 0.5\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
6244  boundary conditions.
6245 
6246 Initial solution: see \b Case \b 4 in the reference.
6247 
6248 Numerical method:
6249  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
6250  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
6251 
6252 Reduced Order Modeling:
6253  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6254  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6255  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6256  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6257  + Number of samples per time window: 50 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6258 
6259 Input files required:
6260 ---------------------
6261 
6262 \b librom.inp
6263 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6264 
6265 \b solver.inp
6266 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6267 
6268 \b boundary.inp
6269 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6270 
6271 \b physics.inp
6272 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6273 
6274 \b weno.inp (optional)
6275 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
6276 
6277 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
6278 following code in the run directory.
6279 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6280 
6281 Output:
6282 -------
6283 Note that \b iproc is set to
6284 
6285  4 4
6286 
6287 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
6288 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
6289 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6290 
6291 After running the code, there should be the following output
6292 files:
6293 
6294 + 11 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
6295 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6296 
6297 + 11 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00010.bin;
6298 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6299 
6300 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
6301 the final one is the solution at \f$t=0.25\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
6302 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
6303 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
6304 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6305 
6306 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
6307 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6308 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d, and Tecplot/VisIt
6309 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
6310 
6311 The following plot shows the final solution (density) - FOM (full-order model) refers to
6312 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution, and Diff
6313 is the difference between the two.
6314 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRiemann4_libROMDMD.png \b Wall \b clock \b times:
6315 - PDE solution: 111.1 seconds
6316 - DMD training time: 17.6 seconds
6317 - DMD prediction/query time: 1.4 seconds
6318 
6319 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6320 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6321 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6322 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6323 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
6324 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6325 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6326 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6327 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6328 and cleaning up),
6329 and total wall time.
6330 
6331 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
6332 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
6333 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
6334 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
6335 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
6336 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
6337 is readable by libROM.
6338 
6339 Expected screen output:
6340 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/Riemann2DCase4_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent_librom_dmd_train 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation - Two-Stream Instability (Time-Windowed DMD)
6341 
6342 See \ref vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent to familiarize yourself with this case.
6343 
6344 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train
6345  (This directory contains all the input files needed
6346  to run this case.)
6347 
6348 Governing equations: 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation (vlasov.h)
6349 
6350 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6351 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6352 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6353 
6354 Domain:
6355  + \f$0 \le x < 2\pi\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
6356  + \f$-7 \le y < 7\f$, \a "dirichlet" (#_DIRICHLET_) (\f$f = 0\f$)
6357 
6358 
6359 Initial solution:
6360 \f$f\left(x,v\right) = \frac{4}{\pi T}\left(1+\frac{1}{10}\cos\left(2k\pi\frac{x}{L}\right)\right)\left[\exp\left(-\frac{\left(v-2\right)^2}{2T}\right) + \exp\left(-\frac{\left(v+2\right)^2}{2T}\right)\right]\f$, \f$k=1,T=1,L=2\pi\f$.
6361 
6362 Self-consistent electric field is computed by solving the Poisson equation
6363 in a periodic domain using Fourier transforms. This examples *requires* HyPar
6364 to be compiled with FFTW (http://www.fftw.org/).
6365 
6366 Numerical Method:
6367  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
6368  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
6369 
6370 Reduced Order Modeling:
6371  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6372  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6373  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6374  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6375  + Number of samples per time window: 200 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6376 
6377 Input files required:
6378 ---------------------
6379 
6380 \b librom.inp
6381 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6382 
6383 \b solver.inp
6384 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6385 
6386 \b boundary.inp
6387 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6388 
6389 \b physics.inp
6390 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6391 
6392 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile and run the
6393 following code in the run directory.
6394 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6395 
6396 Output:
6397 -------
6398 Note that \b iproc is set to
6399 
6400  4 4
6401 
6402 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
6403 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
6404 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6405 
6406 After running the code, there should be the following output
6407 files:
6408 
6409 + 26 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00025.bin;
6410 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6411 
6412 + 26 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00025.bin;
6413 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6414 
6415 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
6416 the final one is the solution at \f$t=5\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
6417 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
6418 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
6419 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6420 
6421 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
6422 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6423 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d or \a text,
6424 and Tecplot/VisIt or something similar can be used to plot the resulting files.
6425 
6426 The following plot shows the evolution of the distribution function -
6427 FOM (full-order model) refers to the HyPar solution,
6428 ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution, and
6429 Diff is the difference between the two.
6430 @image html Solution_1D1VVlasov_SelfConsistentE_libROM_DMD.gif \b Wall \b clock \b times:
6431 - PDE solution: 11.34 seconds
6432 - DMD training time: 2.30 seconds
6433 - DMD prediction/query time: 0.34 seconds
6434 
6435 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6436 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6437 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6438 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6439 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
6440 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6441 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6442 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6443 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6444 and cleaning up),
6445 and total wall time.
6446 
6447 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
6448 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
6449 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
6450 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
6451 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
6452 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
6453 is readable by libROM.
6454 
6455 Expected screen output:
6456 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page navstok2d_ldsc_librom_dmd_train 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Lid-Driven Square Cavity (Time-Windowed DMD)
6457 
6458 See \ref navstok2d_ldsc to familiarize yourself with this case.
6459 
6460 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train
6461  (This directory contains all the input files needed
6462  to run this case.)
6463 
6464 Governing equations: 2D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
6465 
6466 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6467 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6468 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6469 
6470 Reference:
6471 + Erturk, E., Corke, T.C., and Gokcol, C., "Numerical Solutions of
6472  2-D Steady Incompressible Driven Cavity Flow at High Reynolds Numbers",
6473  International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids, 48, 2005,
6474  http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/fld.953.
6475 + Ghia, U., Ghia, K.N., Shin, C.T., "High-Re Solutions for Incompressible
6476  Flow using the Navier-Stokes Equations and a Multigrid Method", Journal
6477  of Computational Physics, 48, 1982, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0021-9991(82)90058-4.
6478 
6479 Note that this is an incompressible problem being solved here using the compressible
6480 Navier-Stokes equations in terms of non-dimensional flow variables. The density and
6481 pressure are taken such that the speed of sound is 1.0, and the flow velocities
6482 specified in the initial and boundary conditions correspond to a characteristic
6483 Mach number of 0.1 (thus, they are 0.1 times the values in the above reference).
6484 
6485 Domain: \f$0 \le x, y \le 1\f$
6486 
6487 Boundary conditions:
6488 + No-slip wall BC on \f$x=0,1, 0 \le y \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
6489 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
6490 + Moving no-slip wall BC on \f$y=1, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with specified
6491  wall velocity of 0.1 in the x-direction).
6492 
6493 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, p=1/\gamma\f$. The velocities are specified according to
6494 the references above, but scaled by a factor of 0.1 to ensure that the characteristic
6495 Mach number is 0.1.
6496 
6497 Other parameters:
6498  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
6499  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100, 1000, 3200\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
6500  where \f$L=1\f$ is the cavity length and width.
6501  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
6502  + \f$M_\infty = 0.1\f$ (characteristic Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
6503 
6504 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
6505 speed of sound is 1.
6506 
6507 Numerical method:
6508  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
6509  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
6510  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
6511  + Time integration: 4th order, 4-stage Runge-Kutta (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
6512 
6513 Reduced Order Modeling:
6514  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6515  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6516  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6517  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6518  + Sampling frequency: 50 (libROMInterface::m_sampling_freq)
6519  + Number of samples per time window: 200 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6520 
6521 Input files required:
6522 ---------------------
6523 
6524 \b librom.inp
6525 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6526 
6527 \b solver.inp
6528 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6529 
6530 \b boundary.inp
6531 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6532 
6533 \b physics.inp (\b Note: this file specifies \f$Re = 3200\f$,
6534 change \a Re here for other Reynolds numbers.)
6535 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6536 
6537 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
6538 and run the following code in the run directory
6539 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6540 
6541 Output:
6542 -------
6543 Note that \b iproc is set to
6544 
6545  4 4
6546 
6547 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
6548 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
6549 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6550 
6551 After running the code, there should be the following output
6552 files:
6553 
6554 + 1 output file \b op.bin;
6555 this is the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6556 
6557 + 1 output file \b op_rom.bin;
6558 this is the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6559 
6560 All the files are binary
6561 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6562 
6563 The provided Python script (\b plotStreamlines.py)
6564 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6565 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d, and Tecplot/VisIt
6566 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
6567 
6568 The following plot shows the final solution (velocity streamlines colored by
6569 the velocity magnitude) - FOM (full-order model) refers to
6570 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution, and Diff
6571 is the difference in the velocity magnitude between the two.
6572 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re3200_libROM_DMD.png \b Wall \b clock \b times:
6573 - PDE solution: 554.6 seconds
6574 - DMD training time: 58.6 seconds
6575 - DMD prediction/query time: 0.3 seconds
6576 
6577 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6578 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6579 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6580 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6581 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
6582 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6583 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6584 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6585 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6586 and cleaning up),
6587 and total wall time.
6588 
6589 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
6590 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
6591 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
6592 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
6593 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
6594 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
6595 is readable by libROM.
6596 
6597 Expected screen output:
6598 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_train 3D Navier-Stokes - Steady, incompressible, viscous flow around a cylinder (Time-Windowed DMD)
6599 
6600 See \ref ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous to familiarize yourself with this case.
6601 
6602 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train
6603 
6604 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
6605 
6606 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6607 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6608 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6609 
6610 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the cylinder defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2],
6611  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
6612 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
6613  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
6614  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
6615 
6616 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
6617  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
6618 
6619 See \ref ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous for pictures showing the domain and geometry.
6620 
6621 Boundary conditions:
6622  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
6623  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
6624  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
6625  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
6626  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
6627  (this is the default).
6628 
6629 Reference:
6630  + Taneda, S., "Experimental Investigation of the Wakes behind Cylinders and Plates at Low
6631  Reynolds Numbers," Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, Vol. 11, 302–307, 1956.
6632  + Dennis, S. C. R., Chang, G.-Z., "Numerical solutions for steady flow past a circular
6633  cylinder at Reynolds numbers up to 100", Journal of Fluid Mechanics, 42 (3), 1970,
6634  pp. 471-489.
6635 
6636 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
6637 
6638 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
6639  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
6640  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
6641  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
6642  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 10\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re) (\b Note:
6643  since the diameter of the cylinder is 2.0, the cylinder-diameter-based Reynolds number is
6644  \f$Re_D = 2Re = 20\f$.
6645 
6646 Numerical Method:
6647  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
6648  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
6649  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
6650  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
6651 
6652 Reduced Order Modeling:
6653  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6654  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6655  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
