6656  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6657  + Sampling frequency: 10 (libROMInterface::m_sampling_freq)
6658  + Number of samples per time window: 500 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6659 
6660 Input files required:
6661 ---------------------
6662 
6663 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train
6664 
6665 \b librom.inp
6666 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6667 
6668 \b solver.inp
6669 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6670 
6671 \b boundary.inp
6672 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6673 
6674 \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
6675 of 10 (corresponding to \f$Re_D\f$ of 20). To try other Reynolds
6676 numbers, change it here.
6677 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6678 
6679 \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
6680 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
6681 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
6682 
6683 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
6684 and run the following code in the run directory.
6685 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6686 
6687 Output:
6688 -------
6689 
6690 Note that \b iproc is set to
6691 
6692  8 4 1
6693 
6694 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
6695 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
6696 this example should be run with 32 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6697 
6698 Please see the original example in the "Immersed Boundaries Examples" section
6699 for a full description of the output files and how to view them. The following only
6700 contains libROM-specific comments.
6701 
6702 After running the code, there should be the following output
6703 files:
6704 
6705 + 1 output file \b op.bin;
6706 this is the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6707 
6708 + 1 output file \b op_rom.bin;
6709 this is the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6710 
6711 All the files are binary
6712 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6713 
6714 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
6715 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6716 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot3d, and Tecplot/VisIt
6717 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
6718 
6719 The following figure shows the flow at \f$Re_D=20\f$. The pressure is plotted in the overall
6720 domain, and the wake is shown by plotting the x-velocity, where it is negative.
6721 FOM (full-order model) refers to the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to
6722 the DMD solution, and Diff is the difference between the two.
6723 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_ReD020_libROM_DMD.png \b Wall \b clock \b times:
6724 - PDE solution: 3038 seconds
6725 - DMD training time: 249 seconds
6726 - DMD prediction/query time: 1.3 seconds
6727 
6728 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6729 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6730 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6731 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6732 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
6733 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6734 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6735 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6736 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6737 and cleaning up),
6738 and total wall time.
6739 
6740 Expected screen output:
6741 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page ns3d_cylinder_unsteady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_train 3D Navier-Stokes - Unsteady, incompressible, viscous flow around a cylinder with vortex shedding (Time-Windowed DMD)
6742 
6743 See \ref ns3d_cylinder_unsteady_incompressible_viscous to familiarize yourself with this case.
6744 
6745 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train
6746 
6747 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
6748 
6749 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6750 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6751 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6752 
6753 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the cylinder defined by [-4,12] X [-2,2],
6754  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
6755 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
6756  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
6757  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
6758 
6759 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
6760  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
6761 
6762 See \ref ns3d_cylinder_unsteady_incompressible_viscous for pictures show the domain and geometry.
6763 
6764 Boundary conditions:
6765  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
6766  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
6767  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
6768  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
6769  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
6770  (this is the default).
6771 
6772 Reference:
6773  + Taneda, S., Experimental Investigation of the Wakes behind Cylinders and Plates at Low
6774  Reynolds Numbers, Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, Vol. 11, 302–307, 1956.
6775 
6776 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
6777 
6778 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
6779  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
6780  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
6781  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
6782  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 50\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re) (\b Note:
6783  since the diameter of the cylinder is 2.0, the cylinder-diameter-based Reynolds number is
6784  \f$Re_D = 2Re = 100\f$.
6785 
6786 Numerical Method:
6787  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
6788  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
6789  non-conservative 2-stage (NavierStokes3DParabolicFunction())
6790  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
6791 
6792 Reduced Order Modeling:
6793  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6794  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6795  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6796  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6797  + Sampling frequency: 2 (libROMInterface::m_sampling_freq)
6798  + Number of samples per time window: 1000 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6799 
6800 Input files required:
6801 ---------------------
6802 
6803 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/
6804 
6805 \b librom.inp
6806 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6807 
6808 \b solver.inp
6809 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6810 
6811 \b boundary.inp
6812 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6813 
6814 \b physics.inp
6815 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6816 
6817 \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
6818 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
6819 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
6820 
6821 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), the following code will generate the
6822 domain with a clustered mesh and uniform horizontal flow. It will take
6823 time to develop the time-periodic vortex shedding flow from this initial solution.
6824 The following steps are recommended:
6825 - Use the code below to generate a initial solution file (initial.inp) in a separate directory,
6826  and set the \a n_iter to 50000 in that directory. Change \a op_overwrite to "yes" to avoid
6827  writing too many solution files. Run HyPar.
6828 - Use the code hypar/Extras/BinaryOPToInitialSolution.c to generate
6829  the initial solution file from the final solution of the above simulation.
6830  This code will write out a file called "solution.inp"; just rename it
6831  to "initial.inp" and place it in the directory where this simulation will
6832  be run.
6833 - Now, using this initial solution, where the time-periodic vortex shedding has developed,
6834  run this simulation with frequent solution output to visualize the vortex shedding.
6835 
6836 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6837 
6838 Output:
6839 -------
6840 
6841 Note that \b iproc is set to
6842 
6843  8 4 1
6844 
6845 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
6846 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
6847 this example should be run with 32 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6848 
6849 Please see the original example in the "Immersed Boundaries Examples" section
6850 for a full description of the output files and how to view them. The following only
6851 contains libROM-specific comments.
6852 
6853 After running the code, there should be the following output
6854 files:
6855 
6856 + 41 output file \b op_00000.bin, ..., op_00040.bin;
6857 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6858 
6859 + 41 output file \b op_rom_00000.bin, ..., op_rom_00040.bin;
6860 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6861 
6862 All the files are binary
6863 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6864 
6865 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
6866 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
6867 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot3d, and Tecplot/VisIt
6868 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
6869 
6870 The following figure shows the vortex shedding. The pressure is plotted in the overall
6871 domain, and the wake is shown by plotting the x-velocity, where it is negative.
6872 FOM (full-order model) refers to the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to
6873 the DMD solution, and Diff is the difference between the two.
6874 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_ReD100_libROM_DMD.gif \b Wall \b clock \b times:
6875 - PDE solution: 2413 seconds
6876 - DMD training time: 2113 seconds
6877 - DMD prediction/query time: 9.8 seconds
6878 
6879 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
6880 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
6881 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
6882 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
6883 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
6884 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
6885 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
6886 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
6887 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
6888 and cleaning up),
6889 and total wall time.
6890 
6891 Expected screen output:
6892 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Unsteady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page euler2d_rtb_librom_dmd_train 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Rising Thermal Bubble (Time-Windowed DMD)
6893 
6894 See \ref euler2d_rtb to familiarize yourself with this case.
6895 
6896 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train
6897  (This directory contains all the input files needed
6898  to run this case.)
6899 
6900 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
6901  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
6902  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
6903  equations are solved.)
6904 
6905 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
6906 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
6907 actual HyPar solution is written at.
6908 
6909 Reference:
6910  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
6911  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
6912  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
6913  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
6914  (Section 3.2).
6915 
6916 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 1000\,m\f$,
6917  "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions on all sides.
6918 
6919 Initial solution: See references above.
6920 
6921 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
6922  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
6923  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
6924  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
6925  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
6926  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
6927  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
6928 
6929 Numerical method:
6930  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
6931  + Time integration: SSPRK3 (TimeRK(), #_RK_SSP3_)
6932 
6933 Reduced Order Modeling:
6934  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
6935  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
6936  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
6937  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
6938  + Sampling frequency: 7 (libROMInterface::m_sampling_freq)
6939  + Number of samples per time window: 1000 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
6940 
6941 Input files required:
6942 ---------------------
6943 
6944 \b librom.inp
6945 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
6946 
6947 \b solver.inp
6948 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
6949 
6950 \b boundary.inp
6951 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
6952 
6953 \b physics.inp
6954 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
6955 
6956 \b weno.inp (optional)
6957 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
6958 
6959 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
6960 and run the following code in the run directory.
6961 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
6962 
6963 Output:
6964 -------
6965 Note that \b iproc is set to
6966 
6967  6 6
6968 
6969 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 6 processors along \a x, and 6
6970 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
6971 with 36 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
6972 
6973 After running the code, there should be the following output
6974 files:
6975 
6976 + 41 output file \b op_00000.bin, ..., \b op_00040.bin;
6977 this is the \b HyPar solutions\b.
6978 
6979 + 41 output file \b op_rom_00000.bin, ..., \b op_rom_00040.bin;
6980 this is the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
6981 
6982 All the files are binary
6983 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
6984 
6985 The binary file contains the conserved variables
6986 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
6987 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
6988 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
6989 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
6990 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
6991 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
6992 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
6993 a tecplot2d or text file.
6994 (compile and run it in the run directory):
6995 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/PostProcess.cpp
6996 
6997 The following animation shows the potential temperature for the HyPar solutions.
6998 It was plotted using VisIt
6999 (https://wci.llnl.gov/simulation/computer-codes/visit/) with
7000 tecplot2d format chosen in the above postprocessing code.
7001 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRTB_libROM_DMD_FOM.gif
7002 The following animation shows the same for the libROM solution predicted
7003 by the DMD object:
7004 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRTB_libROM_DMD_ROM.gif
7005 
7006 The provided Python script (\b plotDiff.py) computes and plots the diff
7007 of the HyPar and DMD solutions for each of the conserved variables. The
7008 following figure shows this diff at the final time for the density.
7009 @image html Solution_2DNavStokRTB_libROM_DMD_diff_density.png \b Wall \b clock \b times:
7010 - PDE solution: 1419 seconds
7011 - DMD training time: 1068 seconds
7012 - DMD prediction/query time: 2.73 seconds
7013 
7014 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
7015 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
7016 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
7017 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
7018 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
7019 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
7020 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
7021 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
7022 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
7023 and cleaning up),
7024 and total wall time.
7025 
7026 Expected screen output:
7027 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/RisingThermalBubble_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page shu_osher_librom_dmd_train 1D Euler Equations - Shu-Osher Problem (Time Windowed DMD)
7028 
7029 See \ref shu_osher to familiarize yourself with this case.
7030 
7031 Description:
7032 ------------
7033 
7034 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train
7035  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7036  to run this case. If there is a \a Run.m, run it in
7037  MATLAB to quickly set up, run, and visualize the
7038  example).
7039 
7040 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
7041 
7042 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
7043 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
7044 actual HyPar solution is written at.
7045 
7046 References:
7047  + C.-W. Shu and S. Osher, "Efficient implementation of
7048  essentially non-oscillatory schemes ,II," J. Comput.
7049  Phys., 83 (1989), pp. 32–78
7050 
7051 Domain: \f$-5 \le x \le 5\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
7052  boundary conditions
7053 
7054 Initial Solution:
7055  + \f$ -5 \le x < -4\f$: \f$\rho = 27/7, u = 4\sqrt{35}/7, p = 31/3\f$
7056  + \f$ -4 \le x \le 5\f$: \f$\rho = 1 + 0.2\sin\left(5x\right), u = 0, p = 1\f$
7057 
7058 Numerical Method:
7059  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): Characteristic-based 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENOChar())
7060  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
7061 
7062 Reduced Order Modeling:
7063  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
7064  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7065  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7066  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
7067  + Number of samples per time window: 60 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
7068 
7069 Input files required:
7070 --------------------
7071 \b librom.inp:
7072 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
7073 
7074 \b solver.inp:
7075 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
7076 
7077 \b boundary.inp
7078 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
7079 
7080 \b physics.inp
7081 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
7082 
7083 \b weno.inp (optional)
7084 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
7085 
7086 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
7087 following code in the run directory:
7088 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
7089 
7090 Output:
7091 -------
7092 After running the code, there should be the following output
7093 files:
7094 
7095 + 11 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00010.bin;
7096 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
7097 
7098 + 11 output files \b op_rom_00000.bin, \b op_rom_00001.bin, ... \b op_rom_00010.bin;
7099 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
7100 
7101 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
7102 the final one is the solution at \f$t=1.8\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
7103 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
7104 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
7105 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7106 
7107 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
7108 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
7109 solutions. It will plot the 3 conserved variables - density, momentum, and energy.
7110 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
7111 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
7112 
7113 The following plot shows the final solution (density) - FOM (full-order model) refers to
7114 the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to the DMD solution.
7115 @image html Solution_1DShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD.png
7116 
7117 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
7118 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
7119 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
7120 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
7121 The numbers are: number of grid points (#HyPar::dim_global),
7122 number of processors (#MPIVariables::iproc),
7123 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
7124 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
7125 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
7126 and cleaning up), and total wall time.
7127 
7128 By default, the code will write the trained DMD object(s) to files in a
7129 subdirectory (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname - default value is "DMD"). If the
7130 subdirectory does not exist, the code \b may \b not report an error
7131 (or give some HDF5 file-writing error); the DMD
7132 objects will not be written! If the subdirectory exists, several files
7133 will exist after the simulation is complete - they are in a format that
7134 is readable by libROM.
7135 
7136 Expected screen output:
7137 \include 1D/Euler1D/ShuOsherProblem_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction_librom_dmd_train 3D Navier-Stokes - Inviscid Shock-Cylinder Interaction (Time-Windowed DMD)
7138 
7139 See \ref ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction to familiarize yourself with this case.
7140 
7141 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train
7142 
7143 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h - by default
7144  #NavierStokes3D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
7145  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 3D Euler
7146  equations are solved.)
7147 
7148 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
7149 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
7150 actual HyPar solution is written at.
7151 
7152 Domain: \f$-2.5 \le x \le 7.5\f$, \f$-5 \le y \le 5\f$
7153 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
7154  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
7155  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
7156 
7157 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
7158  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
7159 
7160 Boundary conditions:
7161  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_ (with post-shock flow conditions)
7162  + xmax: Supersonic inflow #_SUPERSONIC_OUTFLOW_ (with pre-shock flow conditions)
7163  + ymin and ymax: Slip walls #_SLIP_WALL_
7164  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
7165  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
7166  (this is the default).
7167 
7168 Reference:
7169 + O. Boiron, G. Chiavassa, R. Donat, A high-resolution penalization method for large Mach number
7170  flows in the presence of obstacles, Computers & Fluids, 38 (2009), pp. 703-714, Section 5.1
7171 
7172 Initial solution: see reference
7173 
7174 Other parameters:
7175  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
7176 
7177 Numerical Method:
7178  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
7179  + Time integration: RK4 (TimeRK(), #_RK_44_)
7180 
7181 Reduced Order Modeling:
7182  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
7183  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7184  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7185  + Latent subspace dimension: 32 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
7186  + Number of samples per time window: 100 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
7187 
7188 Input files required:
7189 ---------------------
7190 
7191 These files are all located in: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/
7192 
7193 \b librom.inp
7194 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
7195 
7196 \b solver.inp
7197 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
7198 
7199 \b boundary.inp
7200 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
7201 
7202 \b physics.inp
7203 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
7204 
7205 \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
7206 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
7207 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
7208 
7209 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
7210 and run the following code in the run directory.
7211 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
7212 
7213 Output:
7214 -------
7215 
7216 Note that \b iproc is set to
7217 
7218  4 4 1
7219 
7220 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, 4
7221 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
7222 this example should be run with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
7223 
7224 Please see the original example in the "Immersed Boundaries Examples" section
7225 for a full description of the output files and how to view them. The following only
7226 contains libROM-specific comments.
7227 
7228 After running the code, there should be the following output
7229 files:
7230 
7231 + 11 output file \b op_00000.bin, ..., op_00010.bin;
7232 these are the \b HyPar solutions\b.
7233 
7234 + 11 output file \b op_rom_00000.bin, ..., op_rom_00010.bin;
7235 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
7236 
7237 All the files are binary
7238 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7239 
7240 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
7241 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
7242 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot3d, and Tecplot/VisIt
7243 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
7244 
7245 The following plot shows the density contours for the final solution (t=2).
7246 FOM (full-order model) refers to the HyPar solution, ROM (reduced-order model) refers to
7247 the DMD solution, and Diff is the difference between the two.
7248 @image html Solution_3DNavStokShockCyl_Density_libROM_DMD.png \b Wall \b clock \b times:
7249 - PDE solution: 815 seconds
7250 - DMD training time: 155 seconds
7251 - DMD prediction/query time: 33 seconds
7252 
7253 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
7254 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
7255 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
7256 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
7257 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
7258 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
7259 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
7260 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
7261 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
7262 and cleaning up),
7263 and total wall time.
7264 
7265 Expected screen output:
7266 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page linear_adv_sine_librom_dmd_predict 1D Linear Advection - Sine Wave
7267 
7268 See \ref linear_adv_sine to familiarize yourself with this case. This example uses
7269 a DMD object that has already been trained (see \ref linear_adv_sine_librom_dmd_train).
7270 
7271 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict
7272  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7273  to run this case.)
7274 
7275 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
7276 
7277 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
7278 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7279 integrating in time.
7280 
7281 References:
7282  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
7283  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
7284  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
7285 
7286 Domain: \f$0 \le x < 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
7287  boundary conditions
7288 
7289 Initial solution: \f$u\left(x,0\right) = \sin\left(2\pi x\right)\f$
7290 
7291 Reduced Order Modeling:
7292  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7293  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7294  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7295 
7296 Note:
7297 -----
7298 
7299 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7300 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7301 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7302 comments:
7303 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7304  time integration methods).
7305 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7306  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7307  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7308 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7309  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7310 
7311 Input files required:
7312 ---------------------
7313 
7314 \b librom.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp
7315 
7316 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7317 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7318 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7319 using \ref linear_adv_sine_librom_dmd_train.
7320 
7321 \b solver.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp
7322 
7323 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
7324 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
7325 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
7326 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
7327 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
7328 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
7329 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
7330 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
7331 
7332 Output:
7333 -------
7334 After running the code, there should be the following output
7335 files:
7336 
7337 + 31 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00030.bin;
7338 these are the solutions as <B> predicted by the ROM </B>.
7339 
7340 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
7341 the final one is the solution at \f$t=3\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
7342 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
7343 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
7344 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7345 
7346 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotSolution_1DBinary.py)
7347 can be used to generate plots from these binary files.
7348 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
7349 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
7350 
7351 The animation shows the evolution of the solution.
7352 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvSinelibROM_DMD_Predict.gif
7353 
7354 Expected screen output:
7355 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/SineWave_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page linear_adv_disc_librom_dmd_predict 1D Linear Advection - Discontinuous Waves (Time Windowed DMD)
7356 
7357 See \ref linear_adv_disc to familiarize yourself with this case. This example uses
7358 a DMD object that has already been trained (see \ref linear_adv_disc_librom_dmd_train).
7359 
7360 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict
7361  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7362  to run this case.)
7363 
7364 Governing equations: 1D Linear Advection Equation (linearadr.h)
7365 
7366 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from trained time-windowed
7367 DMD objects. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7368 integrating in time.
7369 
7370 References:
7371  + Ghosh, D., Baeder, J. D., "Compact Reconstruction Schemes with
7372  Weighted ENO Limiting for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
7373  SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 34 (3), 2012, A1678–A1706
7374 
7375 Domain: \f$-1 \le x \le 1\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
7376  boundary conditions
7377 
7378 Initial solution:
7379  \f{equation}{
7380  u\left(x,0\right) = \left\{\begin{array}{lc}
7381  \exp\left(-\log\left(2\right)\frac{\left(x+7\right)^2}{0.0009}\right) & -0.8\le x \le -0.6 \\
7382  1 & -0.4\le x \le -0.2 \\
7383  1 - \left|10\left(x-0.1\right)\right| & 0\le x \le 0.2 \\
7384  \sqrt{1-100\left(x-0.5\right)^2} & 0.4\le x \le 0.6 \\
7385  0 & {\rm otherwise}
7386  \end{array}\right.
7387  \f}
7388 
7389 Reduced Order Modeling:
7390  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7391  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7392  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7393 
7394 Note:
7395 -----
7396 
7397 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7398 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7399 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7400 comments:
7401 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7402  time integration methods).
7403 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7404  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7405  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7406 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7407  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7408 
7409 Input files required:
7410 ---------------------
7411 
7412 \b librom.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp
7413 
7414 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7415 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7416 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7417 using \ref linear_adv_disc_librom_dmd_train.
7418 
7419 \b solver.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp
7420 
7421 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
7422 following code in the run directory. \b Note: if the
7423 final time is an integer multiple of the time period,
7424 the file \b initial.inp can also be used as the exact
7425 solution \b exact.inp (i.e. create a sym link called
7426 \a exact.inp pointing to \a initial.inp, or just copy
7427 \a initial.inp to \a exact.inp).
7428 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
7429 
7430 Output:
7431 -------
7432 After running the code, there should be the following output
7433 files:
7434 
7435 + 21 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00020.bin;
7436 these are the solutions as <B> predicted by the ROM </B>.
7437 
7438 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
7439 the final one is the solution at \f$t=3\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
7440 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
7441 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
7442 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7443 
7444 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotSolution_1DBinary.py)
7445 can be used to generate plots from these binary files.
7446 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
7447 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
7448 
7449 The animation shows the evolution of the solution.
7450 @image html Solution_1DLinearAdvDisclibROM_DMD_Predict.gif
7451 
7452 Expected screen output:
7453 \include 1D/LinearAdvection/DiscontinuousWaves_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page sod_shock_tube_librom_dmd_predict 1D Euler Equations - Sod Shock Tube (Time Windowed DMD)
7454 
7455 See \ref sod_shock_tube to familiarize yourself with this case. This example
7456 uses a DMD object that has already been trained (see \ref sod_shock_tube_librom_dmd_train).
7457 
7458 Location: \b hypar/Examples/1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict
7459  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7460  to run this case.)
7461 
7462 Governing equations: 1D Euler equations (euler1d.h)
7463 
7464 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
7465 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7466 integrating in time.
7467 
7468 References:
7469  + G.A. Sod, "A survey of several finite difference methods
7470  for systems of nonlinear hyperbolic conservation laws,"
7471  J. Comput. Phys., 27, 1 (1978).
7472  + C. B. Laney, "Computational Gasdynamics", Cambridge
7473  University Press, 1998.
7474 
7475 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 1.0\f$, \a "extrapolate" (#_EXTRAPOLATE_)
7476  boundary conditions
7477 
7478 Initial Solution:
7479  + \f$ 0 \le x < 0.5\f$: \f$\rho = 1, u = 0, p = 1\f$
7480  + \f$ 0.5 \le x \le 1\f$: \f$\rho = 0.125, u = 0, p = 0.1\f$
7481 
7482 Reduced Order Modeling:
7483  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7484  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7485  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7486 
7487 Note:
7488 -----
7489 
7490 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7491 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7492 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7493 comments:
7494 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7495  time integration methods).
7496 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7497  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7498  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7499 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7500  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7501 
7502 Input files required:
7503 --------------------
7504 
7505 \b librom.inp \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp
7506 
7507 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7508 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7509 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7510 using \ref sod_shock_tube_librom_dmd_train.
7511 
7512 \b solver.inp:
7513 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp
7514 
7515 To generate \b initial.inp, compile and run the
7516 following code in the run directory:
7517 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
7518 
7519 Output:
7520 -------
7521 After running the code, there should be the following output
7522 files:
7523 
7524 + 21 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00020.bin;
7525 these are the solutions as <B> predicted by the ROM </B>.
7526 
7527 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
7528 the final one is the solution at \f$t=0.2\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
7529 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
7530 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
7531 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7532 
7533 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotSolution_1DBinary.py)
7534 can be used to generate plots from these binary files.
7535 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text, and GNUPlot
7536 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
7537 
7538 The animation shows the evolution of the solution (density).
7539 @image html Solution_1DSodShockTubeROM_DMD_Predict.gif
7540 
7541 Expected screen output:
7542 \include 1D/Euler1D/SodShockTube_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page euler2d_vortex_librom_dmd_predict 2D Euler Equations - Isentropic Vortex Convection
7543 
7544 See \ref euler2d_vortex to familiarize yourself with this case.
7545 This example uses a DMD object that has already been trained
7546 (see \ref euler2d_vortex_librom_dmd_train).
7547 
7548 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict
7549  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7550  to run this case.)
7551 
7552 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
7553 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7554 integrating in time.
7555 
7556 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
7557  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
7558  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
7559  equations are solved.)
7560 
7561 Reference: C.-W. Shu, "Essentially Non-oscillatory and Weighted Essentially
7562  Non-oscillatory Schemes for Hyperbolic Conservation Laws",
7563  ICASE Report 97-65, 1997
7564 
7565 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y \le 10\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
7566  boundary conditions.
7567 
7568 Initial solution: The freestream flow is given by
7569 \f{equation}{
7570  \rho_\infty = 1,\ u_\infty = 0.1,\ v_\infty = 0,\ p_\infty = 1
7571 \f}
7572 and a vortex is introduced, specified as
7573 \f{align}{
7574 \rho &= \left[ 1 - \frac{\left(\gamma-1\right)b^2}{8\gamma\pi^2} e^{1-r^2} \right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},\ p = \rho^\gamma, \\
7575 u &= u_\infty - \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(y-y_c\right),\ v = v_\infty + \frac{b}{2\pi} e^{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-r^2\right)} \left(x-x_c\right),
7576 \f}
7577 where \f$b=0.5\f$ is the vortex strength and \f$r = \left[(x-x_c)^2 + (y-y_c)^2 \right]^{1/2}\f$ is the distance from the vortex center \f$\left(x_c,y_c\right) = \left(5,5\right)\f$.
7578 
7579 Reduced Order Modeling:
7580  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7581  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7582  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7583 
7584 Note:
7585 -----
7586 
7587 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7588 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7589 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7590 comments:
7591 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7592  time integration methods).
7593 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7594  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7595  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7596 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7597  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7598 
7599 Input files required:
7600 ---------------------
7601 
7602 \b librom.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp
7603 
7604 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7605 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7606 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7607 using \ref euler2d_vortex_librom_dmd_train.
7608 
7609 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp
7610 
7611 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution) and \b exact.inp
7612 (exact solution), compile and run the following code in the run
7613 directory.
7614 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/exact.c
7615 
7616 Output:
7617 -------
7618 Note that \b iproc is set to
7619 
7620  4 4
7621 
7622 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
7623 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
7624 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
7625 
7626 After running the code, there should be the following output
7627 files:
7628 
7629 + 41 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00040.bin;
7630 these are the solutions as <B> predicted by the ROM </B>.
7631 
7632 The first of each of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
7633 the final one is the solution at \f$t=40\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
7634 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
7635 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
7636 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7637 
7638 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotSolution_2DBinary.py)
7639 can be used to generate plots from these binary files.
7640 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a text or \a tecplot2d, and
7641 Tecplot/VisIt or something similar can be used to plot the resulting files.
7642 
7643 The animation shows the evolution of the solution (density).
7644 @image html Solution_2DNavStokVortex_libROM_DMD_Predict.gif
7645 
7646 Since the exact solution is available at the final time (\a exact.inp), the numerical
7647 errors are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
7648 as well as \b errors.dat:
7649 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/errors.dat
7650 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
7651 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
7652 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
7653 L1, L2, and L-infinity errors (#HyPar::error),
7654 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
7655 and cleaning up),
7656 and total wall time.
7657 
7658 Expected screen output:
7659 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InviscidVortexConvection_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page navstok2d_ldsc_librom_dmd_predict 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Lid-Driven Square Cavity (Time-Windowed DMD)
7660 
7661 See \ref navstok2d_ldsc to familiarize yourself with this case.
7662 This example uses a DMD object that has already been trained
7663 (see \ref navstok2d_ldsc_librom_dmd_train).
7664 
7665 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict
7666  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7667  to run this case.)
7668 
7669 Governing equations: 2D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
7670 
7671 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
7672 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7673 integrating in time.
7674 
7675 Reference:
7676 + Erturk, E., Corke, T.C., and Gokcol, C., Numerical Solutions of
7677  2-D Steady Incompressible Driven Cavity Flow at High Reynolds Numbers,
7678  International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids, 48, 2005,
7679  http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/fld.953.
7680 + Ghia, U., Ghia, K.N., Shin, C.T., High-Re Solutions for Incompressible
7681  Flow using the Navier-Stokes Equations and a Multigrid Method, Journal
7682  of Computational Physics, 48, 1982, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0021-9991(82)90058-4.
7683 
7684 Note that this is an incompressible problem being solved here using the compressible
7685 Navier-Stokes equations in terms of non-dimensional flow variables. The density and
7686 pressure are taken such that the speed of sound is 1.0, and the flow velocities
7687 specified in the initial and boundary conditions correspond to a characteristic
7688 Mach number of 0.1 (thus, they are 0.1 times the values in the above reference).
7689 
7690 Domain: \f$0 \le x, y \le 1\f$
7691 
7692 Boundary conditions:
7693 + No-slip wall BC on \f$x=0,1, 0 \le y \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
7694 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
7695 + Moving no-slip wall BC on \f$y=1, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with specified
7696  wall velocity of 0.1 in the x-direction).
7697 
7698 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, p=1/\gamma\f$. The velocities are specified according to
7699 the references above, but scaled by a factor of 0.1 to ensure that the characteristic
7700 Mach number is 0.1.
7701 
7702 Other parameters:
7703  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
7704  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 100, 1000, 3200\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
7705  where \f$L=1\f$ is the cavity length and width.
7706  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
7707  + \f$M_\infty = 0.1\f$ (characteristic Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
7708 
7709 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
7710 speed of sound is 1.
7711 
7712 Reduced Order Modeling:
7713  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7714  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7715  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7716 
7717 Note:
7718 -----
7719 
7720 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7721 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7722 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7723 comments:
7724 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7725  time integration methods).
7726 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7727  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7728  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7729 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7730  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7731 
7732 
7733 Input files required:
7734 ---------------------
7735 
7736 \b librom.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp
7737 
7738 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7739 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7740 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7741 using \ref navstok2d_ldsc_librom_dmd_train.
7742 
7743 \b solver.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp (\b Note: this file specifies \f$Re = 3200\f$,
7744 change \a Re here for other Reynolds numbers.)
7745 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp
7746 
7747 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
7748 and run the following code in the run directory
7749 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
7750 
7751 Output:
7752 -------
7753 Note that \b iproc is set to
7754 
7755  4 4
7756 
7757 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
7758 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
7759 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
7760 
7761 After running the code, there should be the following output
7762 files:
7763 
7764 + 1 output file \b op.bin;
7765 this is the solutions as <B> predicted by the ROM </B>.
7766 
7767 It is a binary file.
7768 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7769 
7770 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotStreamlines_2DBinary.py)
7771 can be used to generate streamline plots from the binary file.
7772 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d, and Tecplot/VisIt
7773 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting files.
7774 
7775 The following plot shows the final solution (velocity streamlines colored by
7776 the velocity magnitude):
7777 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re3200_libROM_DMD_Predict.png
7778 
7779 Expected screen output:
7780 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log
7781 
7782 \page vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent_librom_dmd_predict 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation - Two-Stream Instability (Time-Windowed DMD)
7783 
7784 See \ref vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent to familiarize yourself with this case.
7785 This example uses a DMD object that has already been trained
7786 (see \ref vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent_librom_dmd_train).
7787 
7788 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict
7789  (This directory contains all the input files needed
7790  to run this case.)
7791 
7792 Governing equations: 2D (1D-1V) Vlasov Equation (vlasov.h)
7793 
7794 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
7795 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7796 integrating in time.
7797 
7798 Domain:
7799  + \f$0 \le x < 2\pi\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
7800  + \f$-7 \le y < 7\f$, \a "dirichlet" (#_DIRICHLET_) (\f$f = 0\f$)
7801 
7802 Initial solution:
7803 \f$f\left(x,v\right) = \frac{4}{\pi T}\left(1+\frac{1}{10}\cos\left(2k\pi\frac{x}{L}\right)\right)\left[\exp\left(-\frac{\left(v-2\right)^2}{2T}\right) + \exp\left(-\frac{\left(v+2\right)^2}{2T}\right)\right]\f$, \f$k=1,T=1,L=2\pi\f$.
7804 
7805 Self-consistent electric field is computed by solving the Poisson equation
7806 in a periodic domain using Fourier transforms. This examples *requires* HyPar
7807 to be compiled with FFTW (http://www.fftw.org/).
7808 
7809 Reduced Order Modeling:
7810  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7811  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7812  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7813 
7814 Note:
7815 -----
7816 
7817 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7818 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7819 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7820 comments:
7821 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7822  time integration methods).
7823 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7824  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7825  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7826 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7827  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7828 
7829 Input files required:
7830 ---------------------
7831 
7832 \b librom.inp \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp
7833 
7834 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7835 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7836 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7837 using \ref vlasov_1d1v_selfconsistent_librom_dmd_train.
7838 
7839 \b solver.inp \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp
7840 
7841 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile and run the
7842 following code in the run directory.
7843 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
7844 
7845 Output:
7846 -------
7847 Note that \b iproc is set to
7848 
7849  4 4
7850 
7851 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
7852 processors along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
7853 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
7854 
7855 After running the code, there should be the following output
7856 files:
7857 
7858 + 26 output files \b op_00000.bin, \b op_00001.bin, ... \b op_00025.bin;
7859 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
7860 
7861 The first of these file sets is the solution at \f$t=0\f$ and
7862 the final one is the solution at \f$t=5\f$. Since #HyPar::op_overwrite is
7863 set to \a no in \b solver.inp, a separate file is written
7864 for solutions at each output time. All the files are binary
7865 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7866 
7867 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotSolution_2DBinary.py)
7868 can be used to generate plots from the binary files that compare the HyPar and DMD
7869 solutions. Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d or \a text,
7870 and Tecplot/VisIt or something similar can be used to plot the resulting files.
7871 
7872 The following plot shows the evolution of the distribution function:
7873 @image html Solution_1D1VVlasov_SelfConsistentE_libROM_DMD_Predict.gif
7874 
7875 Expected screen output:
7876 \include 2D/Vlasov1D1V/SelfConsistentElectricField_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_predict 3D Navier-Stokes - Steady, incompressible, viscous flow around a cylinder (Time-Windowed DMD)
7877 
7878 See \ref ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous to familiarize yourself with this case.
7879 This example uses a DMD object that has already been trained
7880 (see \ref ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_train).
7881 
7882 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict
7883 
7884 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
7885 
7886 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
7887 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
7888 integrating in time.
7889 
7890 Domain: The domain consists of a fine uniform grid around the cylinder defined by [-2,6] X [-2,2],
7891  and a stretched grid beyond this zone.
7892 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
7893  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
7894  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
7895 
7896 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
7897  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
7898 
7899 See \ref ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous for pictures showing the domain and geometry.
7900 
7901 Boundary conditions:
7902  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_
7903  + xmax: Subsonic outflow #_SUBSONIC_OUTFLOW_
7904  + ymin and ymax: Subsonic "ambivalent" #_SUBSONIC_AMBIVALENT_
7905  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
7906  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
7907  (this is the default).
7908 
7909 Reference:
7910  + Taneda, S., "Experimental Investigation of the Wakes behind Cylinders and Plates at Low
7911  Reynolds Numbers," Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, Vol. 11, 302–307, 1956.
7912  + Dennis, S. C. R., Chang, G.-Z., "Numerical solutions for steady flow past a circular
7913  cylinder at Reynolds numbers up to 100", Journal of Fluid Mechanics, 42 (3), 1970,
7914  pp. 471-489.
7915 
7916 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, u=0.1, v=w=0, p=1/\gamma\f$ everywhere in the domain.
7917 
7918 Other parameters:
7919  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
7920  + Freestream Mach number \f$M_{\infty} = 0.1\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Minf)
7921  + Prandlt number \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Pr)
7922  + Reynolds number \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 10\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::Re) (\b Note:
7923  since the diameter of the cylinder is 2.0, the cylinder-diameter-based Reynolds number is
7924  \f$Re_D = 2Re = 20\f$.
7925 
7926 Reduced Order Modeling:
7927  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
7928  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
7929  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
7930 
7931 Note:
7932 -----
7933 
7934 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
7935 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
7936 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
7937 comments:
7938 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
7939  time integration methods).
7940 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
7941  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
7942  need not respect any CFL criterion.
7943 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
7944  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
7945 
7946 Input files required:
7947 ---------------------
7948 
7949 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
7950 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
7951 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
7952 using \ref ns3d_cylinder_steady_incompressible_viscous_librom_dmd_train.
7953 
7954 \b librom.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp \b solver.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp : The following file specifies a Reynolds number
7955 of 10 (corresponding to \f$Re_D\f$ of 20). To try other Reynolds
7956 numbers, change it here.
7957 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
7958 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
7959 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
7960 
7961 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
7962 and run the following code in the run directory.
7963 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
7964 
7965 Output:
7966 -------
7967 
7968 Note that \b iproc is set to
7969 
7970  8 4 1
7971 
7972 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 8 processors along \a x, 4
7973 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
7974 this example should be run with 32 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
7975 
7976 Please see the original example in the "Immersed Boundaries Examples" section
7977 for a full description of the output files and how to view them. The following only
7978 contains libROM-specific comments.
7979 
7980 After running the code, there should be the following output
7981 files:
7982 
7983 + 1 output file \b op.bin;
7984 this is the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
7985 
7986 The files is in binary format.
7987 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
7988 
7989 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
7990 can be used to generate plots from the binary files.
7991 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot3d, and Tecplot/VisIt
7992 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
7993 
7994 The following figure shows the flow at \f$Re_D=20\f$. The pressure is plotted in the overall
7995 domain, and the wake is shown by plotting the x-velocity, where it is negative.
7996 @image html Solution_3DNavStokCylinder_ReD020_libROM_DMD_Predict.png
7997 
7998 Expected screen output:
7999 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Cylinder/Steady_Viscous_Incompressible_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction_librom_dmd_predict 3D Navier-Stokes - Inviscid Shock-Cylinder Interaction (Time-Windowed DMD)
8000 
8001 See \ref ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction to familiarize yourself with this case.
8002 This example uses a DMD object that has already been trained
8003 (see \ref ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction_librom_dmd_train).
8004 
8005 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict
8006 
8007 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h - by default
8008  #NavierStokes3D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
8009  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 3D Euler
8010  equations are solved.)
8011 
8012 Reduced Order Modeling: This example predicts the solution from a trained
8013 DMD object. The code does \b not solve the PDE by discretizing in space and
8014 integrating in time.
8015 
8016 Domain: \f$-2.5 \le x \le 7.5\f$, \f$-5 \le y \le 5\f$
8017 \b Note: This is a 2D flow simulated using a 3-dimensional setup by taking the length of the
8018  domain along \a z to be very small and with only 3 grid points (the domain size along \a z
8019  \b must \b be smaller than the cylinder length).
8020 
8021 Geometry: A cylinder of radius 1.0 centered at (0,0)
8022  (\b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl)
8023 
8024 Boundary conditions:
8025  + xmin: Subsonic inflow #_SUBSONIC_INFLOW_ (with post-shock flow conditions)
8026  + xmax: Supersonic inflow #_SUPERSONIC_OUTFLOW_ (with pre-shock flow conditions)
8027  + ymin and ymax: Slip walls #_SLIP_WALL_
8028  + zmin and zmax: Periodic #_PERIODIC_ (to simulate a 2D flow in the x-y plane)
8029  + The immersed body wall is specified as adiabatic (#_IB_ADIABATIC_);
8030  (this is the default).
8031 
8032 Reference:
8033 + O. Boiron, G. Chiavassa, R. Donat, A high-resolution penalization method for large Mach number
8034  flows in the presence of obstacles, Computers & Fluids, 38 (2009), pp. 703-714, Section 5.1
8035 
8036 Initial solution: see reference
8037 
8038 Other parameters:
8039  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
8040 
8041 Reduced Order Modeling:
8042  + Mode: predict (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_PREDICT_)
8043  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
8044  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
8045 
8046 Note:
8047 -----
8048 
8049 In this mode, HyPar will run just like an usual PDE simulation, except that it will swap out
8050 the numerical spatial discretization and time integration with the ROM-based prediction. The
8051 input files and output files will be the same as a regular simulation with the following
8052 comments:
8053 + Numerical method inputs are ignored (eg. those that specify spatial discretization and
8054  time integration methods).
8055 + In solver.inp, the values for dt, n_iter, and file_op_iter is used only to compute the
8056  simulation times at which to compute and write the solution. The time step size, dt,
8057  need not respect any CFL criterion.
8058 + #HyPar::ConservationCheck is set to "no" since it is not possible to compute conservation
8059  loss for a general domain (because boundary fluxes are not being computed).
8060 
8061 Input files required:
8062 ---------------------
8063 
8064 <B> DMD Object(s) </B>:\n
8065 The trained DMD object(s) must be located in the directory specified in \b librom.inp
8066 as \a dmd_dirname (#DMDROMObject::m_dirname). For this example, they were generated
8067 using \ref ns3d_shock_cylinder_interaction_librom_dmd_train.
8068 
8069 \b librom.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict/librom.inp \b solver.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict/solver.inp \b boundary.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict/boundary.inp \b physics.inp \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict/physics.inp \b cylinder.stl : the filename "cylinder.stl" \b must match
8070 the input for \a immersed_body in \a solver.inp.\n
8071 Located at \b hypar/Examples/STLGeometries/cylinder.stl
8072 
8073 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
8074 and run the following code in the run directory.
8075 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict/aux/init.c
8076 
8077 Output:
8078 -------
8079 
8080 Note that \b iproc is set to
8081 
8082  4 4 1
8083 
8084 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, 4
8085 processors along \a y, and 1 processor along \a z). Thus,
8086 this example should be run with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
8087 
8088 Please see the original example in the "Immersed Boundaries Examples" section
8089 for a full description of the output files and how to view them. The following only
8090 contains libROM-specific comments.
8091 
8092 After running the code, there should be the following output
8093 files:
8094 
8095 + 11 output file \b op_00000.bin, ..., op_00010.bin;
8096 these are the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
8097 
8098 All the files are binary
8099 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
8100 
8101 The provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
8102 can be used to generate plots from the binary files.
8103 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot3d, and Tecplot/VisIt
8104 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting text files.
8105 
8106 The following plot shows the density contours for the final solution (t=2).
8107 @image html Solution_3DNavStokShockCyl_Density_libROM_DMD_Predict.png
8108 
8109 Expected screen output:
8110 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/2D_Shock_Cylinder_Interaction_libROM_DMD_Predict/out.log \page ns2d_ldsc_petsc_implicit 2D Navier-Stokes Equations - Lid-Driven Square Cavity
8111 
8112 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit
8113  (This directory contains all the input files needed
8114  to run this case.)
8115 
8116 Governing equations: 2D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes2d.h)
8117 
8118 Reference:
8119 + Erturk, E., Corke, T.C., and Gokcol, C., "Numerical Solutions of
8120  2-D Steady Incompressible Driven Cavity Flow at High Reynolds Numbers",
8121  International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids, 48, 2005,
8122  http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/fld.953.
8123 + Ghia, U., Ghia, K.N., Shin, C.T., "High-Re Solutions for Incompressible
8124  Flow using the Navier-Stokes Equations and a Multigrid Method", Journal
8125  of Computational Physics, 48, 1982, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0021-9991(82)90058-4.
8126 
8127 Note that this is an incompressible problem being solved here using the compressible
8128 Navier-Stokes equations in terms of non-dimensional flow variables. The density and
8129 pressure are taken such that the speed of sound is 1.0, and the flow velocities
8130 specified in the initial and boundary conditions correspond to a characteristic
8131 Mach number of 0.1 (thus, they are 0.1 times the values in the above reference).
8132 
8133 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
8134 integration, but with the entire RHS on the implicit side
8135 (by setting the \b -ts_arkimex_fully_implicit flag in PETSc inputs).
8136 So, the time integration is implicit (a 6-stage, 4-th order DIRK).
8137 
8138 Domain: \f$0 \le x, y \le 1\f$
8139 
8140 Boundary conditions:
8141 + No-slip wall BC on \f$x=0,1, 0 \le y \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
8142 + No-slip wall BC on \f$y=0, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with 0 wall velocity).
8143 + Moving no-slip wall BC on \f$y=1, 0 \le x \le 1\f$ (#_NOSLIP_WALL_ with specified
8144  wall velocity of 0.1 in the x-direction).
8145 
8146 Initial solution: \f$\rho=1, p=1/\gamma\f$. The velocities are specified according to
8147 the references above, but scaled by a factor of 0.1 to ensure that the characteristic
8148 Mach number is 0.1.
8149 
8150 Other parameters:
8151  + \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
8152  + \f$Re = \frac {\rho u L } {\mu} = 3200\f$ (Reynolds number) (#NavierStokes2D::Re),
8153  where \f$L=1\f$ is the cavity length and width.
8154  + \f$Pr = 0.72\f$ (Prandtl number) (#NavierStokes2D::Pr)
8155  + \f$M_\infty = 0.1\f$ (characteristic Mach number) (#NavierStokes2D::Minf)
8156 
8157 \b Note: Pressure is taken as \f$1/\gamma\f$ in the above so that the freestream
8158 speed of sound is 1.
8159 
8160 Numerical method:
8161  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderUpwind())
8162  + Spatial discretization (parabolic) : 4th order (FirstDerivativeFourthOrderCentral())
8163  non-conservative 2-stage (ParabolicFunctionNC2Stage())
8164  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
8165  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (fully-implicit mode) (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
8166  - Specific method: implicit part of <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
8167 
8168 Input files required:
8169 ---------------------
8170 
8171 <B>.petscrc</B>
8172 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/petscrc
8173 
8174 \b solver.inp
8175 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/solver.inp
8176 
8177 \b boundary.inp
8178 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/boundary.inp
8179 
8180 \b physics.inp (\b Note: this file specifies \f$Re = 3200\f$,
8181 change \a Re here for other Reynolds numbers.)
8182 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/physics.inp
8183 
8184 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
8185 and run the following code in the run directory.
8186 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/aux/init.c
8187 
8188 Output:
8189 -------
8190 Note that \b iproc is set to
8191 
8192  4 4
8193 
8194 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, and 4
8195 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
8196 with 16 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
8197 
8198 After running the code, there should be one output file
8199 \b op.bin, since #HyPar::op_overwrite is set to \a yes in \b solver.inp.
8200 Since #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp.
8201 
8202 The provided Python script (\b Examples/Python/plotStreamlines_2DBinary.py)
8203 can be used to generate streamline plots from the binary file.
8204 Alternatively, #HyPar::op_file_format can be set to \a tecplot2d, and Tecplot/VisIt
8205 or something similar can be used to plot the resulting files.
8206 
8207 The following plot shows the final solution (velocity streamlines colored by
8208 the velocity magnitude):
8209 @image html Solution_2DNavStokLDSC_Re3200_PETSc_Implicit.png
8210 
8211 The file <B>function_counts.dat</B> reports the computational expense
8212 (in terms of the number of function counts):
8213 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/function_counts.dat
8214 The numbers are, respectively,
8215 + Time iterations
8216 + Number of times the hyperbolic term was evaluated
8217 + Number of times the parabolic term was evaluated
8218 + Number of times the source term was evaluated
8219 + Number of calls to the explicit right-hand-side function (PetscRHSFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionExpl())
8220 + Number of calls to the implicit right-hand-side function (PetscIFunctionIMEX() or PetscRHSFunctionImpl())
8221 + Number of calls to the Jacobian (PetscIJacobianIMEX() or PetscIJacobian())
8222 + Number of calls to the matrix-free Jacobian function (PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_Linear(), PetscJacobianFunctionIMEX_JFNK(), PetscJacobianFunction_JFNK(), or PetscJacobianFunction_Linear()).
8223 
8224 Expected screen output (for Reynolds number 3200):
8225 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/LidDrivenCavity_PETSc_Implicit/out.log
8226 
8227 \page euler2d_igwave_petsc_librom_dmd_train 2D Euler Equations (with gravitational force) - Inertia-Gravity Waves (Time-Windowed DMD) with PETSc IMEX time integration
8228 
8229 See \ref euler2d_igwave_petsc to familiarize yourself with this case.
8230
