8231 Location: \b hypar/Examples/2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train
8232  (This directory contains all the input files needed
8233  to run this case.)
8234 
8235 Governing equations: 2D Euler Equations (navierstokes2d.h - By default,
8236  #NavierStokes2D::Re is set to \b -1 which makes the
8237  code skip the parabolic terms, i.e., the 2D Euler
8238  equations are solved.)
8239 
8240 Reduced Order Modeling: This example trains a DMD object and then
8241 predicts the solution using the DMD at the same times that the
8242 actual HyPar solution is written at.
8243 
8244 Reference:
8245  + W. C. Skamarock and J. B. Klemp, "Efficiency and accuracy of
8246  the Klemp-Wilhelmson timesplitting technique", Monthly Weather
8247  Review, 122 (1994), pp. 2623–2630.
8248  + Giraldo, F.X., Restelli, M., "A study of spectral element and
8249  discontinuous Galerkin methods for the Navier–Stokes equations
8250  in nonhydrostatic mesoscale atmospheric modeling: Equation sets
8251  and test cases", J. Comput. Phys., 227, 2008, 3849--3877,
8252  (Section 3.1).
8253 
8254 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
8255 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
8256 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
8257 latter integrated implicitly. See the following reference:
8258 + Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
8259  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
8260  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
8261  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
8262 
8263 Domain: \f$0 \le x \le 300,000\,m, 0 \le y \le 10,000\,m\f$, \a "periodic" (#_PERIODIC_)
8264  boundary conditions along \f$x\f$, "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundary conditions along \f$y\f$.
8265 
8266 Initial solution: See references above.
8267 
8268 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
8269  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::gamma)
8270  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::R)
8271  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes2D::grav_y)
8272  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::rho0)
8273  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes2D::p0)
8274  + Hydrostatic balance type 3 (#NavierStokes2D::HB)
8275  + Brunt-Vaisala frequency 0.01 (#NavierStokes2D::N_bv)
8276 
8277 Numerical method:
8278  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order compact upwind (Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind())
8279  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
8280  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
8281  - Specific method: <B>Kennedy-Carpenter ARK4</B> (TSARKIMEX4 - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX4.html)
8282 
8283 Reduced Order Modeling:
8284  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
8285  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
8286  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
8287  + Latent subspace dimension: 32 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
8288  + Sampling frequency: 1 (libROMInterface::m_sampling_freq)
8289  + Number of samples per time window: 50 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
8290 
8291 
8292 Input files required:
8293 ---------------------
8294 
8295 <B>librom.inp</B>
8296 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
8297 
8298 <B>.petscrc</B>
8299 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/petscrc
8300 
8301 \b solver.inp
8302 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
8303 
8304 \b boundary.inp
8305 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
8306 
8307 \b physics.inp
8308 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
8309 
8310 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
8311 and run the following code in the run directory.
8312 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
8313 
8314 Output:
8315 -------
8316 Note that \b iproc is set to
8317 
8318  24 1
8319 
8320 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 24 processors along \a x, and 1
8321 processor along \a y). Thus, this example should be run
8322 with 24 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
8323 
8324 After running the code, there should be the following output
8325 files:
8326 
8327 + 16 output file \b op_00000.bin, ..., \b op_00015.bin;
8328 this is the \b HyPar solutions\b.
8329 
8330 + 16 output file \b op_rom_00000.bin, ..., \b op_rom_00015.bin;
8331 this is the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
8332 
8333 All the files are binary
8334 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
8335 
8336 #HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp, and
8337 thus, all the files are written out in the binary format, see
8338 WriteBinary(). The binary file contains the conserved variables
8339 \f$\left(\rho, \rho u, \rho v, e\right)\f$. The following code
8340 converts these variables to the primitive variables of interest
8341 to atmospheric flows \f$\left(\rho, u, v, p, \theta\right)\f$.
8342 It also writes out the hydrostatically balanced quantities
8343 \f$\left(\rho_0,\pi_0, \theta_0\right)\f$ for this case that
8344 can be used to compute and plot the temperature and density
8345 perturbations. These variables are then written to either
8346 a tecplot2d or text file.
8347 (compile and run it in the run directory):
8348 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/PostProcess.c
8349 
8350 Alternatively, the provided Python script (\b plotSolution.py)
8351 can be used to generate plots from the binary files of the atmospheric
8352 flow variables and compare the HyPar and DMD
8353 solutions. It will plot the potential temperature perturbation but can
8354 be modified easily to plot other quantities.
8355 
8356 The following plot shows the potential temperature perturbation
8357 contours at the final time t=3000 (FOM is the HyPar solution, ROM is
8358 the DMD prediction, and diff is the difference between the two):
8359 @image html Solution_2DNavStokIGWavePETSc_libROMDMD_Train.png \b Wall \b clock \b times:
8360 - PDE solution: 521 seconds
8361 - DMD training time: 15.1 seconds
8362 - DMD prediction/query time: 8.7 seconds
8363 
8364 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
8365 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
8366 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
8367 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
8368 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
8369 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
8370 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
8371 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
8372 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
8373 and cleaning up),
8374 and total wall time.
8375 
8376 Expected screen output:
8377 \include 2D/NavierStokes2D/InertiaGravityWave_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log \page ns3d_bubble_petsc_librom_dmd_train 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (with gravitational force) - Rising Thermal Bubble (Time-Windowed DMD) with PETSc IMEX time integration
8378 
8379 See \ref ns3d_bubble_petsc to familiarize yourself with this case.
8380 
8381 Location: \b hypar/Examples/3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train
8382  (This directory contains all the input files needed
8383  to run this case.)
8384 
8385 Governing equations: 3D Navier-Stokes Equations (navierstokes3d.h)
8386 
8387 Domain: \f$0 \le x,y,z < 1000\,{\rm m}\f$, \a "slip-wall" (#_SLIP_WALL_) boundaries
8388  everywhere, with zero wall velocity.
8389 
8390 Reference:
8391  + Kelly, J. F., Giraldo, F. X., "Continuous and discontinuous Galerkin methods for a scalable
8392  three-dimensional nonhydrostatic atmospheric model: Limited-area mode", J. Comput. Phys., 231,
8393  2012, pp. 7988-8008 (see section 5.1.2).
8394  + Giraldo, F. X., Kelly, J. F., Constantinescu, E. M., "Implicit-Explicit Formulations of a
8395  Three-Dimensional Nonhydrostatic Unified Model of the Atmosphere (NUMA)", SIAM J. Sci. Comput.,
8396  35 (5), 2013, pp. B1162-B1194 (see section 4.1).
8397 
8398 The problem is solved here using <B>implicit-explicit (IMEX)</B> time
8399 integration, where the hyperbolic flux is partitioned into its entropy
8400 and acoustic components with the former integrated explicitly and the
8401 latter integrated implicitly. See the following reference:
8402 + Ghosh, D., Constantinescu, E. M., "Semi-Implicit Time Integration of
8403  Atmospheric Flows with Characteristic-Based Flux Partitioning", SIAM
8404  Journal on Scientific Computing, 38 (3), 2016, A1848-A1875,
8405  http://dx.doi.org/10.1137/15M1044369.
8406 
8407 Initial solution: A warm bubble in cool ambient atmosphere. Note that in this example, the
8408 gravitational forces and rising of the bubble is along the \a y-axis.
8409 
8410 Other parameters (all dimensional quantities are in SI units):
8411  + Specific heat ratio \f$\gamma = 1.4\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::gamma)
8412  + Universal gas constant \f$R = 287.058\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::R)
8413  + Gravitational force per unit mass \f$g = 9.8\f$ along \a y-axis (#NavierStokes3D::grav_y)
8414  + Reference density (at zero altitude) \f$\rho_{ref} = 1.1612055171196529\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::rho0)
8415  + Reference pressure (at zero altitude) \f$P_{ref} = 100000\f$ (#NavierStokes3D::p0)
8416  + Hydrostatic balance type 2 (#NavierStokes3D::HB)
8417 
8418 Numerical Method:
8419  + Spatial discretization (hyperbolic): 5th order WENO (Interp1PrimFifthOrderWENO())
8420  + Time integration: PETSc (SolvePETSc())
8421  - Method Class: <B>Additive Runge-Kutta method</B> (TSARKIMEX - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX.html)
8422  - Specific method: <B>ARK 2e</B> (TSARKIMEX2E - https://petsc.org/release/docs/manualpages/TS/TSARKIMEX2E.html)
8423 
8424 Reduced Order Modeling:
8425  + Mode: train (libROMInterface::m_mode, #_ROM_MODE_TRAIN_)
8426  + Component Mode: monolithic (libROMInterface::m_comp_mode, #_ROM_COMP_MODE_MONOLITHIC_)
8427  + Type: Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) with time windowing (libROMInterface::m_rom_type)
8428  + Latent subspace dimension: 16 (DMDROMObject::m_rdim)
8429  + Sampling frequency: 1 (libROMInterface::m_sampling_freq)
8430  + Number of samples per time window: 50 (DMDROMObject::m_num_window_samples)
8431 
8432 Input files required:
8433 ---------------------
8434 
8435 <B>.petscrc</B>
8436 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/petscrc
8437 
8438 \b librom.inp
8439 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/librom.inp
8440 
8441 \b solver.inp
8442 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/solver.inp
8443 
8444 \b boundary.inp
8445 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/boundary.inp
8446 
8447 \b physics.inp
8448 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/physics.inp
8449 
8450 \b weno.inp (optional)
8451 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/weno.inp
8452 
8453 To generate \b initial.inp (initial solution), compile
8454 and run the following code in the run directory.
8455 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/aux/init.c
8456 
8457 Output:
8458 -------
8459 Note that \b iproc is set to
8460 
8461  4 4 4
8462 
8463 in \b solver.inp (i.e., 4 processors along \a x, 4
8464 processors along \a y, and 4 processor along \a z). Thus,
8465 this example should be run with 64 MPI ranks (or change \b iproc).
8466 
8467 After running the code, there should be the following output
8468 files:
8469 
8470 + 11 output file \b op_00000.bin, ..., \b op_00010.bin;
8471 this is the \b HyPar solutions\b.
8472 
8473 + 11 output file \b op_rom_00000.bin, ..., \b op_rom_00010.bin;
8474 this is the \b predicted solutions from the DMD object(s)\b.
8475 
8476 All the files are binary
8477 (#HyPar::op_file_format is set to \a binary in \b solver.inp).
8478 
8479 The binary solution file contains the conserved variables
8480 (\f$\rho,\rho u,\rho v,\rho w,e\f$).
8481 
8482 The Python script plotSolution.py calculates the primitive
8483 and reference variables
8484 \f$\rho,u,v,w,P,\theta,\rho_0,P_0,\pi,\theta_0\f$ (where the
8485 subscript \f$0\f$ indicates the hydrostatic mean value) for both
8486 the op_* and op_rom_* files. It plots 3D figures for \f$\theta\f$
8487 (potential temperature) for the PDE solution, the DMD predictions,
8488 and the difference between the two.
8489 
8490 The following figure shows the potential temperature at the final time. Colored
8491 contours are plotted in the X-Y plane, and contour lines are plotted in the Z-Y
8492 plane (FOM is the HyPar solution, ROM is the DMD prediction, and diff is the
8493 difference between the two):
8494 @image html Solution_3DNavStok_Bubble3D_PETSc_libROMDMD_Train.png
8495 
8496 \b Wall \b clock \b times:
8497 - PDE solution: 906 seconds
8498 - DMD training time: 22.5 seconds
8499 - DMD prediction/query time: 4.5 seconds
8500 
8501 The L1, L2, and Linf norms of the diff between the HyPar and ROM solution
8502 at the final time are calculated and reported on screen (see below)
8503 as well as \b pde_rom_diff.dat:
8504 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/pde_rom_diff.dat
8505 The numbers are: number of grid points in each dimension (#HyPar::dim_global),
8506 number of processors in each dimension (#MPIVariables::iproc),
8507 time step size (#HyPar::dt),
8508 L1, L2, and L-infinity norms of the diff (#HyPar::rom_diff_norms),
8509 solver wall time (seconds) (i.e., not accounting for initialization,
8510 and cleaning up),
8511 and total wall time.
8512 
8513 Expected screen output:
8514 \include 3D/NavierStokes3D/RisingThermalBubble_PETSc_IMEX_libROM_DMD_Train/out.log
8515

Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind
int Interp1PrimFifthOrderCompactUpwind(double *, double *, double *, double *, int, int, void *, void *, int)
5th order compact upwind reconstruction (component-wise) on a uniform grid
